sec_questions: Heat-shock treatment is a method in which the vial is incubated in ice, then treated at temperature up to 50°C and again transferred on ice. It is usually used in transferring recombinant DNA within the host (bacterial cell).
The method by which recombinant DNA is directly injected into the nucleus of an animal cell is called ________.
The method by which recombinant DNA is directly injected into the nucleus of an animal cell is called micro-injection. A glass micropipette is used for injecting the material into cells.
Biolistics is also known as a gene gun. It is a method in which cells are bombarded with high-velocity micro-particles of gold or tungsten coated with DNA. It is mostly used for plant cells.
What temperature is suitable for heat-shock treatment?
42°C-45°C is the ideal temperature for heat-shock treatment. Mostly calcium chloride is used in this. It is suitable for the transformation of bacterial cells such as E.coli.
Which metal microparticles are used in gene gun?
The microparticles of gold-coated with DNA are used in gene gun technique. Aurum is a Latin word for gold. Other metal used for this technique is tungsten.

Biolistics or gene gun is the method that uses a ‘disarmed pathogen’ vector. A pathogen from which virulence or disease-causing genes are removed is known as a disarmed pathogen. It is a process in which DNA is transferred into a host without any risk of infection.
The nucleic acid in most of the organisms is ______

Most of the organisms consist of DNA as their genetic material. DNA stands for deoxyribonucleic acid. It is the hereditary material of most of the humans and almost all animals (exception-some viruses). It is double-stranded and is more stable than RNA.
The bacterial cells can be lysed by using ______ enzyme.
The enzyme used for breaking or lysis of bacterial cells is lysozyme. It helps in the breakdown of carbohydrates found in a bacterial cell. It is also found in tears.
The plant cells can be lysed by using ______ enzyme.

Cellulase is the enzyme used for the lysis of plant cells. It catalyzes cellulolysis, which is the breakdown of cellulose. Cellulase acts on the glycosidic linkages of cellulose. Cellulose is mostly found in plant cell walls along with other components.
The fungal cells can be lysed by using ______ enzyme.

The fungal cell wall consists of chitin as the major component. Chitinase is the enzyme used for the breakdown of chitin. This enzyme breaks down the glycosidic bonds present in the chitin. This enzyme is usually produced by higher plants for their protection.
The enzyme which cleaves DNA is DNase. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphodiester linkages of DNA. It is a type of endonuclease. Ligases are the enzymes used in the joining of two strands.
The restriction enzyme needs to be in _____ form to cut the DNA.

The restriction enzyme needs to be in pure form to cut the DNA. The restriction enzymes are molecular scissors that cleave the DNA at specific recognition sites. Restriction enzymes are also known as restriction endonucleases or restrictase.
Which macromolecules are present along with DNA within the cell?

Along with DNA the cell also consists of various macromolecules such as lipids, RNA, polysaccharides. A macromolecule is a large molecule that is formed by polymerization of monomers. A macromolecule consists of more than 100 monomers.

Lipid is a macromolecule made up of fatty acids and glycerol. A fatty acid consists of carboxylic acid along with an aliphatic chain. This chain can be saturated (single bond) or unsaturated (double or triple bonds).

Amino acid is the monomer of proteins. These are organic compounds that join together to form peptides which further join together to form proteins. Two amino acids join together with the help of a peptide bond.
_______ is the building block of carbohydrates.

Carbohydrates are made up of monosaccharides. It is the sugar that cannot be hydrolyzed further. They come together to form a disaccharide which further goes on forming a carbohydrate. They are the major source of energy for living beings.
Ribonuclease is the enzyme responsible for catalyzing the cleavage of RNA. RNA stands for ribonucleic acid. It is also known as RNase. It also cleaves the DNA-RNA hybrids.
The antibiotic resistance gene can be used as ________ marker for selecting transformants.

The antibiotic resistance gene can be used as a selectable marker for selecting transformants. This gene confers the trait for artificial selection and may code for resistance to any antibiotic such as ampicillin, penicillin, kanamycin, tetracycline, etc. The successful transformants will grow on antibiotic-containing media.
The common bacteria used in genetic engineering is _____.

E.coli is the bacteria most commonly used in genetic engineering. It is a model organism. It can be easily and inexpensively cultured within a laboratory. It grows at a faster rate and has a doubling time of approximately 20 minutes.

Recombinant DNA technology is associated with Herbert Boyer since he invented it along with Stanley Cohen. He worked on restriction enzymes found in E.coli. He invented DNA cloning which led to the discovery of several recombinant proteins such as insulin.
If any protein-encoding gene is expressed in a heterologous host, it is called a _______ protein.

A protein encoded by a gene of recombinant DNA is called a recombinant protein. The heterologous host is the host responsible for producing proteins that they are not supposed to produce that is they express the genes which are artificially incorporated within them.
Which culture system is used to obtain cells in the exponential phase?

The continuous culture system is used to obtain the cells in the exponential phase. In continuous culture, the fresh media is added from one side while the used media is simultaneously drained from the other side. This helps to obtain cells in a single phase.
_______ culturing method produces higher biomass and higher yield of the desired product.

The continuous culturing method produces the cells which are in the same phase i.e. exponential phase. Since all cells are in the same phase. This type of culturing method produces higher biomass and yields the maximum desired product.
_______ growth conditions are required to obtain the maximum yield.
Optimum means favorable. These conditions favor the growth of bacteria and maximum growth is seen when the cells are provided with optimum conditions. Maximum growth leads to maximum product yield.
How many stages does a bacterial growth curve have?

A typical bacterial growth curve has four distinct phases, namely log phase, lag/exponential phase, stationary phase, and death/decline phase. Bacteria divide with the help of binary fission. Few other micro-organisms such as algae, protozoa, yeasts also show these same growth phases.
What facilitates the even mixing of ingredients within a bioreactor?

Bioreactor is a device or vessel which helps in carrying out various biological reactions providing them optimum conditions. The stirrer facilitates the even mixing of ingredients like broth, the air in a bioreactor. This stirrer is also known as impellers.

The log (logarithmic) phase of the bacterial growth curve is also known as the exponential phase. It is the second phase of the bacterial growth curve. In this phase the bacteria that have adapted to the new environment doubles. Thus, the maximum growth rate is seen in this phase.
The enzyme which cleaves proteins is a protease. RNase is the enzyme that cleaves the RNA. Lipases are responsible for the breakdown of lipids while DNase catalyzes the breakdown of DNA.
The DNA is wound around histone proteins. They are alkaline in nature which helps in packaging and condensation of DNA. DNA wound around histone forms a complex called a nucleosome.
Which chemical is used to obtain a precipitate of pure DNA?
Ethanol is used to obtain the precipitate of pure DNA. It is used in concentrating and de-salting of nucleic acids. It makes the nucleic acid less hydrophilic thus easing their extraction.
The second trophic level in a lake is:
Zooplankton forms the second trophic level in a lake as they are the primary consumers in food chain that is aquatic, feeding upon phytoplankton. So, they hold the second level.
As energy is passed from one trophic level to another, the amount of usable energy:
energy is not passed from one trophical level to another

The transfer of energy from one trophic level to next trophic level follows 10 percent law known as Lindeman's law of trophic efficiency which states that the efficiency of energy transferred from one trophic level to the next higher trophic level is about 10%. Rest of the energy is lost in respiration. So the energy decreases as it is transferred to subsequent trophic levels.
Which of the following types of lakes is characterised by annual water overturning?

Monomictic lakes is annual water overturning.

Monomictic lakes are holomictic lakes that mix from top to bottom during one mixing period each year. Monomictic lakes may be subdivided into cold and warm types.
The pyramid of number in grassland ecosystem is:

The pyramid of numbers is a diagrammatic representation of the total number of individuals that can be found at each level of a food chain in varying ecosystems. The pyramid of numbers is always erect in the case of a grassland ecosystem because the base of the pyramid in the grassland ecosystem is composed of grass which is followed by primary and secondary consumers. Since the number of primary and secondary consumers goes on decreasing in comparison to grass, the pyramid always stays erect.
Succession on sand dunes is referred to as:

Primary succession can happen when bare sand is colonised by plants. Over time, the sand builds up into sand dunes, raising the ground above the height of sea level. Succession in sand dunes is sometimes called a psammosere.
Which of the following is formed by producers in ecosystem?

In an ecosystem, the rate of production or accumulation of organic matter per unit area per unit time is called productivity. Plants are autotrophic. They perform photosynthesis by using solar energy to synthesize their own food. Hence they are the producers in an ecosystem. The rate at which solar energy is stored by producers is called as primary productivity.
What is the percentage of photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) in the incident solar radiation?

Around 50% of the total radiation from sunlight falls under photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) and supports the process of photosynthesis. It constitutes the light of 400-700 nm wavelength which is absorbed by chlorophyll pigment. Out of which only 2-10% are captured by plants.

Drip tip foliage is found in tropical evergreen forests.

The leaves of forest trees have adapted to cope with exceptionally high rainfall. Many tropical rainforest leaves have a drip tip. It is thought that these drip tips enable raindrops to run off quickly. Plants need to shed water to avoid the growth of fungi and bacteria in the warm, wet tropical rainforest.
In a freshwater ecosystem, the zone of the ecosystem that receives effective light for producers is the:

In a freshwater ecosystem, the zone of the ecosystem that receives effective light for producers is the limnetic zone.

Unlike the profundal zone, the limnetic zone is the layer that receives sufficient sunlight, allowing for photosynthesis. For this reason, it is often simply referred to as the photic zone. The limnetic zone is the most photosynthetically active zone of a lake since it is the primary habitat for planktonic species.
Which of the following occur at the same trophic level?

The step or position in a nutritive series like food chain is referred to as trophic level.

There are different trophic levels in an ecosystem and food chain. The producers (photosynthetic organisms) form the first trophic level and consumers take up the successive trophic levels.

The plants or producers take up the primary trophic level. The animals that consume plant/producers take up the secondary trophic levels like deer, cow, bee, earthworm. Animals feeding on the animals of secondary trophic level are considered tertiary trophic level. Snake, frog, crow.
Which of the following is the submerged aquatic plant that is always found just below the surface of water?

Potamogeton is the submerged aquatic plant that is always found just below the surface of water.

Potamogeton coloratus, the fen pondweed, is an aquatic plant in the genus Potamogeton. It is found in shallow peaty calcareous lakes, ponds and ditches, commonly associated with lowland fens.
Which of the following greeenhouse gases is primarily produced by paddy fields?

Methane greenhouse gases is primarily produced by paddy fields.

Paddy fields account for around 20% of human-related emissions of methane a potent greenhouse gas. Farmers normally flood rice fields throughout the growing season, meaning that methane is produced by microbes underwater as they help to decay any flooded organic matter.
Cycling of elements in an ecosystem is referred to as:

Cycling of elements in an ecosystem is referred to as biogeochemical cycles.

The term biogeochemical cycle is used for exchange or circulation of biogenetic nutrients between living and non living components of biospheres. The biogenetic nutrients are essential elements required by organisms for their body-building and metabolism which are provided by earth and returned to earth after the death of organisms and/or through excreta of animals.
Root nodules appear red due to the presence of:

Root nodules appear red due to the presence of leghaemoglobin.

The nodules appear pink in colour due to the presence of leghemoglobin. This is an iron-containing pigment that is pinkish in color. The pigment is responsible to scavenge oxygen for the functioning of the enzyme nitrogenase in nitrogen fixation.
Radiant energy is not required in the process of:

Radiant energy is not required in the process of fertilization.

Radiant energy is the physical energy resulting from electromagnetic radiation, usually observed as it radiates from a source into the surrounding environment. Radiant energy sources include the entire electromagnetic radiation spectrum, including gamma rays, x-rays, radio frequencies, microwaves, light and heat.
What can be visualized as a functional unit of nature?

An ecosystem consists of biotic and abiotic components that interact within a system. The components are linked together with various nutrient cycles and energy flows. Thus it can be visualized as a functional unit of nature.
What are the two basic categories of an ecosystem?

The terrestrial and aquatic are two basic categories of an ecosystem. Deserts, forests, and grasslands are included in the terrestrial ecosystems; while, ponds, lakes, rivers, wetlands, and estuary are included in the aquatic ecosystems.
What is the characteristic of each type of ecosystem?

The characteristic of each type of ecosystem is the interaction between biotic and abiotic factors. The components are linked together with various nutrient cycles and energy flows. Thus it can be visualized as a functional unit of nature.
What is the horizontal distribution of different species occupying different levels?

The horizontal distribution of different species occupying different levels is called zonation. It is a spatial pattern occurring horizontally along the ground. The zones are according to parameters such as altitude or depth.
What is the spatial pattern that occurs vertically called?

The spatial pattern that occurs vertically is called stratification. It is the vertical distribution of species determined by the height of the organisms. For example, trees, herbs, shrubs, and grasses occupy the top, middle, and bottom strata respectively.
In which of the following aspects do the components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit?

The components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit when the aspect is productivity. Productivity is the amount of generation organic matter i.e. biomass in a unit of time in that ecosystem.
In which of the following aspects do the components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit?

The components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit when the aspect is decomposition. It is a part of the nutrient cycle in which organic substances are broken down into simpler organic matter.
In which of the following aspects do the components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit?

The components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit when the aspect is energy flow. It is the calorific amount of energy that moves from the sun and up to each subsequent level of the food chain in an environment.
In which of the following aspects do the components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit?

The components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit when the aspect is nutrient cycling. It is the flux and exchange of nutrients (organic and inorganic matter) back into the production of living matter.
Which of the following is an abiotic component of a pond?
Water is an abiotic component of a pond ecosystem. Water is essential for the growth and transfer of gases, and nutrients within the organisms. The pond is an example of a freshwater ecosystem.
Which of the following climatic conditions regulate the functioning of a pond?

Various climatic conditions such as temperature, sunlight, and day length regulate the rate of the functioning of a pond. The pond ecosystem performs all the functions of any ecosystem i.e., conversion of inorganic into organic material with the help of energy.
Which of the following is an autotrophic component of a pond?

The submerged, floating, and marginal plants found at the edges are autotrophic components of a pond. These are the organisms (producers) that can produce their own food using light, water, carbon dioxide, or other chemicals.
Which of the following is an autotrophic component of a pond?
The phytoplanktons are the autotrophic component of a pond. These are microscopic algae and primary producers that provide food for creatures including zooplankton, fishes, snails, shrimps, etc.
Which of the following is the consumer of a pond ecosystem?
The zooplankton is the consumer of a pond ecosystem. It is a microscopic, heterotrophic organism that feeds on phytoplankton. It is found in the free-swimming and bottom-dwelling forms.
Which of the following is the decomposer of a pond ecosystem?

The fungi are decomposers of a pond ecosystem. Fungi are heterotrophic, unicellular eukaryotes that lack chloroplasts. They decompose the dead and decaying matter and provide essential nutrients to the producers.
What is characterized as a rivalry between members of two different species for the use of the same resources in the same territory?

Interspecific competition is the struggle between members of different species over access to resources in a given region. An illustration is when tigers and lions that coexist in the same region fight over the same prey.
In what situations does indirect competition arise during exploitation?
Single organism interferes with the survival and procreation of others.
Two species feed on the same prey.
Two species compete with one another for resources and space.
Organisms fight with one another for resources like food, prey, or space in an indirect manner known as exploitation competition. As a result, resources become less and less readily available.
Which two species exhibit indirect seeming competition?
Battle it out for resources and mates
Share the same resources in the area
The seeming rivalry arises between two species who compete for the same prey in an indirect manner. In this, one common predator may use both species as prey. It is an unfavorable indirect contact.
Mutualism is a type of interspecific interaction where both the interacting species are benefited.
Who makes cellulase in the ungulates intestines?

The cellulase is produced by many bacterial species in the gut of ungulates. The gut bacteria aid in the breakdown of cellulose since many of them are herbivores. Anaerobic bacteria make up the majority of gut microorganisms.
A mycorrhiza exhibits what kind of interaction?

A mutualistic relationship between fungi and plants is known as mycorrhiza. Mycorrhiza is necessary for the uptake of minerals (nitrogen, phosphorous, etc.) from the soil by about 80–90% of plants, while fungi depend on plants for vital elements like sugars for optimum development.
How does the body make up for the limited oxygen availability in altitude sickness?
Increasing the production of red blood cells

The body increases the creation of red blood cells, which will enhance the intake of oxygen, to make up for the low oxygen availability seen during altitude sickness. Over 3500 m, or 8,000 feet, a person becomes ill from altitude sickness.
What is the name of the characteristic of the creature that allows it to live and reproduce in its habitat?

An organism’s ability to survive and reproduce in its environment is referred to as adaptation. It goes through an evolutionary process from generation to generation. It involves a quality, trait, or characteristic that benefits an organism in a certain environment.
What is the name of the organism whose body temperature and the osmotic concentration of its body fluid, respectively, alter with ambient temperature and with the ambient water osmotic concentration?

Poikilotherms, or conformers, are organisms whose body temperature varies with the outside temperature. In aquatic species, this osmotic concentration of bodily fluid also varies with the osmotic concentration of the surrounding water. Examples include fish, lizards, insects, and more.
Which of the following species has a variety of thick-walled spores that enable them to tolerate unfavorable circumstances and germinate when a suitable environment is present?

Fungi create a variety of thick-walled spores that assist them in withstanding unfavorable circumstances and germinate when a suitable environment is present. Algae, lesser plants, and bacteria can also create these kinds of spores.
Under unfavorable circumstances which state do snails enter?

In the summer, several fish and snails experience aestivation. It is extended dormancy, and another name for it is “summer sleep.” In mostly cold-blooded creatures like earthworms, bees, tortoises, crocodiles, etc., it aids in regulating body temperature and prevents water loss.
What state allows seeds to penetrate under unfavorable circumstances?
When circumstances are unfavorable, seeds go into dormancy. Plants have an adaptive system that keeps seeds from sprouting. When the circumstances are right, it aids in delayed germination.
Which of the following organisms does not undergo yearly migration?

The movement of organisms from one geographic place to another is called migration. It could be merely passing or ongoing. Each year, there is an annual migration. Of the possibilities listed above, salamanders do not exhibit a yearly migration.
What is the definition of population density?
The number of animals and plants in a specific area
The number of people in a specific region in a specific amount of time
The number of animals and plants in a specific location

The population density provides information on the total number of people residing in a certain region at any given moment. It is a word used in geography. Overpopulation is a term used to describe nations with excessive population density.
A population that exhibits birth rates that are identical to the death rate implies:

In the Plateau phase, the birth rate remains stationary so the natality rate is equal to the mortality rate. No more population growth, population size is constant. In this phase, the net change in the population becomes zero.
Exponential growth phase in human population started about:

The global population growth was very slow until the 1750. There was a long period of stationary growth phase, with the world's population about 300 million. But after 1750, the world's population grew significantly.
Antifreeze proteins or AFPs enable organisms that possess them to:

Antifreeze proteins (AFPs) are biological antifreeze molecules that were first discovered in polar fish. AFPs can attach to ice and hence prevent ice crystal development. Because of AFPs, fish may live in ice-covered or cold waters below the freezing point (0.7 °C) of their blood serum.
A group of individuals from different species living in the same habitat and exhibiting functional interactions is called:

A biotic community, also known as a biota or 'biocoenosis,' is a group of organisms that share an environment or habitat and interact with one another. An ecosystem is made up of the biotic community and the physical landscape, or abiotic factors.
Animals adapted to live in the tundra
Animals adapted to live in the deep sea

A xerocole, sometimes known as a desert animal, is an animal that has evolved to live in the desert. They must overcome two major obstacles: a scarcity of water and extreme heat. They save water by avoiding evaporation and concentrating excretions.

Animals that dwell underground and dig tunnels and burrows are known as fossorial and subfossorial. Some of them are fully below, while others surface for a few hours during the day. The basal rate of the average fossorial animal is between 60% and 90%.
_________ is the unrestricted growth of populations, which will result in the maximum growth of that population.

The unrestrained growth of populations that results in the population's maximum growth is referred to as biotic potential. The biotic potential is defined as a species' maximum conceivable vital index, or when the species has the highest birth rate and lowest mortality rate.
Crassulacean acid metabolism in plants helps to __________.

Crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM) is a photosynthetic adaptation to intermittent water supplies found in arid-zone plants (such as cacti) and tropical epiphytes (e.g., orchids and bromeliads). During the day, CAM plants cover their stomata and absorb CO2 at night, when the air temperature is cooler.

Xerophytes are plants that grow in areas with very little water and moisture. They are mostly found in arid and semi-desert environments. These plants have changed their physical structures to adapt to their environments, such as thickened cuticles, sunken stomata, and lengthy roots that reach deep into the soil.
Mimicry, in biology, phenomenon characterized by the superficial resemblance of two or more organisms that are not closely related taxonomically.
In which of the following phases, the maximum growth rate occurs?

The log phase (also known as the logarithmic or exponential phase) is a period in which cells double in size. If growth is unrestricted, doubling will occur at a constant pace, resulting in a doubling of both the number of cells and the rate of population expansion with each passing period.
In which one of the following habitats, does the diurnal temperature of soil surface view most?

Days in the desert are extremely hot, and nights are extremely cold. Desert soil is far more vulnerable to these variations than soil in other regions due to sparse plant cover. The earth becomes hot throughout the day and cools down often at night. As a result, this choice is right because the temperature varies the greatest here.
Animals undergo inactive stages during winters. It is called:

Hibernation is a strategy for animals to store energy in order to survive harsh weather or a shortage of food. Physiological changes such as a reduction in body temperature and a reduced metabolism are involved. People may benefit from medical research into the processes involved in hibernation.
Two different parasites on the same food

The partial or complete sharing of resources or other ecological characteristics (predators, foraging area, soil type, and so on) by two or more species is referred to as niche overlap. In community ecology, niche overlap is a crucial issue since it is thought to govern how many and which species may coexist in a community.
An example of a terrestrial gastropod is:
A garden snail is a shelled gastropod. The name is most often applied to land snails, terrestrial pulmonate gastropod molluscs.
Select the type of biotic interactions with example, in which one of the interacting species is benefited while other remains unaffected.

In commensalism one of the interacting species is benefitted while other remains unaffected. In mutualism both the interacting species are benefitted, amensalism one of the interacting species is harmed while other remains unaffected. parasitism one of the interacting species is benefitted whereas other is harmed.
In genetic engineering experiments, restriction enzymes are used for:

Restriction enzymes, also called restriction endonucleases, bind to DNA and cleave the double strand, forming smaller pieces of DNA. There are three types of restriction enzymes; Type I restriction enzymes recognize a DNA sequence and cut the strand randomly more than one thousand base pairs away from the site. Type II restriction enzymes, the most useful for molecular biology laboratories, recognize and cut the DNA strand predictably at a specific sequence which is usually less than ten base pairs long. Type III restriction enzymes are similar to Type I, but these cut the DNA about thirty base pairs from the recognition sequence.
DNA moves towards ______ during agarose gel electrophoresis.

During agarose gel electrophoresis the DNA moves towards the anode. Since DNA is negatively charged it moves toward the positively charged terminal. An anode is a positive terminal while the cathode is the negative terminal.
Which enzyme helps in joining of DNA?

Ligases are the enzyme that helps in the joining of two strands of DNA. Lyase is responsible for the breakdown of molecules. Helicase helps in the unwinding of DNA. Lipases are enzymes that breakdown lipids.
Who among the following was awarded the Nobel Prize for the development of PCR technique?

Kary Mullis was awarded the Nobel Prize for the development of PCR technique in 1985. Herbert Boyer invented recombinant DNA technology. Arthur Kornberg won Nobel prize for his discovery of the mechanism in the biological synthesis of DNA. Hargovind Khorana constructed first synthetic gene.
Which of the following has popularised the PCR (polymerase chain reactions)?

In the PCR, the process of replication of DNA is repeated many times, the segment of DNA can be replicated to approximately 1 billion copies and this is achieved by the use of thermostable DNA polymerase which is isolated mainly from thermostable bacteria like Thermus aquaticus. The availability of this thermostable DNA polymerase popularised the PCR.
PCR stands for Polymerase chain reaction. It is a technique used for DNA amplification. It was developed by Kary Mullis and is a useful technique in genetic engineering.
Which one of the following is related with genetic engineering?

The plasmid is an extrachromosomal genetic element used in genetic engineering that occurs in many bacterial strains. Plasmids are circular deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) molecules that replicate independently of the bacterial chromosome.
Hind II was the first restriction enzyme to be isolated. This enzyme was first isolated from Haemophilus influenzae Rd strain II.
The transfer of genetic material from one bacterium to another through the mediation of a vector like virus is termed as:
Transduction is the process by which genetic material (DNA) is transferred from one bacterium to another through the mediation of a vector, like virus.
Which of the given statement is correct in the context of observing DNA separated by agarose gel electrophoresis?
DNA can be seen in visible light.
DNA can be seen without staining in visible light.
Ethidium bromide stained DNA can be seen in visible light.
Ethidium bromide stained DNA can be seen under exposure to UV light.

DNA cannot be seen in visible light, so options a and b are incorrect. Staining by ethidium bromide and presence of UV light are necessary to see DNA. So, the correct answer is 'Ethidium bromide stained DNA can be seen under exposure to UV light.'
In agarose gel electrophoresis, DNA molecules are separated on the basis of their:

In agarose gel electrophoresis, the DNA fragments separate out (resolve) according to their size or length because of the sieving property of agarose gel. It means the smaller the fragment size, the farther it will move.
A recombinant DNA molecule can be produced in the absence of the following:

Hosts are the organisms in which the genes of other organisms are expressed. Hosts are used once the rDNA is created. Hence Escherichia coli is not necessary for making recombinant DNA molecules as it is not the only host that is necessary for gene cloning. For example, Escherichia coli acts as a host and produces the human protein insulin.
The DNA fragments produced by the use of restriction endonucleases can be separated by:

Gel electrophoresis is a method for separation and analysis of macromolecules (DNA, RNA and proteins) and their fragments, based on their size and charge. It is used in molecular biology to separate a mixed population of DNA and RNA fragments by length, to estimate the size of DNA and RNA fragments or to separate proteins by charge.
Cleaving of phosphodiester bond in DNA by the enzyme.
Cutting of DNA at specific position only.
Prevention of the multiplication of bacteriophage in bacteria.

Restriction enzyme: They restrict the propagation of foreign DNA in the bacterium. Hence the word ‘restriction’ in restriction enzyme refers to prevention of the multiplication of bacteriophages in bacteria.
Constructing recombinant DNA by joining with vectors.

Biolistic gun or gene gun method initially developed to transfer the gene in plant cell directly. It is a method involving the transfer of genes to the plants without the use of any vectors (plasmid etc.).
An antibiotic resistance gene in a vector usually helps in the selection of:

Selectable markers help in identifying and eliminating non-transformants and selectively permitting the growth of the transformants. Normally, the genes encoding resistance to antibiotics such as ampicillin, chloramphenicol, tetracycline or kanamycin, etc. are considered useful selectable markers. So, an antibiotic resistance gene in a vector usually helps in the selection of transformed cells.
The role of DNA ligase in the construction of a recombinant DNA molecule is:
Formation of phosphodiester bond between two DNA fragments.
Formation of hydrogen bonds between sticky ends of DNA fragments.
Ligation of all purime and pyrimidine bases.

Purified DNA ligase is used in gene cloning to join DNA molecules together to construct recombinant DNA. DNA ligase is an enzyme, that facilitates the joining of DNA strands together by catalyzing the formation of a phosphodiester bond. Ligases can join any DNA fragments with 'blunt' ends. They can also join DNA fragments with 'sticky' ends, but only if the nucleotides on the strands are complementary.
The three steps involved in PCR are ________

Denaturation, annealing, and extension are three steps involved in PCR. In denaturation, the DNA is denatured. The primers are added in annealing and in extension, the primers extend giving rise to new DNA strands.
Which of the following should be chosen for best yield if one were to produce a recombinant protein in large amounts?
A stirred-tank bioreactor without in-lets and out-lets.

After having cloned the gene of interest and having optimised the conditions to induce the expression of the target protein one has to consider producing it on a large scale. Small volume cultures cannot yield appreciable quantities of products.

To produce in large quantities the development of bioreactors, where large volume (100-1000 litres) of culture (continuous) can be processed, was required.
Extra DNA, associated with the genome, but cannot replicate.

Plasmids are the extrachromosomal DNA is bacterial cell because they are not linked with the main chromosomal DNA. They are double-stranded and circular in structure. They have their own origin of replication which is a segment on DNA that begins the replication. So, they are self-replicating DNA molecules. They are capable of making their own copies. Due to this property plasmids have been used as vectors in biotechnological processes.
Taq polymerase is a type of DNA polymerase obtained from the bacteria Thermus aquaticus. It is a thermophilic bacteria and its polymerase remains active at high temperatures (>80°C).
A technique used in making copies of a specific segment of DNA involves:
A technique used in making copies of a specific segment of DNA involves polymerase chain reaction.
Which of the following statements does not hold true for restriction enzyme?
It produces the same kind of sticky ends in different DNA molecules.

Restriction enzyme:

  • Recognises a palindromic nucleotide sequence.
  • Is an endonuclease isolated from bacteria.
  • Produces the same kind of sticky ends in different DNA molecules.
The scientists who were succeded in isolating antibiotic resistant gene from a plasmid for the first time:
Stanley Cohen and Herbert Boyer isolated an antibiotic resistance gene by cutting out a piece of DNA from a plasmid which was responsible for conferring antibiotic resistance, in the year 1972.
The site in the vector which helps in identifying and eliminating non transformants:

Selectable marker: It helps in identifying and eliminating non-transformants and selectively permitting the growth of the transformants. e.g. Ampicillin, kanamycin are considered as useful selectable markers for E.coli.
Which of the following bacteria is not a source of restriction endonuclease?
Entamoeba coli is not a bacterium and Haemophilus influenzae, Escherichia coli and Bacillius quifacieus are source of restriction endonuclease.
Which of the following steps are catalysed by Taq polymerase in a PCR reaction?
Extension of primer end on the template DNA.

PCR is the short form for polymerase chain reaction which is the phenomenon which is used for amplification of the part-specific region of DNA as per our interest. Taq polymerase is the enzyme that attaches nucleotides together and help is the extension of primer end on the template DNA.
Significance of 'heat shock' method in bacterial transformation is to facilitate:
Binding of DNA to the cell wall.
Uptake of DNA through membrane transport proteins.
Uptake of DNA through transient pores in the bacterial cell wall.

Heat shock method in presence of a bivalent cation like Ca+2 creates transient pores in the cell wall allowing the uptake of foreign DNA present in the medium. So, the correct answer is 'Uptake of DNA through transient pores in the bacterial cell membrane'
While isolating DNA from bacteria, which of the following enzymes is not used?

While isolating DNA from bacteria, Deoxyribonuclease enzymes is not used.

Lysozyme is used for breaking the membranes which surround DNAs. Ribonuclease is used for removing RNA. Protease is used for removing protein. All these steps are necessary for isolation of DNA from bacteria.
The DNA polymerase enzyme used in PCR is obtained from:
Taq polymerase is a thermostable DNA polymerase I obtained from the thermophilic bacterium Thermus aquaticus. It is used in PCR.
The building block of nucleic acid is:

Nucleotides, the building blocks of nucleic acids, consist of a nitrogenous base (adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine in DNA, or uracil in RNA), a pentose sugar (deoxyribose or ribose), and a phosphate group. They polymerize via phosphodiester bonds to form the backbone of DNA and RNA, encoding genetic information through the sequence of bases. This versatility facilitates crucial cellular processes such as replication, transcription, and translation.
Each strand of DNA has a typical structure. Which of the following statements correctly explains its structure?
The sugar-phosphate chain on the outside and the bases on the inside are held together by weak hydrogen bonds.
The sugar-phosphate chain on the inside and the bases on the outside are held together by weak hydrogen bonds.
The sugar-phosphate chain on the outside and the bases on the inside are held together by strong hydrogen bonds.
The sugar-phosphate chain on the inside and the bases on the outside are held together by strong hydrogen bonds.

In DNA, the sugar-phosphate backbone forms the outer structure of the double helix, with nitrogenous bases positioned internally. Base pairing via hydrogen bonds (A with T and C with G) results in the ladder-like structure of the helix, where bases stack internally and the sugar-phosphate backbone comprises the sides. This arrangement gives DNA its characteristic double helical shape.
Which of the following base pairs in DNA are correct?

Guanine-Cytosine represents a correct base pair in DNA. In DNA, the base pairing occurs between adenine (A) and thymine (T), forming two hydrogen bonds, and between guanine (G) and cytosine (C), forming three hydrogen bonds. This complementary base pairing ensures the stability and fidelity of the DNA molecule.
In the Griffith experiment, which of the following resulted in the death of the mice?
Live S strain bacteria → Inject into mice
Live R strain bacteria → Inject into mice
Heat-killed S strain bacteria → Inject into mice
Heat-killed R strain bacteria → Inject into mice

Griffith performed the transformation experiment in mice using the R and S strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae. S strain is generally pathogenic and R strain is non-pathogenic. However, the heat-killed S strain cannot cause the disease. So when R strain and heat-killed S strain bacteria were injected separately, the mice stayed alive. But when injected together, the mice died. This was because, R strain bacteria got “transformed” into S strains, and caused the disease. Heat-killed R strain does not affect the mice and the mice live.
In which of the following processes does copying of genetic information from one strand of DNA into RNA take place?

Transcription involves RNA polymerase binding to DNA at the promoter, unwinding the double helix, and synthesizing mRNA. This process copies genetic information from DNA into mRNA, facilitating gene expression. It's a crucial step in genetic information flow within cells.
Which of the following is/are the characteristic(s) of genes?

Genes are segments of DNA that serve as the basic units of heredity. They possess several key characteristics:

Replication and transmission to progeny, ensuring the inheritance of genetic information from one generation to the next. 

Mutability, as genes can undergo changes or mutations over time, contributing to genetic diversity and evolution. 

Storage of hereditary information, as genes encode the instructions necessary for the development, functioning, and regulation of organisms. 

So, all options accurately describes the characteristics of genes, encompassing their roles in replication, transmission, mutability, and storage of hereditary information.
Which of the following does not define the transcription unit in a DNA?
The transcription unit consists of promoter structural gene and terminator. The inducer (lactose/ allolactose) is not a component of the transcription unit.

VNTR are useful in DNA profiling because they:

I. Are hypervariable

II. Are inherited

III. Synthesize constitutive enzymes

Choose the correct option given below?

VNTRs (Variable Number Tandem Repeats) are regions of DNA where short sequences of nucleotides are repeated in tandem. They are useful in DNA profiling for forensic and genetic identification purposes because:

They are hypervariable: VNTRs exhibit high variability in the number of repeats among individuals, making them useful for distinguishing between different individuals based on their unique VNTR patterns.

They are inherited: VNTR alleles are passed down from parents to offspring, allowing for the establishment of familial relationships and genetic relatedness based on shared VNTR profiles.
In a genetic code, some codons do not code for amino acids that function as stop codons. Which of the following does not belong to this group?

In the genetic code, UAG, UAA, and UGA are stop codons, also known as termination codons or nonsense codons. These codons signal the termination of translation, leading to the release of the polypeptide chain from the ribosome. In contrast, UUU (uracil-uracil-uracil) is the codon for the amino acid phenylalanine. Therefore, UUU does not belong to the group of stop codons.
Which of the following codes has a dual function?

The codon AUG has a dual function. It codes for amino acid methionine and it also acts as initiator codon. AUG codes for the amino acid methionine, and so all protein translation begins with methionine. Methionine is specified by the codon AUG, which is also known as the start codon. Consequently, methionine is the first amino acid to dock in the ribosome during the synthesis of proteins.
In point mutation, how many base pairs are inserted or deleted?

In point mutation, a single nucleotide base pair is either substituted, inserted, or deleted from the DNA sequence. This alteration can lead to changes in the corresponding mRNA codon during transcription, potentially resulting in changes to the amino acid sequence of the encoded protein. Therefore, point mutations typically involve the alteration of only one base pair.

The enzyme polynucleotide phosphorylase randomly assembles nucleotides into a polynucleotide phosphorylase to a solution of adenosine triphosphate and guanosine triphosphate, how many types artificial mRNA 3 nucleotide codons would be possible?

The enzyme polynucleotide phosphorylase functions in \(3^{\prime}\) to \(5^{\prime}\) exoribonuclease activity and oligonucleotide polymerization. It synthesizes mRNA by adding nucleotides at the \(3^{\prime}\) end. With only adenosine and guanosine available, the possible combinations generate 8 different codon types.
During autocatalysis of DNA, which one of the following provide free OH group and is also used to anchor for addition of new DNA nucleotides?

During DNA replication, an RNA primer synthesized by primase provides a free 3' OH group. This OH group serves as the starting point for DNA nucleotide addition by DNA polymerase. Additionally, the RNA primer acts as an anchor for DNA polymerase during synthesis initiation.
Which one of the incorrect statement regarding DNA polymerase III?
It is used to ligate any DNA fragment

DNA polymerase III is primarily involved in DNA synthesis during DNA replication and does not have a role in ligating DNA fragments. This function is carried out by DNA ligase.

DNA polymerase III cannot directly bind to the oric site. The oric site is recognized by initiator proteins, which then recruit DNA polymerase III and other replication machinery components to initiate DNA replication.

DNA polymerase III is not isolated from a virus. It is a bacterial enzyme and is one of the main DNA polymerases involved in bacterial DNA replication.

Therefore, all of the statements are incorrect regarding DNA polymerase III.

Direction: Match the following:

1.

Splicing

a.

Addition of methyl guanosine triphosphate at 5'–end

2.

Capping

b.

Addition of adenylate residues at 3'–end

3.

Tailing

c.

Removal of non-coding introns

The correct match is : 1 - c, 2 - a, 3 - b.

Splicing is the process of removing non-coding introns from pre-mRNA transcripts, leaving behind only the coding exons to form mature mRNA.

Capping involves the addition of a modified guanosine nucleotide, known as a 5' cap, to the 5' end of the mRNA molecule. This modification helps stabilize the mRNA and is crucial for mRNA stability and translation initiation.

Tailing, also known as polyadenylation, involves the addition of a string of adenylate residues (poly-A tail) to the 3' end of the mRNA molecule. This modification protects the mRNA from degradation and plays a role in mRNA export, translation, and stability.
The tendency of offspring to differ from parents is called:

The tendency of offspring to differ from parents is called variation. It is the degree by which progeny or offspring differ from their parents. These variations could either be genotypic variations (difference in genetic makeup) or phenotypic variations (different traits). The difference that exists between progeny and parents is known as variation.
The physical expression or appearance of a character is called as:

The physical appearance of a character is called as phenotype. It is defined as the physical expression of a trait or character of an individual. The phenotype is determined by both their genomic makeup( genotype) and environmental factors. Example: The tallness of a pea plant is a physical expression of an individual.
The alternate forms of a gene is called:

The alternate forms of a gene are called alleles. An allele is a variant form of a gene. Some genes have a variety of different forms, which are located at the same position, or genetic locus, on a chromosome. Humans are called diploid organisms because they have two alleles at each genetic locus, with one allele inherited from each parent.
Which of the following is not a correct statement with respect to DNA?

DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is not a basic substance. It is a complex molecule composed of nucleotides, which are made up of a phosphate group, a sugar molecule (deoxyribose), and one of four nitrogenous bases (adenine, guanine, cytosine, or thymine). DNA is the hereditary material found in almost all living organisms and plays a fundamental role in genetic inheritance and protein synthesis. It was first identified by Friedrich Miescher in 1869.
The phenomenon known as wobble refers to:
The movement of multiple ribosomes along the same mRNA
The shifting of the reading frame in a deletion or insertion mutation
The ability of a tRNA to pair with different codons that may differ in the third base
The movement of a tRNA from the A to the P site

The wobble hypothesis describes how a tRNA molecule can recognize multiple codons that may vary in the third base. This flexibility allows for the pairing of non-standard base pairs at the third position of the codon-anticodon duplex. Despite these variations, the same amino acid is incorporated into the growing polypeptide chain, ensuring accurate protein synthesis.
Which one of the following is correct regarding mature mRNA in eukaryotes?
Exons and introns do not appear in the mature RNA.
Exons appear but introns do not appear in the mature RNA.
Introns appear but exons do not appear in the mature RNA.
Both exons and introns appear in the mature RNA.

In eukaryotes, the primary transcript (pre-mRNA) undergoes RNA processing, including splicing, to produce mature mRNA. During splicing, introns (non-coding sequences) are removed from the pre-mRNA, and the remaining coding sequences, known as exons, are joined together to form the mature mRNA. Therefore, in mature mRNA, exons are present, while introns are absent. This processing ensures that only the coding regions of the gene are translated into proteins.
The last human chromosome that was completely sequenced is:

Chromosome 1, the largest human chromosome, was the final one to be fully sequenced in May 2006. It contains vital genetic information encoded in its nucleotide base pairs and is associated with various diseases like hearing loss, glaucoma, breast cancer, and Alzheimer's disease. The sequence of Chromosome 1 also reveals evolutionary signals within specific genes contributing to human fitness.
In double helix model of DNA, how far is each base pair from the next base pair?

In the double helix model of DNA, the distance between adjacent base pairs (the distance along the helix axis from one base pair to the next) is approximately 0.34 nm. This distance represents the spacing between the nitrogenous bases within the DNA molecule.
Which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to pyrimidines?

Pyrimidines are not 7 membered rings. Pyrimidines are a type of nitrogenous bases which are heterocyclic compounds with a 6 membered single-ring structure. Nitrogen is present at 1 and 3 positions of the rings. Examples of pyrimidines include thymine, uracil, and cytosine.
By which of the following bonds, a nitrogenous base is linked to the pentose sugar?

In DNA and RNA molecules, nitrogenous bases like adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine, and uracil are connected to the pentose sugar (deoxyribose in DNA, ribose in RNA) through N-glycosidic bonds. These bonds form between the nitrogen atom of the base and the C1' carbon of the sugar during nucleotide synthesis, essential for constructing nucleotide monomers within nucleic acid polymers.
The deoxyribose and ribose belong to a class of sugars, that is called:
Both deoxyribose and ribose belongs to a class of sugars called Pentoses. Pentose sugar contains five carbon sugar molecule.
The location of promoter site and the terminator site for transcription is:
3 (downstream) end and 5 (upstream) end, respectively of the transcription unit
5 (upstream) end and 3 (downstream) end, respectively of the transcription unit

In transcription, which is the process of synthesizing RNA from a DNA template, the promoter sequence is located upstream (towards the 5' end) of the transcription start site. The promoter sequence contains specific sequences recognized by RNA polymerase, which initiates transcription.

Similarly, the terminator sequence is located downstream (towards the 3' end) of the transcription end site. The terminator sequence signals the end of transcription and causes RNA polymerase to dissociate from the DNA template.

Overall, transcription proceeds in the 5' to 3' direction along the DNA template, and the promoter and terminator sequences are essential elements that regulate the initiation and termination of transcription, respectively.
Through which among the following linkages are the two nucleotides connected through the 3’-5’ end?

The phosphodiester linkage connects the 3' carbon of one nucleotide's sugar to the 5' carbon of the adjacent nucleotide's sugar. This linkage forms the backbone of the DNA or RNA molecule, providing stability and allowing for the linear arrangement of nucleotides in the polymer.
The chemical name for thymine is known as:

Thymine is chemically known as 5-methyl uracil. It is one of the four nucleobases found in DNA, pairing with adenine via two hydrogen bonds. Thymine is essential for the accurate replication and transmission of genetic information.
Which among the following is the exact ratio of guanine to cytosine in a DNA double helical structure?

In a DNA double helix, guanine (G) always pairs with cytosine (C) through three hydrogen bonds, forming a stable base pair. This complementary pairing results in an equal ratio of guanine to cytosine in the DNA molecule, hence the ratio of 1:1. This equal proportion of G-C base pairs contributes to the overall stability and structural integrity of the DNA molecule.
As per 'Panspermia', life reached Earth in the form of:

The cosmozoic theory is also called the theory of panspermia. According to this theory, life has reached this planet Earth from other heavenly bodies such as meteorites, in the form of highly resistant spores of some organisms. This idea was proposed by Richter in 1865 and supported by Arrhenius (1908) and other contemporary scientists.
Pasteur's experiments and similar ones that followed convinced most people that spontaneous generation of life did not happen because:
Pasteur used very fine mesh screens to cover his flasks.
Pasteur did not boil his flasks for a long time.
Pasteur's swan-necked flasks ruled out the objection that spoiled air could have contaminated his experiments.

Pasteur's experiments demonstrated that when nutrient broths were placed in flasks with swan-necked curves, preventing microorganisms from entering while allowing air exchange, no microbial growth occurred despite prolonged exposure to air. This disproved the notion of spontaneous generation by showing that microorganisms were not spontaneously generated in the broth, but rather came from pre-existing microorganisms in the air. Thus, Pasteur's meticulous experimental design and use of swan-necked flasks provided compelling evidence against spontaneous generation.
From his experiments, S. L. Miller produced amino acids by mixing the following in a closed flask:
CH3, H2, NH4, and water vapor at 800∘C
CH4, H2, NH3, and water vapor at 600∘C
CH3, H2, NH3, and water vapor at 600∘C
CH4, H2, NH3, and water vapor at 800∘C

S.L. Miller conducted an experiment to prove the theory of chemical origin. In their experiment, the conditions of primitive earth were created in the laboratory. The electric discharge was stimulated into a closed flask containing CH4, H2, NH3 and water vapour at 800ºC. This proved that life originates from non-living components.

The first mammals are believed to have appeared during the Mesozoic Era, specifically in the Triassic period, which lasted from approximately 252 million years ago. These early mammals evolved from synapsids, a group of reptiles, and gradually diversified over time. The Triassic period marked a significant transition in Earth's history, witnessing the emergence of various new forms of life, including the ancestors of modern mammals.
Which of the following cannot be explained by Lamarckism?
Degeneration of visual apparatus in cave dwellers

Dull progeny of Nobel laureate cannot be explained by Lamarckism.

Lamarckism proposes that acquired traits during an organism's lifetime can be passed on to its offspring. However, intellectual capabilities, such as intelligence or dullness, are not considered acquired traits in Lamarckian theory and cannot be inherited. The absence of limbs in snakes, long necks of giraffes, and degeneration of visual apparatus in cave dwellers could be explained by Lamarckism through the concept of use and disuse of organs leading to evolutionary changes over generations.
Which of the following were probably the first mammals on the Earth?

Shrew-like animals, also known as basal mammals, are believed to be among the earliest mammals on Earth. These small, insectivorous mammals appeared during the Mesozoic Era, specifically in the late Triassic or early Jurassic period, around 200 million years ago. They were likely small, mouse-sized creatures with primitive mammalian characteristics. Dinosaur-like animals are not mammals but rather reptiles, and platypus-like animals belong to the monotremes, a group of egg-laying mammals, which evolved later. Rabbit-like animals would have appeared much later in mammalian evolution.
The two key concepts branching descent and natural selection belong to which theory of evolution?

Branching descent and natural selection are fundamental concepts in Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, commonly referred to as Darwinian evolution. Darwin proposed that all species are descended from a common ancestor through a process of branching descent, with modifications occurring over successive generations due to natural selection. This theory revolutionized our understanding of the diversity of life on Earth and continues to serve as the foundation for modern evolutionary biology.
Hardy-Weinberg principle states that allele frequencies get change when evolutionary forces act on a population. Which of the following is not an evolutionary force?

Random mating is not considered an evolutionary force because it does not directly alter allele frequencies within a population. Instead, it is one of the assumptions of the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, which states that mating occurs randomly with respect to genotype frequencies. Mutations , gene flow, and genetic drift are all evolutionary forces that can lead to changes in allele frequencies within populations over time.
Which one of the following options gives one correct example of convergent evolution and divergent evolution respectively?
Eyes of octopus and mammals, Bones of forelimbs of vertebrates
Thorns of Bougainvillea and tendrils of Cucurbita, Wings of butterfly and birds
Bones of forelimbs of vertebrates, Wings of butterfly and birds
Thorns of Bougainvillea and tendrils of Cucurbita, Eyes of octopus and mammals

Convergent evolution occurs when unrelated organisms independently evolve similar traits or characteristics due to similar environmental pressures or ecological niches. In this case, the development of complex eyes in both octopuses and mammals is an example of convergent evolution. Despite octopuses being invertebrates and mammals being vertebrates, both have evolved sophisticated eyes with similar structures to optimize visual perception in their respective habitats.

On the other hand, divergent evolution refers to the process where closely related species evolve different traits or characteristics due to adapting to different environments or ecological niches. The comparison of the bones of forelimbs in vertebrates exemplifies divergent evolution. Despite sharing a common ancestor, vertebrates have diversified to occupy various ecological niches, leading to differences in the structure and function of their forelimbs.
After industrialization in 1920, there were more dark-colored moths in England because:
Soot from industries changed the color of white moths.
White colored moths immigrated to other areas due to pollution.
White colored moths died due to toxic pollutants from industries.

After industrialization in the 1920s, England experienced widespread air pollution from industries, resulting in the deposition of soot and other pollutants on surfaces, including trees where moths rested. The light-colored peppered moth, which was prevalent before industrialization, became more visible to predators against the darkened tree bark. Consequently, darker moths, which were less conspicuous against the darkened backgrounds, gained a survival advantage over the lighter moths. This phenomenon, known as industrial melanism, led to an increase in the population of dark-colored moths, as they were better camouflaged and less likely to be preyed upon.
Change in the frequency of alleles in a population results in evolution as proposed by:

The Hardy-Weinberg principle states that allele frequencies in a population will remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of evolutionary forces such as mutations, gene flow, genetic drift, and natural selection. However, any deviation from this equilibrium indicates that evolution is occurring within the population. Therefore, the change in allele frequencies in a population, which results in evolution, is a fundamental aspect of the Hardy-Weinberg principle.
Which of the following were not among the basic concepts of Lamarckism?

Internal vital forces: Lamarck suggested that organisms possess inherent internal forces or tendencies driving them towards greater complexity and adaptation to their environment.

Use and disuse of organs: Lamarck proposed that the use or disuse of organs by organisms during their lifetime would result in the development or degeneration of those organs, respectively, and these acquired traits could be inherited by offspring.

Inheritance of acquired characters: Lamarck hypothesized that organisms could pass on traits acquired during their lifetime to their offspring, contributing to evolutionary change.

The concept of the struggle for existence, which involves competition among individuals for resources and survival, is more closely associated with Charles Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection, rather than Lamarckism.
Which among the following are not included in the concept of inheritance of acquired characters?

Melanism in peppered moths is a classic example of natural selection. Before the industrial revolution, the light-colored morph was advantageous against lichen-covered trees. However, industrial pollution darkened tree bark, making the dark-colored morph more cryptic. As a result, the frequency of the dark morph increased in industrial areas due to higher survival rates against predation. This phenomenon, known as industrial melanism, demonstrates how environmental changes can drive shifts in allele frequencies within populations through natural selection, without any involvement of Lamarckian mechanisms.
According to Lamarckism, long necked giraffes evolved because:
Short necks suddenly changed into long necks
Of stretching of necks over many generations by short necked ones

According to Lamarckism, long necked giraffes evolved because of stretching of necks over many generations by short necked ones. According to Lamarckism, the ancestors of giraffe had small neck and forelimbs and were like horses. They were residing in places with no surface vegetation, therefore, they had to stretch their neck and forelimbs to take the leaves for food. This led to slight elongation of these parts. Whatever they acquired in one generation was transmitted to the next generation with the result that a race of long necked and long forelimbed giraffes were developed.
The idea of Natural selection as the fundamental process of evolutionary changes was reached:
Independently by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in 1900
Independently by Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in 1859

Both Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace independently reached the idea of natural selection as the fundamental process of evolutionary change. They presented their ideas jointly in 1858, and Darwin published his seminal work "On the Origin of Species" in 1859, outlining the theory of evolution by natural selection.
Which of the following is correctly matched?
Hugo de Vries – Use and disuse theory

August Weismann proposed the theory of continuity of germplasm, which posits that hereditary information is transmitted through the germ cells (sperm and eggs) and remains separate from the somatic cells, thus ensuring the continuity of genetic material from generation to generation. This theory laid the groundwork for our modern understanding of genetics and inheritance.

Darwin is associated with the theory of evolution by natural selection, not myogenesis.

Louis Pasteur is associated with the discovery and development of pasteurization, a process used to kill harmful microorganisms in food and beverages.

Hugo de Vries proposed the theory of mutationism and introduced the concept of saltation, which suggests that evolutionary change occurs through sudden, large-scale mutations rather than gradual accumulation of small changes through use and disuse.
Jurassic period of the Mesozoic era characterized by:
Radiation of reptiles and origin of mammal like reptiles
Gymnosperms are dominant plants and first birds appear

During the Jurassic period of the Mesozoic era, gymnosperms, including conifers and cycads, were the dominant plant group, shaping terrestrial ecosystems. This period saw the emergence of the first birds, evolving from theropod dinosaurs, marking a significant milestone in the evolutionary history of vertebrates. The presence of gymnosperms as dominant plants provided habitat and food sources for diverse terrestrial life forms, including the evolving dinosaurs and the newly emerging birds. Thus, the Jurassic period is characterized by the flourishing of gymnosperms and the appearance of the earliest avian species, contributing to the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of the era.
Which of the following are properties of stabilizing selection?

Stabilizing selection is characterized by the preservation of the intermediate phenotype and the reduction of phenotypic variation in a population. It occurs when the environment remains relatively constant and favors the average phenotype. In such an environment, extreme phenotypes are selected against, leading to the maintenance of the intermediate phenotype. This is because the average phenotype is well-adapted to the prevailing conditions and provides a fitness advantage.
Which of the following was not included in the theory of special creation?
All the living organisms that see today were created as such
The diversity was always the same since creation and will be the same in future
The solar system came from a massive body

The theory of special creation posits that all living organisms were created in their present form and have remained unchanged since their creation. It also suggests that the diversity of life has always been the same since creation and will remain unchanged in the future. Additionally, proponents of special creation often believe in a relatively young Earth, typically around 4000 to 10,000 years old, based on religious interpretations. However, the origin of the solar system from a massive body is not a component of the theory of special creation; instead, it aligns more with scientific explanations such as the nebular hypothesis. Therefore, option (D) is not included in the theory of special creation.
Anatomically the structurally different structures with functional similarity are:

Analogous structures are anatomically different structures in different species that have similar functions but evolved independently in response to similar environmental pressures or ecological niches. These structures do not share a common evolutionary origin but have converged to perform similar functions. Examples of analogous structures include the wings of birds and insects, which both serve the function of flight but have different anatomical structures.
Which of the following is not a similarity between man and apes?

Smaller head and less cranial capacity is not a similarity between man and apes. Humans (Homo sapiens) share several anatomical similarities with apes (such as tail absence, erect posture, and grasping hands), humans actually have larger heads and greater cranial capacity compared to apes. The human brain is larger and more complex, with a significantly larger cerebral cortex, allowing for higher cognitive functions such as language, reasoning, and problem-solving. Therefore, smaller head and less cranial capacity does not represent a similarity between humans and apes, instead, it highlights a significant difference.
Which one of the following experiments suggests that the simplest living organisms could not have originated spontaneously from nonliving matter?
Microbes did not appear in stored meat
Meat was not spoiled, when heated and kept sealed in a vessel
Larva could appear in decaying organic matter

Meat was not spoiled, when heated and kept sealed in a vessel suggests that the simplest living organisms could not have originated spontaneously from nonliving matter. This experiment, often referred to as Louis Pasteur's swan-necked flask experiment, provided evidence against the spontaneous generation of life from nonliving matter. Pasteur demonstrated that when meat broth was heated and sealed in a flask with a long, swan-necked neck that prevented airborne microorganisms from entering, the broth remained free of spoilage or microbial growth. This experiment supported the idea of biogenesis, which states that living organisms only arise from pre-existing living organisms, rather than spontaneously generating from nonliving matter.

Directional selection is also known as progressive selection. Directional selection, a form of natural selection, favors individuals with extreme phenotypes over the average phenotype, leading to a shift in the population's trait distribution towards one end of the spectrum. This directional shift occurs due to environmental changes or selective pressures, causing certain traits to become more advantageous.

In disruptive selection, individuals with extreme phenotypes at both ends of the spectrum are favored over individuals with intermediate phenotypes. This type of natural selection occurs when environmental conditions favor multiple distinct phenotypic traits within a population, rather than a single optimal phenotype. As a result, individuals with extreme traits at both ends of the spectrum are better adapted to different aspects of the environment and experience higher fitness, leading to the maintenance of phenotypic diversity within the population.
An important evidence in favor of organic evolution is the occurrence of:

Homologous organs are structures that are similar in different species because they share a common evolutionary origin, even if their functions may have diverged. Vestigial organs are structures that have lost their original function in the course of evolution. Both homologous and vestigial organs provide evidence in favor of organic evolution. Homologous organs demonstrate common ancestry and shared evolutionary history among different species, while vestigial organs suggest that organisms have evolved from ancestors with different functional needs, and these structures have become unnecessary over time. Therefore, the occurrence of homologous and vestigial organs supports the concept of organic evolution.
Which of the following represents the Hardy Weinberg equation?

In a population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the frequencies of alleles (represented by p and q) and genotypes remain constant from generation to generation, and they sum up to 1 (or 100%). Hardy Weinberg equation is:

p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1

where p2 represents the frequency of homozygous dominant individuals (AA), 2pq represents the frequency of heterozygous individuals (Aa), and q2 represents the frequency of homozygous recessive individuals (aa).
How many factors affect the Hardy Weinberg principle?

Hardy Weinberg stated that there are five factors affecting this principle. They are Gene migration or gene flow, genetic drift, mutation, genetic recombination, and natural selection. Each factor plays a major role in evolution. These factors collectively influence the genetic composition of populations and play significant roles in driving evolutionary change.
Which is the correct statement regarding Founder effect?

The Founder effect, characterized by a small group establishing a new population, can influence the genetic diversity of that population. In some cases, this reduced genetic diversity can contribute to reproductive isolation between populations, a key step in speciation. While the Founder effect itself does not directly cause speciation, it can initiate processes such as genetic drift and isolation that may eventually lead to the formation of new species over evolutionary time. Therefore, the Founder effect can play a role in the early stages of speciation by influencing the genetic composition of founding populations.
The results in the formation of new phenotypes is:

New phenotypes can result from pre-existing helpful mutations, which are genetic changes that provide individuals with advantageous traits in their environment. These mutations occur before the appearance of the new phenotype and can contribute to the development of novel characteristics that enhance an organism's survival and reproductive success. Therefore, Pre-existing helpful mutations describes the genetic basis for the formation of new phenotypes through beneficial mutations that existed prior to the emergence of the phenotype.
The animals which evolved into the first amphibian that lived on both land and water, were:

The animals that evolved into the first amphibians, which could live both on land and in water, were indeed lobefin fishes, specifically a group known as lobe-finned fish or Sarcopterygii. These early lobefin fishes possessed limb-like fins with robust bones and muscles, enabling them to move and support themselves on land. Over time, these fish-like creatures adapted to terrestrial environments, eventually giving rise to the first tetrapods, which are the ancestors of modern amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
Spermatozoa are nourished during their development by:

Spermatozoa are nourished during their development by sertoli cells.

Each lobule of testes contains one to three seminiferous tubules in which the sperms are produced. 

Each seminiferous tubule is lined on its inside by two types of cells called male germ cells (spermatogonia) and Sertoli cells. Sertoli cells are also known as nurse cells. They provide nutrition to spermatozoa. Spermatozoa are developing sperms. It is formed during the last stage of spermatogenesis. This stage is known as spermiogenesis. In this step, spermatids are transformed into spermatozoa (sperms) by the process of metamorphosis. Heads of spermatozoa are embedded in the Sertoli cells.
In man the vas deferencs emerges from:
The vas deferens emerge from the cauda epididymis. It's a tube that carries mature sperm from the testes to the ejaculatory duct during ejaculation.

Follicular atresia is degeneration of enlarged folliciles.

The breakdown of the ovarian follicles is called as follicular atresia, which includes granulosa cells that surrounds the oocytes, internal and external theca cells. It occurs continually throughout a woman's life, as she is born with millions of follicles but will only ovulate around 400 times in her lifetime.

Mature ovarian follicles are called the Graffian follicle which rupture and releases the secondary oocyte. Estrogen is secreted by the Graafian follicle present in the ovary. It increases the endometrial thickening in the uterus. A high amount of estrogen causes an LH surge resulting in ovulation.
The development of primary sex characteristics is evidenced by:
A rapid change in height and weight.

Primary sexual characteristics are the physical characteristics directly involved in reproduction, such as the sex organs such as the testes, ovaries, and external genitalia. Thus the development of primary sex characteristics is evidenced by the growth and development of the ovaries.
Which of the following hormones acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate secretion of some factors which help in the process of spermiogenesis?

Spermiogenesis is the final stage of spermatogenesis where the spermatids need to mature into motile sperm cells (spermatozoa). The main hormones which regulate spermatogenesis are testosterone and FSH (follicle stimulating hormone) and the Sertoli cells possess receptors for both these hormones. Thus, the Sertoli cells, which nurse the sperm cells in the testes mature when the FSH secreted by the anterior pituitary binds to its receptors.
Polar bodies are produced during the formation of:

During the development of the foetus, many oogonia are produced which undergo mitosis and form primary oocytes which remain at prophase of meiosis I throughout the childhood. Primary oocytes are enclosed by a single layer of cells, the granulosa cells and form structures known as primordial follicles. During woman's fertile years, one primordial follicle per month develops into a mature follicle, known a Graafian follicle. It contains a secondary oocyte and the first polar body, formed when the primary oocyte divides by meiosis I. The secondary oocyte is haploid. The second meiotic division proceeds as far as metaphase but does not continue until a sperm fuses with the oocyte. At fertilisation, secondary oocyte undergoes the second meiotic division producing a large cell, the ovum and a second polar body. All polar bodies are small cells.

So, the first polar body is produced during the formation of the Secondary oocyte.
The foetal ejection reflex in humans triggers the release of:
