The foetal ejection reflex in humans triggers the release of oxytocin from maternal pituitary.

  • The mild uterine contractions called fetal ejection reflex originate from the fully developed fetus and the placenta.
  • The release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary gland is triggered by the fetal ejection reflex.
  • Stronger contractions are induced by oxytocin's effect on the uterine muscle, which in turn triggers more oxytocin release.
  • Stronger and stronger contractions come from the ongoing stimulatory reflex between uterine contraction and oxytocin release, which causes the baby to be expelled from the uterus through the birth canal.
Which of the following hormones is not secreted by human placenta?

LH is the hormone that is not secreted by human placenta. It is secreted by anterior pituitary. Initially during pregnancy, hCG performs the function of LH of maintaining corpus luteum for the secretion of progesterone. Later (around 16th week) in pregnancy, when placenta itself starts secreting estrogen and progesterone, corpus luteum regresses.
Which of the following is secreted only during the luteal phase of a menstrual cycle?

The luteal phase is also referred to as the 'secretory phase'. This refers both to the secretion of progesterone from the corpus luteum and to the secretion of a clear fluid by the endometrium during this phase. Only higher primates have menstrual cycles with regular bleeding.
Sixty percent of semen is produced by:

Sixty percent of semen is produced by seminal vesicles.

A major bulk of the semen consists of secretions from the male accessory glands, namely, seminal vesicles, bulbourethral glands and prostate gland. Of these, about sixty per cent of the semen constitutes of amino acids, fructose, citric acid, potassium etc. coming from the seminal vesicles.
Which one of the following events is correctly matched with the time period in a normal menstrual cycle?

In human females, menstruation is repeated at an average interval of about 28/29 days, and the cycle of events starting from one menstruation till the next one is called the menstrual cycle. One ovum is released (ovulation) during the middle of each menstrual cycle. The cycle starts with the menstrual phase, when menstrual flow occurs and it lasts for 3-5 days. The menstrual phase is followed by the follicular phase. During this phase, the primary follicles in the ovary grow to become a fully mature Graafian follicle and simultaneously the endometrium of uterus regenerates through proliferation. The growth of superficial and middle layer of endometrium occurs from the 5th to 14th day of the cycle under the influence of estrogen.
The vas deferens receives duct from the seminal vesicle and opens into urethra as_________.

The vas deferens receives duct from the seminal vesicle and opens into urethra as ejaculatory duct.

The vas deferens is a continuation of the cauda epididymis (tail part of epididymis). It is about 40 cm long and slightly coiled at first but becomes straight as it enters the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal. Here, it passes over the urinary bladder, curves around the ureter and joins a duct from seminal vesicle and opens into the urethra as the ejaculatory duct. These ducts store and transport the sperms from the testis to the outside through urethra.
First meiotic division of primary oocyte is completed:
At the time of copulation within fallopian tube
After formation of ovum within the ovary
At the time of fertilization within ampulla

The first meiotic division starts before delivery of the female foetus and is completed within the tertiary follicle of the ovary. Meiotic division of the secondary oocyte is completed at the time of fusion of a sperm with an ovum.
In a human foetus the limbs and digits develop after:

In a human foetus the limbs and digits develop after 8 weeks.

In human foetus, limbs are initially undifferentiated mesoderm which is covered with the epithelium. At the end of week 4 the limb bud primordia appear as small elevations. However, most of the development in the limbs occurs at week 6 but cannot be clearly differentiated. At 8 weeks of gestation, the feet and hands can be distinguished, but may still be webbed. A couple of weeks later, one can identify the limbs and digits clearly. 

Thus, the limbs and digits in a human foetus begin to develop after '8 weeks'.
Fertilisation in humans is practically feasible only if:
The ovum and sperms are transported simultaneously to ampullary-isthmic junction of the fallopian tube
The ovum and sperms are transported simultaneously to ampullary-isthmic junction of the cervix
The sperms are transported into cervix within 48 hrs of release of ovum in uterus
The sperms are transported into vagina just after the release of ovum in fallopian tube

The motile sperms swim rapidly, pass through the cervix, enter into the uterus, and finally reach the junction of the isthmus and ampulla (ampullary-isthmic junction) of the fallopian tube. The ovum released by the ovary is also transported to the ampullary-isthmic junction where fertilization takes place. Fertilization can only occur if the ovum and sperms are transported simultaneously to the ampullary isthmic junction. This is the reason why not all copulations lead to fertilization and pregnancy.
Mature sperms are stored in the:

The epididymis is a coiled tube present on the posterior surface of each testis. Vasa differentia from the rete testis opens into the epididymis. Within epididymis, sperms undergo maturation and nourishment. It is also the site for the storage of sperm.
The eggs with calcareous shells are called:

Cleidoic eggs are those eggs, which have a protective shell and are laid out of water. The shell is porous to air and may be flexible or calcareous (hard). The eggs contain all the food the embryo needs to develop into a hatchling. The significance of the cleidoic egg is that it enables reproduction out of, and often away from, water. The eggs of insects and birds, which is enclosed in a protective shell limiting the exchange of water, gases, etc. These types of eggs are found in reptiles, birds, and insects.
Choose the incorrect statement from the following:
In birds and mammals, internal fertilisation takes place.
Polyspermy is prevented by the chemical changes in the egg surface.
In the human female implantation occurs almost seven days after fertilisation.

During fertilisation, a sperm comes in contact with the zona pellucida layer of the ovum and induces changes in the membrane that block the entry of additional sperm. Thus, it ensures that only one sperm can fertilise an ovum.
Which of the following hormones is not secreted by the human placenta?

LH is the hormone that is not secreted by the human placenta. It is secreted by the anterior pituitary. Initially, during pregnancy, hCG performs the function of LH of maintaining corpus luteum for the secretion of progesterone. Later (around the 16th week) in pregnancy, when the placenta itself starts secreting estrogen and progesterone, the corpus luteum regresses.
Identify the wrong statement from the following:
High levels of estrogen trigger the ovulatory surge.
Oogonial cells start to proliferate and give rise to functional ova in regular cycles from puberty onwards.
Sperms released from seminiferous tubules are poorly motile/ non-motile.
Progesterone levels is high during the post-ovulatory phase of the menstrual cycle.
High levels of LH and FSH trigger the ovulatory surge. Sperms released from seminiferous tubules are non-motile. Oogonial cells cease activity when the girl child is still in the womb.
Mesoderm, the middle layer of the embryo differentiates into structures like:
conjunctiva, nervous system, hairs, nails
gut, respiratory tract, urinary bladder, digestive gland

Mesoderm, the middle layer of the embryo differentiates into structures like connective tissues, dermis, iris, and adrenal cortex. It is responsible for the formation of the critical structural elements of the body. The skeletal muscles, smooth muscles, bone, cartilage, blood vessels, and the skeleton are also formed from mesoderm.
Which of the following is not a function of the fertilizin-antifertilizin reaction?

A fertilizin is a proteoglycan secreted from the cortical region of the egg cytoplasm, that interacts with the antifertilizin of the sperm of the same species. This makes the sperm stick to the surface of the egg. An antifertilizin is a protein present in the plasma membrane of the sperm. Fertilizin acts as a receptor for antifertilizin and the reaction between fertilizin and antifertilizin makes the sperm more capable of fertilizing the egg of the same species.
Which enzyme is secreted by a sperm which helps in its penetration into the ovum?

Hyaluronidase: it is a family of enzymes that degrade hyaluronic acid. It is found in human testes, in bacterial cultures as a by-product, or in the heads of leeches and snake venoms. Hyaluronidase enzyme breaks down the outer membrane of the ovum called zona pellucida.
Production of milk by the mammary glands of a female towards the end of pregnancy is called _________.
Mammary gland cells develop the potential to produce milk towards the end of pregnancy. This process is termed as lactation.
What is the milk produced in the initial few days of lactation called?
The first couple of days after the onset of lactation, the milk produced from the mammary glands is yellowish and rich in nutrients and antibodies for the newborn baby. This is called colostrum.
Is produced by granulosa cells in ovary and inhibits the secretion of FSH
Is produced by granulosa cells in ovary and inhibits the secretion of LH
Is produced by nurse cells in testes and inhibits the secretion of LH
Inhibits the secretion of LH, FSH and prolactin

Inhibin is produced by granulosa cells in ovary and inhibits the secretion of LH.

FSH and LH act on specific membrane receptors in granulosa cells and theca cells of the ovary, stimulating follicular growth and hormone synthesis. The peptide hormone inhibin is synthesized and secreted by granulosa cells and specifically inhibits FSH synthesis and secretion by the pituitary. So, the correct option is "is produced by granulosa cells in ovary and inhibits the secretion of FSH".
Implantation of embryo at site other than uterus
Implantation of defective embryo in the uterus
Pregnancies terminated due to the hormonal imbalance

Ectopic pregnancies are referred to as implantation of embryo at site other than uterus.

The condition in which the fertilized egg gets implanted outside the uterus is called ectopic pregnancy. Under normal conditions, the fertilized egg travels through the fallopian tube and attaches to the uterine lining. In most situations, ectopic pregnancy occurs when the egg is implanted in either of the fallopian tubes. Hence it is also called tubal pregnancy. The fallopian tube cannot support the growing uterus and may lead to severe problems in fetal development.
The oestrous or menstrual cycle begins with a breaking down of the womb wall. The ovum or egg is released:

The menstrual cycle begins due to the breakdown of endometrial lining of the uterus and its blood vessels which forms liquids that flow out through the vagina. In human females, menstruation is repeated at an average interval of about 28/29 days, and the cycle of events starting from one menstruation till the next one is called the menstrual cycle. In the middle of the cycle, about 14th day both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) attain a peak level. The rapid secretion of LH leading to its maximum level during the mid of the cycle is called LH surge. This surge induces rupture of Graafian follicle and thereby the release of ovum (ovulation).
Human milk differs from cow's milk in that it contains a:

Mature human milk contains 3%--5% fat, 0.8%--0.9% protein, 6.9%--7.2% carbohydrate calculated as lactose, and 0.2% mineral constituents expressed as ash. Its energy content is 60--75 kcal/100 ml. The protein content is markedly higher and carbohydrate content is lower in colostrum than in mature milk.
Which of the following is a recessive trait in pea plants?
Recessive traits are the ones that require both alleles to be present to result in the expression of the gene product. Of the mentioned traits, only dwarf stem height is a recessive trait.
If you were to sample garden pea plants in Mendel’s garden, which of the following statements would hold?
Round seeds were more abundant than wrinkled seeds
Wrinkled seeds were more abundant than round seeds
Both round and wrinkled seeds were equally abundant
It depends on the time of day when sampling is done
Dominant allele can express even in the presence of a recessive allele. Hence dominant phenotype is more common. Round seeds are dominant over wrinkled seeds; hence would be more abundant.
What was the model organism used by Mendel to give the laws of inheritance?
Mendel was a priest at a church. He grew garden peas behind the church. He studied the passing of characters within these by the process of hybridization.
What was the type of pea lines used by Mendel?
True-breeding pea lines were used by Mendel to study the processes. These are plants that are homozygous, hence have two copies of the same alleles.
What method is used to produce a true-breeding line?

A true-breeding line is the one that is homozygous for a given allele. This can be achieved by repeated self-pollination over many generations. This exposes the traits encoded by recessive alleles, which would otherwise be suppressed by the presence of dominant alleles.
Which of the following is a dominant character in pea plants?
Dominant characters are the ones that are expressed even when a single allele of the gene is present. Of the mentioned traits, only tall stem height is a dominant character.
What are the possible phenotypes that can be observed after self-crossing violet flowered pea plants?
Violet is dominant over white. Self-crossing of violet flowered plants will produce 25% recessive plants, which will have white-flowers.
Which of the following was not observed in F2 progeny of true-breeding tall and dwarf plants?

The F2 progeny has both dwarf and tall plants. 25% of them are homozygous tall, 50% are heterozygous tall, and 25% are homozygous dwarf. Dwarfness is a recessive trait and thus cannot be expressed in the heterozygous state.
Based on his experiments on pea plants, what were the things that he suspected of being transferred across generations?

Mendel studied pea plant inheritance of traits. He observed a pattern in the way traits were passed from parents to offsprings. Based on these, he suspected the existence of “factors” that need to be transferred through gametes from parents to offsprings.

The factors that Mendel observed were forgotten for decades to come. Later experiments, independent of these studies of Mendel, led to the discovery of genes as the source of transfer of information that codes for traits. Later it was found that Mendel’s factors were indeed genes.
What are the copies of genes that code for different phenotypes called?
Alleles are the copies of genes that code for contrasting traits. They are different forms of the same gene. For an allele to express, it should have a fitness benefit over its counterpart allele.
Which zygosity has the same allelic pair of genes?
Homozygosity refers to the state of genes that have both copies of genes or alleles as the same alleles. Heterozygous condition has two different alleles.
The factor expressed only in homozygous state is called _________.
A recessive factor cannot express itself when a dominant factor is present. It can only express when the organism has two copies of it. Thus, it requires homozygous state to express itself.
What is the cross between VV and vv called?
The offsprings produced from this cross are heterozygous for only one gene, which encodes for tallness. Thus, the cross is called a monohybrid cross.
What kind of a process is the segregation of alleles during meiosis?

Segregation of alleles leads to each gamete having only a single allele at the end of meiosis. This process is purely random or stochastic. Thus, the probability of a gamete having either alleles is 50%.
What, according to Medel, was responsible for the inheritance of specific traits?
Mendel discovered the laws of inheritance. He attributed these traits being encoded by factors. Later studies showed that these factors are genes.
The structure of DNA by ______ received the Nobel Prize in 1962.

One of the central problems in molecular biology was unraveling the structure of DNA. This was finally postulated by Francis Crick and James Watson in 1953. For this, they shared a Nobel Prize in 1962.
What branch of biology focusses on the study of patterns of inheritance?

Genetics is the branch of biology that deals with questions of inheritance. It uses techniques from various disciplines like Molecular biology, Cell biology, and many more to understand the basis of inheritance.
The process of transfer of characters from parents to offspring is referred to as ______.
Inheritance or Heredity is the process of transfer of information from parents/ancestors to offsprings. This gives rise to patterns that can be studied using the subject of genetics.
Who proposed the laws of inheritance in living organisms?

The laws of inheritance in living organisms were proposed by Gregor Mendel. He was the first person to apply the scientific method to understand patterns of inheritance. However, the importance of his work was not recognized until after his death.
What technique in plant biology was used by Gregor Mendel to derive the patterns of inheritance?

Gregor Mendel carried out the hybridization of pea plants with specific characters and used manual counting to carry out estimates of factors over generations. This gave rise to the laws of inheritance, as we know today.
What is the pair of homologous chromosomes that line together during the meiosis I called?
The pair of chromosomes that line up during meiosis has two copies of each homologous chromosome. Hence it is called a bivalent.
Who interpreted by observing the independent segregation of chromosomes during meiosis, that the factors they carry would also separate independently?

Sutton and Boveri had studied the segregation of chromosomes very closely by staining the cells and then developing a differential staining approach to visualize the pairs of chromosomes. To their surprise, this was very similar to the expectation of Mendel’s factors. Hence they made the conclusion that independent separation of chromosomes should lead to independent segregation of factors.
What theory was coined by Sutton and Boveri?

Sutton and Boveri were the key players in the world of biology during the decade of 1900-1910. They observed chromosome movements and studied Mendel’s experiments. Based on these, they devised the chromosomal theory of inheritance.
What is represented in the boxes of the Punnett square?

In the Punnett square, the boxes are filled with the offsprings that can be produced, in principle, from the combinations of gametes of both parents. This can be used to determine the genotypic and phenotypic ratios of the progeny.
The cross between white eyed female Drosophila and a red eyed male Drosophila would lead to the production of:
red eyed males and red eyed females
white eyed males and white eyed females
red eyed females and white eyed males
white eyed males and red eyed females.

The cross of white eyed female with red eyed male gives red eyed females and white eyed males. Rarely this cross may give all white eyed females and red eyed males. This results from non-separation of two homologous X chromosomes during anaphase I of meiosis. Both X chromosomes go together to same pole resulting in formation of one XXY i.e., white eyed female and red eyed males. This phenomenon is known as non-disjunction of two X chromosomes.
Which of the following is the carrier of genetic information?
DNA is the carrier of genetic information. Genes located on the DNA present in the chromosome controls each and every feature of an organism.
On which of the following chromosomal disorders are based on?
Imbalance in chromosome number and chromosome arrangement
Mutant allele and imbalance in chromosome number

The chromosomal disorders are the disorders that are based on the imbalance in chromosome number and chromosomal arrangement. The disorders which are due to the mutant allele and their defective products are known as Mendelian disorders.
Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Down’s syndrome?
Tallness is not a characteristic feature of Down’s syndrome. Some characteristic features include- Short stature, small round head, partially open mouth, furrowed tongue, etc.
Which of the following is not a feature of the tongue of the person suffering from Down’s syndrome?

The tongue of the person suffering from Down’s syndrome is not straight. It is wrinkled and is comparatively bigger than a normal human tongue. The tongue is also furrowed. These features help in the diagnosis of Down’s syndrome.
Removed during maturation of pro-insulin to insulin.

C-peptide is a short peptide chain that connects the A-chain and B-chain in pro-insulin. During the maturation process of pro-insulin to insulin, C-peptide is cleaved off, resulting in the formation of mature insulin. Therefore, it is removed during the maturation process rather than being responsible for the biological activity of insulin.
In mammals insulin is secreted as:

Insulin is a pro-hormone secreted in mammals by the pancreas. This pro-hormone need to be processed to become a fully mature and functional hormone. Insulin allows the absorption of glucose from the blood.
The trigger factor for activation of toxin of Bacillus thuringiensis is:

The trigger for the activation of the toxin produced by Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) is the alkaline pH environment found in the gut of insects. When ingested by insects, the alkaline conditions of the insect gut cause the toxin to become activated, leading to its toxicity against the insect pests. This specificity allows Bt toxins to selectively target and kill specific insect pests while remaining harmless to other organisms with different gut pH conditions.
A cell displaying a foreign antigen used for synthesis of antigens
Production of somaclonal variants in tissue cultures
When a piece of RNA that is complementary in sequence is used to stop expression of a specific gene

When a piece of RNA that is complementary in sequence is used to stop expression of a specific gene is antisense technology. It is a tool used for gene expression inhibition. The principle associated with antisense technology is that an antisense nucleic acid sequence base pairs with a complementary sense RNA strand. This pairing prevents it from being translated into a protein which is a macromolecule.
In gene therapy, the gene defects are cured in a child or ________ stage.
In gene therapy, the gene defects are cured in child or embryonic stage. This phase is chosen to avoid complications and each and every cell will receive a healthy, functional gene.
Which kind of rice was patented by a U.S. company, despite the fact that the majority of variants of this rice are found in India?

Basmati rice, primarily cultivated in India, was patented by a U.S. company, RiceTec, in the 1990s. This sparked controversy due to its traditional significance and long history in the Indian subcontinent. Critics argued against the patent, highlighting issues of biopiracy and the attempt to claim ownership over a culturally significant crop.
PCR based markers have been developed to:
Obtain soil microorganisms with the help of specific enzyme reductase

PCR based markers have been developed to Differentiate different biotypes of gall midge. PCR-based markers are considered as the second-generation of molecular markers and are based on DNA sequence polymorphisms detected by PCR amplification of the sample DNAs. The DNA polymorphisms are reflected in the amplification products from the target regions of the sample DNAs.
Today transgenic model exist for disease like:

Transgenic animals serve as a model for human diseases. Today transgenic model exists for a disease like cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is a genetic, hereditary disease that affects the lungs and digestive system of humans.
Which of the following is an example of a biopharmaceutical produced using transgenic animals?

Transgenic animals, such as goats or pigs, can be genetically engineered to produce human proteins like insulin in their milk or tissues. This approach allows for the large-scale production of biopharmaceuticals, including insulin, which can then be extracted and purified for therapeutic use in treating diabetes. Therefore, insulin is an example of a biopharmaceutical produced using transgenic animals.
Which biotechnological tool is used to amplify specific DNA sequences for genetic testing and diagnosis?

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a powerful biotechnological tool used to amplify specific DNA sequences. It allows for the rapid replication of a targeted segment of DNA, enabling the production of millions of copies from just a few initial strands. PCR is widely employed in genetic testing and diagnosis to detect the presence of specific genes or mutations associated with diseases, forensics, and paternity testing.
By studying the effects of gene one can tell ______ role of a gene in the body.

The biological role of the introduced foreign gene can be predicted or observed by studying the effects of the gene in transgenic animals. The manipulated gene can introduce a new character or may lead to the loss of a character.
Transgenic mice are being developed for use in testing the safety of vaccines before they are used on:

Transgenic mice are being developed for use in testing the safety of vaccines before they are used on humans. These genetically modified mice are engineered to express human genes relevant to the immune system, allowing researchers to better predict human immune responses to vaccines. By conducting preclinical trials on transgenic mice, scientists can assess vaccine efficacy, toxicity, and potential side effects before advancing to human clinical trials, thereby enhancing safety and accelerating the vaccine development process.
Chemical safety testing is also known as _______ testing.

Chemical safety testing is also known as toxicity testing. It is said so because it measures the amount of toxic (chemical) substance in a sample that may affect living or non-living environment. It is also called as toxicology testing.
Which biotechnological approach is used to produce vaccines against viral diseases like hepatitis B?

Recombinant DNA technology involves the insertion of genes encoding viral antigens into expression vectors, which are then used to produce recombinant proteins in host cells. These recombinant proteins serve as antigens for vaccines against viral diseases.
Cleaving of phosphodiester bond in DNA by the enzyme
Cutting of DNA at specific position only
Prevention of the multiplication of bacteriophage by the host bacteria

'Restriction' in Restriction enzyme refers to prevention of the multiplication of bacteriophage by the host bacteria. A restriction enzyme is an enzyme that cuts DNA at or near a specific recognition nucleotide sequences known as restriction sites. These enzymes are found in bacteria and provide a defense mechanism against invading virus.
The techniques of using live organisms of enzymes from organism to produce products and processes useful to human is called:

Biotechnology is the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make products, or any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms, or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use.
_______ is the right granted by a government to an inventor to prevent others from the commercial use of his invention.
Patents are the right granted by a government to an inventor to prevent others from the commercial use of his invention. It is a form of intellectual property that gives legal rights to the inventor.
GEAC makes decisions regarding the validity and the safety of which kind of organisms?

GEAC makes decisions regarding the validity and the safety of genetically modified organisms. It works under the Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change and takes decisions regarding the validity of GM research and safety of introducing GM products for public services.
What is the primary function of monoclonal antibodies in medicine?
Detection of specific molecules in the body

Monoclonal antibodies are laboratory-produced molecules that can bind to specific targets, such as antigens or proteins. In medicine, they are used for targeted detection of molecules, such as tumor markers or pathogens, in diagnostic tests like ELISA.
Production of a human protein in bacteria by is possible because:
Bacterial cells can carry out the RNA splicing reactions.
The mechanism of gene regulation is identical in humans and bacteria.
The human chromosome can replicate in bacterial cells.

Production of a human protein in bacteria by is possible because the genetic code is universal. The genetic code, which specifies the correspondence between nucleotide triplets (codons) in mRNA and amino acids in proteins, is the same across all living organisms. Therefore, when the gene encoding a human protein is inserted into bacterial cells, the bacterial machinery can read the mRNA transcript and synthesize the corresponding protein using its own ribosomes and tRNA molecules. This process, known as recombinant DNA technology, enables the production of human proteins in bacterial hosts for various biotechnological and medical applications.

Restriction enzymes, also known as restriction endonucleases, are often referred to as molecular scissors because they have the ability to cut DNA molecules at specific recognition sites. This enzymatic activity enables them to cleave DNA at precise locations, facilitating various molecular biology techniques such as DNA cloning and restriction mapping.
The RNA interference helps in which of the following activity?

RNA interference (RNAi) serves as a defense mechanism in cells by targeting and degrading viral RNA or inhibiting viral protein translation. It helps to protect cells from viral infection by regulating gene expression and interfering with viral replication. This mechanism is essential for cell defense against foreign genetic elements like viruses.
In some children, the ADA deficiency can be cured by:

ADA (adenosine deaminase) deficiency, a genetic disorder affecting the immune system, can be treated by both bone marrow transplantation and enzyme replacement therapy. Bone marrow transplantation can provide functional ADA-producing cells, while enzyme replacement therapy involves administering the missing ADA enzyme to supplement the deficient enzyme activity.
Antibodies are secreted against the antigen. Antibodies are the immunoglobulin which binds with the antigen and eliminates it. These are developed by the immune system of humans.
Which is used to select genes from genomic library?

DNA probes are stretches of single-stranded DNA used to detect the presence of complementary nucleotide sequences (target sequences) by hybridization. Genomic library comprises large number of genes in the form of different nucleotide sequences of DNA fragments and they can be selected with the help of DNA probes.
Silencing of a gene could be achieved through the use of:
Both short interfering RNA and antisense RNA

Silencing of a gene can be achieved by both antisense RNA and short interfering RNA (RNAi). Antisense RNA is a single-stranded RNA molecule complementary to a specific mRNA sequence, inhibiting translation or promoting degradation of the mRNA. Similarly, short interfering RNA (RNAi) molecules trigger the degradation of specific mRNA molecules, thereby reducing gene expression.

Golden rice is genetically modified to produce beta-carotene, Bt-brinjal contains a gene from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis for insect resistance, and Bt-cotton carries a gene from Bacillus thuringiensis for resistance to certain pests. Therefore, all of the three are genetically modified crop.

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) technique was invented by Karry Mullis in 1983. PCR revolutionized molecular biology by allowing the amplification of specific DNA sequences, making it an indispensable tool in various fields such as genetics, forensics, and medical diagnostics.
Golden rice is a transgenic crop of the future with the:

Golden rice is a genetically modified crop engineered to produce high levels of provitamin A (beta-carotene), a precursor of vitamin A. This trait addresses vitamin A deficiency, a significant health problem in many developing countries where rice is a staple food.
Cry-I endotoxins obtained from Bacillus thuringiensis are effective against:

Cry-I endotoxins obtained from Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) are effective against bollworms, which are major pests of various crops like cotton, corn, and soybeans. These endotoxins specifically target certain insect pests, such as the larvae of lepidopteran insects like bollworms, causing their death upon ingestion.
What is the genotype of the person suffering from Klinefelter’s syndrome?
The genotype of the person suffering from Klinefelter’s syndrome is 44+ XXY. This deviation from a normal person’s genotype is due to the additional copy of the X-chromosome.
Which of the following is incorrect with respect to Klinefelter’s syndrome?
The fusion of an abnormal egg with normal sperm
The fusion of a normal egg with an abnormal sperm
The fusion of a normal egg with a normal sperm

The fusion of a normal egg with a normal sperm leads to the formation of a healthy baby. Klinefelter’s syndrome appears due to the union of an abnormal egg (two X-chromosomes + autosomes) with a normal sperm (Y-chromosome+ autosomes) or a normal egg (X-chromosome + autosomes) with abnormal sperm (XY chromosomes+ autosomes).
Which of the following is a representation of a recessive trait?

Blue eyes are the representation of a recessive trait. Some other recessive traits include albinism, alkaptonuria, and cystic fibrosis. Some dominant traits are achondroplasia, brown eyes, brachydactyly, Huntington disease, etc.

Genes which are involved in quantitative inheritance are called as polygenes. In quantitative inheritance, each dominant allele expresses itself as a part of functional polypeptide and the full trait is shown when all the dominant alleles are present in an organism.
Which of the following is the representation of a dominant trait?

Widow’s peak is an example of a dominant trait. Other dominant traits include tongue rollers, morphan syndrome, free ear lobes, etc. Some recessive traits are tongue non-roller’s, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, fused ear lobes, Tay- Sachs disease, etc.
What is the inheritance of characters by plasmagenes known as?

The inheritance of characters by plasmagenes is known as extrachromosomal inheritance or extranuclear inheritance. Plasmagenes are some self-replicating genes which are present in the cytoplasm, mitochondrial DNA and chloroplast DNA.
Which of the following is incorrect with respect to mutation?

Mutations are not continuous. Instead, mutations are discontinuous variations in the genotype and phenotype of an organism. This is due to the changes in chromosomes and DNA. Mutations are sudden and they are a cause of the variation in DNA.
Which of the following is not a type of mutation?

Mutations are of three different types depending upon their cause and environment. The three types are:

i. Gene mutation

ii. Chromosomal aberrations

iii. Genomatic mutations
Which of the following is a classic example of point mutation?
Sickle cell anaemia is a classic example of point mutation. Point mutation generally means that when a single base pair of DNA changes, a gene mutation occurs that causes the alternation of DNA.
Which of the following is also known as the removal of one or more bases from the nucleotide chain?

The removal of one or more bases from the nucleotide chain is also known as deletion. Deletion is a type of frame-shift mutation. If we add one or more bases in a nucleotide chain, then it is called insertion.
What is the substitution of a purine base with a pyrimidine base known as?
The substitution of a purine base with a pyrimidine base or vice versa is known as transversion. This refers to the substitution mutation which is the replacement of one base by another.
Which of the following is not responsible for the formation of chromosomes?

The endoplasmic reticulum is not responsible for the formation of chromosomes. Chromosomes are made up of proteins, DNA, and RNA. The loss or gain of a segment of DNA often causes the alternation of chromosomes.
When a part of a chromosome is duplicated
When a part of a chromosome is left out
When part of a DNA molecule is not copied during DNA replication
When a part of a chromosome is translocated

A deletion mutation occurs when part of a DNA molecule is not copied during DNA replication. This uncopied part can be as small as a single nucleotide or as much as an entire chromosome. The loss of this DNA during replication can lead to a genetic disease.
Shifting of part of chromosomes to the outside wall of nucleus
Shifting of a chromosome to another chromosome
Shifting of a part of a chromosome to another homologous chromosome
Shifting of a part of a chromosome to another non-homologous chromosome

Translocation is the shifting of a part of a chromosome to another non-homologous chromosome. It results in the formation of new recombinant chromosomes as this induces faulty pairing of chromosomes during meiosis.
What is the full form of CML?

CML stands for Chronic myelogenous leukaemia. CML occurs due to the translocation of a segment of the long arm from chromosome 22 to chromosome 9. Chromosome 22 is also known as the Philadelphia chromosome.
Segmental changes of chromosome having an evolutionary significance, is of which of the following?

An important class of translocation having evolutionary significance is known as segmental changes or reciprocal translocation. It involves the mutual exchange of chromosome segments between two non-homologous chromosomes.
In which of the following organisms, an inversion occurs frequently?

Inversion occurs frequently in Drosophila as a result of X-ray radiation. Inversion is technically a type of chromosomal aberration where the linear order of genes changes by 180° through the rotation.
Genomatic mutation is of how many types?

Genomatic mutations are of two types-

i. Aneuploidy

ii. Euploidy

This kind of mutation involves the change in chromosome number that bring about visible threats on the phenotype.
Where are the parental genotypes mentioned in a Punnett square?
In a Punnett square, the parental genotypes are represented in the left column and the top row of the square.

The first chemical mutagen that was used in world war II is mustard gas. It was first used by C. Auerbach et. al. Chemical mutagens which are known on the planet Earth are more dangerous than radiations.
Which of the following is incorrect with respect to aneuploidy?
Arises due to the non-disjunction of homologous pair of chromosomes
Arises due to the non-disjunction of non-homologous chromosomes
One gamete comes to have an extra chromosome
Another gamete becomes deficient in one chromosome

Aneuploidy does not arise due to the non-disjunction of non-homologous chromosomes. Instead, it arises due to the non-disjunction of the homologous pair of chromosomes. It results in the formation of gamete with an extra chromosome and the other gamete deficient in one chromosome.
Which of the following represents nullisomic conditions?
2n-2 represents nullisomic condition which is a type of aneuploidy. 2n-1, 2n+1, and 2n+2 represent the monosomic condition, trisomic condition, and tetrasomic condition respectively.
Which of the following is not an example of aneuploidy?

Phenylketonuria is not an example of aneuploidy. The examples of aneuploidy are Down’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome, and turner’s syndrome where down’s and Klinefelter’s syndrome show trisomy condition while turner’s syndrome show monosomic condition.
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to polyploidy?
A decrease in the number of sets of chromosomes
Increase in the number of sets of chromosomes

Decrease in the number of sets of chromosomes is not known as polyploidy. In polyploidy conditions, after the telophase stage of cell division, cytokinesis fails to occur which results in an increase in a whole set of chromosomes in an organism. Polyploidy is often seen in plants and it results in sterility in animals.
H.J Muller is considered as the father of Actinobiology. He used X-rays to increase the rate of mutation in Drosophila. He opened an entirely new field in inducing mutations.
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to ionizing radiation?
The cells ionized show abnormal cell division
Frequency of induced mutations is directly proportional to the doses of the radiations

Ionizing radiations are responsible for different types of cancer as ionizing radiations cause the breaks in the chromosomes. The cells which become ionized show abnormal cellular division. The frequency of induced mutations is also directly proportional to the doses of the radiations.
Which of the following chemical mutagen is both mutagenic to replicating and non-replicating DNA?
Nitrous acid is the chemical mutagen that is both mutagenic to replicating and non-replicating DNA. Acridines are very powerful mutagens and they induce frame shift-mutation or gibberish mutation.
Which of the following mutations is the most common type of mutation?
The commonest type of mutation is the forward mutation in which the normal or the wild type of gene changes to a new genotype which can be either recessive or dominant.
What kinds of traits were described by Mendel?
Through the experiments of pea conducted by Mendel, he described distinct contrasting traits such as flower colour which are either purple or white.
Which of the following is a classic example of polygenic inheritance?

Skin colour in humans is a classic example of polygenic inheritance as this trait is controlled by three or more genes and we can see that this trait is not so distinct amongst the human population and is spread across a gradient.
Askin’s Tumour is which type of Cancer?

Askin's tumour is a rare, primitive neuroectodermal tumour which arises from the soft tissues of the chest wall, particularly in the paravertebral region. It was first described by Askin in 1979. It is recognized as part of the Ewing's sarcoma family of tumours. It is a type of Blood Cancer.
Which of the following cells are destroyed by the HIV virus which results in the weakening of the immunity of a person?

HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus.

HIV causes AIDS and interferes with the body's ability to fight infections. The virus can be transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen or vaginal fluids. It destroys Lymphocytes.
Identify the correct pair representing the causative agent of typhoid fever and the confirmatory test for typhoid.

Salmonella typhi: It causes typhoid fever in humans. It enters the human body through contaminated food or water. It enters the small intestine initially, and from here it spreads to other organs.

The Widal test is used as a confirmatory test for typhoid. It measures the capacity of antibodies against flagella and lipopolysaccharide receptors of bacteria in the serum of individuals.
A drug addict exhibits which of the following withdrawal symptoms?

Drug addiction can be defined as the psychological attachment to certain effects like euphoria, temporary feeling of well-being, produced by excess usage of drugs & alcohol. The characters shown by the body due to the abrupt discontinuation of drugs or alcohol are called withdrawal symptoms.

Withdrawal symptoms include:

  1. Anxiety
  2. Shakiness
  3. Nausea
  4. Sweating
Cancer detection is not based on which of the following tests or studies?

Early detection of cancer is essential as it allows the disease to be treated successfully in many cases. Cancer detection is based on biopsy and histopathological studies of the tissue and the blood and bone marrow tests for increased cell counts in the case of leukaemias.
What is the use of monoclonal antibodies?
They are used to detect cancerous cells
They are used to increase the blood platelets count
They are used to give a three-dimensional image of the internal organs of the body
Monoclonal antibodies against cancer-specific antigens are also used for the detection of certain cancers. For example, Herceptin. They are usually prepared by hybridoma technology.
Which of the following is not a common approach to treat cancer?

The common approaches for treatment of cancer are surgery, radiation therapy (with least ionising radiations), immunotherapy and chemotherapy. Most cancers are treated by the combination of surgery, radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
Which of the following radiations are used in radiotherapy?

In radiotherapy, tumour cells are irradiated lethally by gamma rays which are the most penetrating and least ionising rays. For example, I131 is used to treat thyroid cancer. These radiations generally kill the immature, fast dividing cancerous cells.
When are the biological response modifiers used to treat cancer?
When the immune system responds to cancerous cells
When the immune system fails to detect the cancerous cells
When the immune system destroys the cancerous cells

Tumour cells have been shown to avoid detection and destruction in the immune system. Therefore, the patients are given substances called as biological response modifiers such as α-interferon when the immune system of the body fails to recognise the cancerous cells, which then activates their immune system and helps in destroying the tumour.
Substances used to prevent the action of carcinogens
Substances used to slow down the immune system

Anticarcinogens are the substances which prevent the action of carcinogens. Anticarcinogens occur in green-yellow vegetables, fruits and milk. &beta-carotene present in green-yellow vegetables is a promotor-inhibitor which weakens the action of cancer promoters.
Plasmodium vivax is a protozoan parasite and a human pathogen. This parasite generally causes malaria and affects the liver.
The antigen binding site of an antibody depicts:

The antigen-binding site of an antibody depicts the idiotype The antigenic determinants on antibodies are classified into three categories: Isotype, Allotype & Idiotype

Idiotype: The unique amino-acid sequence of the variable domains of a given antibody can function not only as an antigen-binding site but also as a set of antigenic determinants.

The idiotypic determinants are generated by the conformation of the heavy and light0chain variable regions. Each individual antigenic determinant of the variable region is referred to as an idiotype.
Hypersensitivity to an allergen is due to _________.

Hypersensitivity refers to undesirable reactions produced by the immune system including allergies and autoimmunity. They are usually referred to as an abnormal (aberrant) functioning of the immune system and these reactions may be damaging, uncomfortable, or occasionally fatal. Hence, hypersensitivity to an allergen is due to the aberrant functioning of the immune system.
Chikungunya: It is a viral disease (genus Alphavirus) that is transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes – including Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

The full form of NACO is the National Aids Control Organization. It is a government organization of India, set up to monitor the epidemic in India under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Also, it aims to improve HIV+ individuals’ healthcare coverage and to safeguard and uphold their human rights. It views an India in which every HIV+ individual has access to healthcare services and dignified care.
Which of the following is not the causal organism for ringworm?
Macrosporum - is not the causal organisms for ringworm. Microsporum, Trichophyton, Epidermophyton are the organisms that causes different ringworm infections.
ELISA uses an enzyme to detect the binding of antigen and antibody. The enzyme converts the colorless substrate into a colored product, indicating the presence of Ag: Ab binding.
A drug that prevents infection and decay is called a/an:

Analgesic: An analgesic is a type of medication that helps relieve pain. It works by reducing pain signals in the body, providing comfort and easing discomfort. Common analgesic drugs include acetaminophen (paracetamol), ibuprofen, and aspirin.
Which one of the following vitamin deficiency diseases can be cured by eating a diet which includes green leafy vegetables, banana, cereals, egg yolk?

Anaemia occurs when there's a deficiency of haemoglobin or iron in the blood. Haemoglobin, an iron-rich protein, is responsible for transporting oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues. Insufficient iron leads to decreased haemoglobin levels, hindering proper oxygen circulation throughout the body. This condition primarily results from an iron deficiency. Treatment often involves medications to boost iron levels. Consuming iron-rich foods such as jaggery, amla, and green leafy vegetables is recommended. Healthy haemoglobin levels typically range from 13.5 to 17.5 gm/dl for men and 12.0 to 15.5 gm/dl for women.
The person not able to see nearby objects clearly is suffering from?
Hypermetropia is a vision defect also known as long sightedness defect. Person suffering from this is able to see the distant object clearly but unable to see the nearby objects clearly.
Which of the following is mRNA vaccine used against Covid-19 infection?

The Moderna COVID‑19 vaccine sold under the brand name Spikevax, is a COVID-19 vaccine developed by American company Moderna, the United States National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), and the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA).
The inflammatory response in allergy is due to the release of ________ by mast cells.

Inflammatory response in allergy is due to the release of histamine by mast cells. Histamine along with IgE antibodies act as allergy mediator. It dilates arteries and causes fluid accumulation which causes the inflammatory response.
Which of the following is a communicable disease?

Measles is a highly contagious virus that resides in the nose and throat mucus of infected individuals. It spreads through coughing and sneezing, with transmission occurring when others breathe contaminated air or touch infected surfaces and then their eyes, noses, or mouths. The disease is characterized by a fever, malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, often referred to as the three "C"s. Pathognomonic signs include Koplik spots, followed by a maculopapular rash, typically appearing around 14 days after exposure.
B.C.G. vaccine is normally used to prevent-

The B.C.G. vaccine is a vaccine primarily used against tuberculosis (TB). It is named after its inventors Albert Calmette and Camille Guérin.

In countries where tuberculosis or leprosy is common, one dose is recommended in healthy babies as soon after birth as possible.
Which of the following diseases is an allergic response?

Hay Fever is an allergic swelling and secretion of the mucous membrane of nose, throat and conjunctiva in response to pollen and spores. Itchy and watery eyes, sneezing and running nose are its most common symptoms.
In polycythemia, cells that increase in number abnormally are:

The cells that increase abnormally are erythrocytes, also commonly known as red blood cells. Erythrocytes are essential for carrying oxygen to all parts of the body, and while an increase in their number might sound good, it can lead to complications like blood clots due to increased blood viscosity.
Use of polished rice in human diet causes following diseases:

The milling and polishing processes both remove nutrients. A diet based on unenriched white rice leaves many people vulnerable to the neurological disease beriberi, due to a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Beriberi is the classical manifestation of chronic dietary deficiency in vitamin B1.
Drug which reduce fever is known as:

An antipyretic is a drug that reduces fever.  Antipyretics cause the hypothalamus to override a prostaglandin-induced increase in temperature.  The body then works to lower the temperature, which results in a reduction in fever.

Therefore drug which reduces fever is known as antipyretic.
Nucleic acid present in corona virus is:

Coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2 (the virus responsible for COVID-19), contain ribonucleic acid (RNA) as their genetic material. RNA viruses, like coronaviruses, use RNA as their primary genetic material instead of DNA. This RNA carries the instructions necessary for viral replication and protein synthesis within host cells.
Scurvy is caused by not having enough ________, resulting in general weakness, anaemia, gum disease and skin bleeding.

Ascorbic acid, commonly known as Vitamin C, functions as an antioxidant and plays a vital role in tissue repair and enzyme-related processes within the body. Deficiency of this essential nutrient can lead to scurvy. Vitamin C is abundant in citrus fruits like lemon, orange, and guava. Its chemical formula is C6H8O6.
Flowers with both androecium and gynoecium are called:

Flowers with both androecium and gynoecium are called Bisexual flowers.

A flower that contains both the male reproductive structure (androecium) and female reproductive structure (gynoecium) is called a bisexual flower or monoecious. E.g. Rose, China rose etc.
The transfer of pollen from the anther to stigma is called _________.

The transfer of pollen from the anther to stigma is called Pollination.

Pollination is the process by which pollen is transferred from the anther or the male part to the stigma or the female part of the plant thereby enabling fertilization and reproduction.
The fusion of female reproductive nucleus with the male reproductive nucleus is known as _______.

The fusion of female reproductive nucleus with the male reproductive nucleus is known as Fertilization.

Fertilization is a process in sexual reproduction that involves the fusion of male gamete and female gamete leading to the formation of a zygote that develops into an organism.
The two nuclei at the end of the pollen tube are called _____.

The two nuclei at the end of the pollen tube are called Tube nucleus and generative nucleus.

  • After pollination process, the pollen grains germinate into pollen tube .
  • The pollen tube travels through stigma and style and reaches the ovules in the ovary .
  • Then the generative nucleus divides into two male gametes in which one fuses with egg and the other one fuses with pollen nuclei.

Generative nucleus divides forming 2 male nuclei.

After fertilization, the generative nucleus divides to form two nuclei, one is called male gametic nucleus and other is sperm nucleus. So, as the pollen tube is growing, at its tip, there are three nuclei, male gametic nucleus, sperm nucleus and tube nucleus without a cell wall, sharing a common cytoplasm.

Embryo sac is located inside the ovule.

The embryo sac develops within the ovule surrounded by the nucellus, which is in turn surrounded by the integuments. One cell of the nucellus undergoes meiosis to produce four megaspores.
One nucleus of the pollen tube and secondary nucleus of the ovum grow into:

Endosperm is formed when the two sperm nuclei inside a pollen grain reach the interior of a female gametophyte (sometimes known as the embryo sac). One male nucleus fuses with the egg cell to form a zygote (2n) and another male nucleus fuses with the secondary nucleus of the central cell, resulting in endosperm (2n) formation.
The stalk of Datura flower at its base is known as ______________.

The stalk of Datura flower at its base is known as Pedicel.

Pedicel is a green stalk on which a flower is borne in an inflorescence. It holds individual flowers in place.
The male reproductive part of a flower is known as ___________.

The male reproductive part of a flower is known as stamen.

In many plants, flowers are referred to as the reproductive parts. The flowers consists of male reproductive structures called stamens and a female reproductive structure called pistil. Stamen consists of two parts- anther and filament. Pistil consists of three parts- stigma, style and ovary.

The other name for gynoecium is Pistil.

The gynoecium represents the female reproductive part of the flower. The gynoecium may consist of a single pistil (monocarpellary) or may have more than one pistil (multicarpellary). When there is more than one, the pistils may be fused together (syncarpous) or maybe free (apocarpous). Each pistil has three parts the stigma, style and ovary. The stigma serves as a landing platform for pollen grains. The style is the elongated slender part beneath the stigma. The basal bulged part of the pistil is the ovary.
Functional megaspore in a flowering plant develops into:

In angiosperms or flowering plants, the megaspore mother cell produces a functional megaspore that develops into an embryo sac through two distinct processes megasporogenesis (formation of the megaspore in the nucellus, or megasporangium), and megasporogenesis (development of the megaspore into the embryo sac, or megagametophyte).
Which of the following is similar to autogamy, but requires pollinators?

Geitonogamy is similar to autogamy, but requires pollinators.

Transfer of pollen from an anther of one flower to a stigma of another flower on the same plant is called as geitonogamy. Although geitonogamy is functionally cross-pollination involving a pollinating agent, genetically it is similar to autogamy since the pollen grains come from the same plant. Cleistogamy or automatic self-pollination describes the trait of certain plants to propagate by using non-opening, self-pollinating flowers. Especially well known in peanuts, peas, and beans.
What is the function of the filiform apparatus?
Recognize the suitable pollen at the stigma

The function of the filiform apparatus is to guide the entry of pollen tube.

Synergid cell wall forms filiform apparatus at the micropylar end. Filiform apparatus is the extension of the synergids beyond apex of embryo sac. It helps in entry of pollen tube in the synergids.

Ruminate endosperm occurs in annonaceae.

  • Ruminate endosperm is the condition in which the endosperm is dissected by in-growths of the seed coat, is a common condition in the palms or Annonaceae. This type of endosperm develops early and hence the in-growths are formed directly into its tissue.
  • Seeds of Annonaceae are characterized as possessing are one to many pistil; have a fleshy and usually brightly colored cover, have ruminate endosperm (nutritive tissue surrounding the embryo) and are oily.
Which of the following statements is correct?
The hard outer layer of pollen is called intine

'Tapetum nourishes the developing pollen' is correct.

  • The tapetum which is present along with the embryo to provide nourishment for the growing embryo. It is found in sporangium, particularly within the anther of flowering plants. It is important for the development of pollen grains. The cells are usually bigger and normally have more than one nucleus per cell.
  • Sporogenous tissues are diploid in nature.
  • Endothecium - secretes materials essential for the proper maturation of the pollen grains.
  • Intine is the inner layer; outer tough layer of pollen is called as exine.
Which of the following fruit is produced by parthenocarpy?

Banana is produced by parthenocarpy.

Banana does not produce viable seeds and usually depends on asexual modes of reproduction. It thus, commonly produces fruits without any seeds and are called parthenocarpic. Naturally, mango lemon and apple donot produce parthenocarpic fruits.
Seed formation without fertilization in flowering plants involves the process of:

Seed formation without fertilization in flowering plants involves the process of apomixis. 

  • Although seeds, in general, are the products of fertilization, a few flowering plants such as Asteraceae and grasses, have evolved this special mechanism.
  • An apomixis is a form of asexual reproduction that mimics sexual reproduction. It includes abnormal sexual reproduction in which egg or other cells like synergids and antipodals develop into an embryo without fertilization and meiosis.

Adventitious roots develop from Pericycle or interfascicular parenchyma.

Roots produced other than radicle are called adventitious roots. These are formed from pericycle or interfascicular cambium.

Rewards and attractants are required for Entomophily.

Entomophily is the pollination where the insects carry the pollen from the anther to stigma of the flower. In order to sustain the animal visit the flower serve nectar and pollen grain as rewards.

A dioecious flowering plant prevents Autogamy and geitonogamy.

  • Autogamy is pollination by transfer of pollen grains from the anther of a flower to the stigma of the same flower.
  • Geitonogamy is pollination by transfer of pollen grains from the anther of a flower to the stigma of another flower of the same plant. 
  • A plant having unisexual flowers is said to be dioecious. Such a flower will neither exhibit autogamy nor geitonogamy.
If an endosperm cell of an angiosperm contains 24 chromosomes, the number of chromosomes in each cell of the root will be:

In seed plants, the endosperm is the tissue that surrounds and nourishes the embryo.

Endosperm is triploid in nature i.e., 3n.

3n = 24 then,

n = \(\frac{24}{3}\) = 8

Each cell of the root structure represents the diploid condition in the plants i.e., 2n.

2n = 2 × 8 = 16

So, the number of chromosome in root cell is 16.
The cells of endosperm have 24 chromosomes. What will be the number of chromosomes in the gametes?

In angiosperms, endosperm is a triploid structure.

∴ 3n = 24 (given), then n = 8

As gametes are haploid structures, therefore number of chromosomes in gametes will be 8.
The true embryo develops as a result of fusion of:

The true embryo develops as a result of fusion of Egg cell and male gamete.

In double fertilisation out of the two male gametes one fuses with egg or oosphere to perform generative fertilisation. Generative fertilisation is also called syngamy or true fertilisation. It gives rise to a diploid zygote or oospore.
Father of Indian embryology is:

Father of Indian embryology is P. Maheshwari.

Panchanan Maheswari was a prominent Indian botanist noted chiefly for his invention of the technique of test-tube fertilization of angiosperms.
The portion of embryonal axis between plumule(future shoot) and cotyledons is called ___________.

The portion of embryonal axis between plumule(future shoot) and cotyledons is called Epicotyl.

  • Hypocotyl is actually a transition zone which is present between the shoot and the root. This actually represents the stem of a germinating seedling which follows the cotyledon. It is present above the radical. 
  • Epicotyl is the part of the embryonic axis which is present between the plumule and the cotyledons. Plumule is the upper terminal part of the embryo and the lower part of the embryo is radical.
  • Coleorhiza is a which protects the root of the germinating grain. It is a protective layer which is present around the root.
  • Coleoptile is a pointed shaped protective layer which covers the imaging shoot of the monocotyledons. It has contains two vascular bundles on either sides.
Coleorhiza and coleoptile are the protective sheaths covering _______ and ______ respectively.

Coleorhiza and coleoptile are the protective sheaths covering Radicle and Plumule respectively.

The epicotyl bearing shoot apex and leaf primordia are enclosed in a foliar structure called coleoptile. It protects the plumule during emergence from the soil.

The radicle is protected in a sheath called coleorhiza. It protects the radicle during its passage into the soil.
________ is not an endospermic seed.

Pea is not an endospermic seed.

Endosperm represents the food storing tissue of a seed. It is produced as a result of double fertilisation in angiosperms. In most monocots and some dicot seeds, the food reserve remains in the endosperm. They are called endospermic or albuminous seeds, e.g., maize, wheat, castor bean, coconut, barley, rubber. However, in the majority of dicot seeds(e.g., orchids, Sagittaria), the endosperm is consumed during seed development and the food is stored in cotyledons and other regions. They are called non endospermic or exalbuminous seeds.
Endosperm is completely consumed by the developing embryo in:

Endosperm is completely consumed by the developing embryo in Pea and groundnut.

Endosperm is completely consumed by developing embryo in the seed and the food reserve gets stored in the cotyledons. Such seeds are called non-endospermic or exalbuminous. Example- Pea and groundnut.

And in some seeds the endosperm persists to the mature seed stage as a storage tissue. These seeds are called endospermous or albuminous . Example- Maize and castor.

Pollen grain is a Microspore.

  • Pollen grains and microspores are the same things.
  • Microspores are found in land plants. These are small in structure.
  • Microspores undergo microsporogenesis to develop themselves. When a favorable condition arises, microspores develop into pollen grains.
How many pollen mother cells should undergo meiotic division to produce 64 pollen grains?

16 pollen mother cells should undergo meiotic division to produce 64 pollen grains.

Each pollen mother cell(PMC), by a meiotic division, gives rise to a group of four haploid microspores. Thus, 16 pollen mother cells undergo meiotic divisions to produce 64 pollen grains.
The innate tendency of offspring to resemble their parents is called :
The innate tendency of offspring to resemble their parents is called heredity. The offspring resembles to parent due to same genetic combination inherited from parents.

Genotype is the genetic combination of an individual. TT and Tt are genotypically different but phenotypically appear tall. In a broad sense, the term "genotype" refers to the genetic makeup of an organism; in other words, it describes an organism's complete set of genes.
Who is regarded as the father of genetics?

Mendel is regarded as the father of genetics due to his initial law of inheritance given by him on the basis of Hybridisation conducted by him on garden pea. Gregor Mendel's work in pea led to our understanding of the foundational principles of inheritance.
Hugo de Vries did his experiments on the plant :
Hugo de Vries did his genetic experiments with Oenothera lamarkiana (evening primrose) and gave the "theory of mutation".

The chiasmata formation occurs during diplotene phase of prophase I of meiosis I. Chiasmata are the points of attachment between non-sister chromatids of two homologous chromosomes. It leads to an exchange of segments and creates variation.

Monosomy is absence of a single chromosome from a diploid cell (2n-1). Nullisomy is absence of one complete pair of homologous chromosomes (2n-2). Presence of one chromosome four times is called tetrasomy (2n+2). A diploid cell with an extra chromosome is trisomic (2n+1)
A pregnant woman who has undergone amniocentesis test, finds an extra Barr body in her embryo. The syndrome which is likely to be associated with embryo is :

A pregnant woman who has undergone amniocentesis test, finds an extra Barr body in her embryo. The syndrome which is likely to be associated with embryo is Klinefelter's syndrome.

Klinefelter syndrome is a sex chromosome disorder in boys and men that results from the presence of an extra X chromosome in cells. The presence of an extra Barr body is due to the presence of an extra X chromosome.
"Gametes are never hybrid". It is a statement of law of :

According to Mendel’s monohybrid cross, during gamete formation, the alleles for each gene segregate from each other so that each gamete carries only one allele for each gene. It is called the Law of Segregation.
In cell of superfemale with 47 chromosomes ( 44 + XXX ) visible barr bodies are-

Barr body is the dense and inactive structure which is formed during embryonic development in females.

Number of barr body = (No. of X chromosomes-1)

For eg- In human female, no. of chromosomes is 2A + XX : therefore, No. of barr body will be 2-1 =1

No. of barr body in 44 + XXX (superfemale) will be 3-1 = 2
Sex influenced characters are due to which of the following genes?

The 22 pairs of chromosomes which are totally the same in male and female are known as autosomes and the genes present on them are called autosomal genes.

Sex influenced genes and sex limited genes are located on autosomes. While sex linked genes are located on X and Y chromosomes.
In man, sperms contain autosomes and allosomes, then which of the following as allosomes?
Human males are composed of 22 pairs of autosomes and last allosome XY. Thus, in haploid gamete there will be 22 autosomes and either X or Y.
According to the question, Drosophila is having 2 X chromosomes and 3 autosomes which make the X/A ratio 0.66 (between 1 and 0.50) i.e., intersex genotype.

In genetics, a test cross, first introduced by Gregor Mendel, involves the breeding of a dominant trait individual with a recessive individual, in order to determine the zygosity of the former by analysing proportions of offspring with the recessive phenotype. It checks heterozygosity in F1 generation.
The functional unit of mutation is a :
Muton is the smallest hereditary element that can be altered by mutation. It is the functional unit of mutation.

In pedigree analysis, normal male and normal females are represented by "square" and "circle" respectively. The affected male and affected females are represented by "shaded square" and "shaded circle" respectively.
Which of the following types of mutations occurs the most frequently?

The most frequent sort of mutation is a forward mutation, in which the normal or wild type of gene transforms into a new genotype that may be dominant or recessive. A forward mutation is a genetic change from a wild-type to a mutant allele or the generation of a new mutation from a wild-type allele. New qualities in the population evolve as a result of the forward mutation.
Which of the following chemicals can cause mutations in both replicating and non-replicating DNA?

Nitrous acid is a chemical mutagen that can induce mutations in both replicating and non-replicating DNA. It is capable of converting adenine bases in DNA to hypoxanthine bases. This alteration disrupts the normal base pairing of adenine with thymine during replication, leading to hypoxanthine pairing with cytosine instead. Additionally, strong mutagens like acridines can cause frameshift or gibberish mutations. Overall, numerous compounds exhibit mutagenic properties and can result in various types of mutations.
Which of the following techniques may be used to identify an inheritance pattern within a family?

Pedigree analysis, a method of researching human genetic illnesses, may be used to track the pattern of inheritance of Mendelian disorders that are passed down to offspring in accordance with Mendelian principles.
When is it possible for a woman to be colorblind?
The father has normal vision and the mother is a carrier
The father has normal vision and the mother is colorblind
The father is colorblind and the mother has a normal vision
The father is colorblind and the mother is a carrier

A girl can only be colorblind under two circumstances: i. when her father is colorblind and her mother carries the disease; ii. when both her father and mother are colorblind.

So, for a girl to be colorblind, her father must likewise be colorblind.
How many sickle cell genotypes are there in the population?

In a population, sickle cell anemia can occur in three different genotypes. These are

  • HbA HbA: Regular people
  • HbA HbS: Healthy people who transmit the illness by acting as carriers;
  • HbS HbS: People who have the disease but don’t reach adulthood.
Which of the following is a cause of thalassemia?

A series of diseases collectively referred to as thalassemia are caused by a deficiency in the production of globin polypeptide in RBC. The excess of other globin chains that build up in our bodies and cause various illnesses result from the absence or diminished synthesis of one of the globin chains.
Which of the following claims would be accurate if garden pea plants from Mendel’s garden were sampled?
Round seeds were more prevalent than wrinkled seeds
Wrinkled seeds were more prevalent than round seeds
Both round and wrinkled seeds were equally prevalent
The response depended on the time of day the sample was taken
Even when a recessive allele is present, the dominant allele can still express. Thus, dominant phenotypes are more prevalent. Because round seeds outnumber wrinkled seeds, they would be more common.
Which of the following characteristics is not a result of Mendel’s research?
Creation of a trustworthy and relevant data source

Mendel studied a huge sample of pea plants using the reliable scientific method as well as mathematical and statistical tools, making his findings unique in their field. He also established a trustworthy and respectable data source that may be used regularly to draw conclusions. Furthermore, his methods required taking care of the model organism at hand and were ethical even by today’s standards.
Which of the following is not a pair of opposing characteristics Mendel studied?

Mendel examined seven pairs of opposing features during his investigations. These comprised terminal flowers, full and constricted pods, axial and yellow pods, as well as green and yellow pods. Violet and white were the two floral colors that were examined.
The type of inheritance in which a single gene controls a trait and the dominant allele masks the recessive allele is known as:

A person with one dominant allele and one recessive allele is referred to as a heterozygote in dominant-recessive inheritance, whereas a person with two copies of the same allele is referred to as a homozygote.
Identify which of the following mode of inheritance is represented by the given statement, "One of the Mendelian ideas is depicted by a cross in which the F1 generation resembles both parents"?

In codominance, two alleles express themselves independently when present together. Therefore, the offspring resembles both parents. Codominance is a type of inheritance in which two versions (alleles) of the same gene are expressed separately to yield different traits in an individual. That is, instead of one trait being dominant over the other, both traits appear, such as in a plant or animal that has more than one pigment color.
If we cross two heterozygous individuals, the percentage of offspring with recessive phenotype will be:

A monohybrid cross is a cross between two individuals with different alleles at one genetic locus. If we cross two heterozygous individuals (Aa), then the percentage of offspring with recessive phenotype will be:

Aa × Aa = AA Aa Aa aa, so recessive phenotypes would be 14= 25%.
What is the name of the phenomenon in which the expression of a trait is influenced by the environment rather than solely by the genotype?

The term "epigenetics" describes changes in gene expression that do not result from modifications to the underlying DNA sequence. Instead, these alterations happen because DNA or the proteins and other molecules that interact with DNA to regulate gene expression have been altered.
Identify, which of the following is the best example of pleiotropy?

Sickle cell anemia is an example of a pleiotropic gene because here the mutation in the single gene carries out several changes throughout the body and affects the body in different ways. Here mutation occurs in only HBB genes.
Which one of the following is an example for X-linked chromosome inheritance?

Colour blindness is a colour vision deficiency. It is the defect in seeing colour or differences in colour. It is diagnosed with by Ishihara colour test or by any genetic testing.

Till date, there is no cure for colour blindness. X-chrome lens is a special type of lens that helps people with red-green colour blindness in bright light.
Which of the following forest plants controls the light conditions at the ground?
Tall trees control the light conditions at the ground.
What will happen to a well growing herbaceous plant in the forest if it is transplanted outside the forest in a park?
It will grow well because it is planted in the same locality.
It may not survive because of change in its micro climate.
It grows very well because the plant gets more sunlight.
A well growing herbaceous plant in the forest if it is transplanted outside the forest in a park. It may not survive because of change in its micro climate.
If a population of 50 paramoecium present in a pool increases to 150 after an hour, what would be the growth rate of population?

Initial population of paramecium Pi = 50

After one hour population of paramecium Pf = 150

Growth rate after one hour = Pf – Pi

= 150-50= 100
A population has more young individuals compared to the older individuals. What would be the status of the population after some years?
It will first decline and then stabilise
A population has more young individuals compared to the older individuals. It will increase the status of the population after some years.
What parameters are used for tiger census in our country’s national parks and sanctuaries?

Sometimes population size is indirectly estimated without actually counting them or seeing them. E.g. ; The tiger census in our National Parks and Tiger Reserves is often based on pug marks and faceal pellets.
Which of the following would necessarily decrease the density of a population in a given habitat?
Mortality and emigration would necessarily decrease the density of a population in a given habitat.
A protozoan reproduces by binary fission. What will be the number of protozoans in its population after six generations?
What are the populations of the different species which live and interact together in the ecosystem called?

A group of populations is known as a community. It is a group of people who share the same place or live within the same area. These people may share common characteristics. It is the organizational level between population and ecosystems.
What are the interactions between organisms in a community called?

The interactions between organisms in a community are called biological interaction. They may include organisms of the same species or different species. The interactions between organisms are essential for survival and the proper functioning of the ecosystem.
What are the modifications of the organisms living on the land for their survival called?

The modifications of the organisms living on the land for their survival called terrestrial adaptations. It is exhibited by all organisms, plants as well as animals. These adaptations are for various biological activities.
Which of the following is an adaptation for running?
