The adaptation for running is known as cursorial adaptation. It is an adaptation for fast running to find hiding places for protection from various predators. Some examples of cursorial animals are deer, horse, cockroach, leopard, etc.
What is an adaptation for climbing and balancing called?

The adaptation for climbing and balancing is known as arboreal adaptation. It is also known as scansorial adaptation. It is used by animals for climbing on trees, rocks, walls, etc. This type of adaptation is shown by monkeys, sloths, chameleons, koalas, etc.
Which among the following is a characteristic of arboreal adaptation?

Hind limbs provided with longer toes are a characteristic of arboreal adaptation. Along with this arboreal animals have a long prehensile tail (monkeys) with strong and stout limbs. They also have opposable digits (marsupials) and elongated claws (squirrels).
Which among the following has adapted for arboreal adaptation?
Monkey is an example of arboreal adaptation. It has strong and stout limbs, long prehensile tail along with opposable digits. Because of these adaptations they can easily climb on trees, walls.
Nt defines the population density at time t. The death rate, birth rate, immigration, and emigration are the factors influencing population density.
Who does a pilot fish accompanies for feeding on falling pieces of food?

The pilot fish accompanies a shark for feeding on falling pieces of food. It may also accompany rays or turtles. It is an example of commensalism in which pilot fish gains food without harming another organism.
What is a relationship between organisms of different species where an organism is benefited and other is harmed called?

A relationship between organisms of different species where an organism is benefited and other is harmed is known as parasitism. The organism which is benefited is known as parasite while the harmed one is called the host.
What is a relationship in which larval development of one organism occurs inside or on the surface of another organism resulting in the death of the host called?

Parasitism is a close relationship between species, where one organism, the parasite, lives on or inside another organism, the host, causing it some harm, and is adapted structurally to this way of life.
What is an organism carrying another organism to the host called?

The organism carrying another organism to the host is called a vector. A vector itself does not cause disease but transfers the pathogen to host. Some major vectors are plasmids, cosmids, viral vectors, and artificial chromosomes.
A female anopheles mosquito is a vector that transmits the malaria-causing protozoan called Plasmodium. Anopheles gambiae is one of the best-known vectors that transmit Plasmodium falciparum.
In which the organism’s abdomen does Sacculina live?

Sacculina is a genus of barnacles that resides inside the gut of a crab. It is a parasite that shows adverse effects on crabs such as it hinders the normal metabolism of crab and also reduces its reproduction capacity.
What is a relationship in which one parasite feeds on another parasite which in turn feeds on its host called?

A relationship in which one parasite feeds on another parasite which in turn feed on its host is called epi-parasite. These are also known as secondary or hyper parasites. An example is a bacterium in an insect’s gut that feeds on cattle.
What is a protozoan living in the digestive tract of a flea living on a dog is an example of?

A protozoan living in the digestive tract of a flea living on a dog is an example of Hyper-parasitism. It is also known as secondary or epi-parasite. It is a relationship in which one parasite feeds on another parasite which in turn feeds on its host.
Which of the following is a S-shaped growth curve?

The logistic growth curve is also known as the sigmoid / S-shaped growth curve. It is considered to be a realistic curve. It is obtained due to the finite and limited source of resources in a population. It is also called a Verhulst-Pearl Logistic Growth curve.
Which shape does the exponential growth curve show?
An exponential growth is observed when resources in the population are unlimited. The population grows in geometric fashion and results in a J-shaped curve.
In which phase is the stationary phase absent?

The stationary phase is absent in exponential growth. Exponential growth is observed when resources in the population are unlimited. The population grows in geometric fashion and results in a J-shaped curve.
In which growth the environmental resistance suddenly occurs?
The environmental resistance suddenly occurs in exponential growth. In this, there is no stationary phase and population density shows a sudden crash due to environmental resistance.
Under special conditions which factor is responsible for influencing population density?

Under special conditions, immigration is responsible for fluctuating population density. It is an act of coming into a different country of which they are not natives and reside permanently. This increases the population density of an area where they are residing.
At what year is the census carried?
Census is carried out every 10 years. Population census is the process of collecting, compiling, analyzing demographic, economic and social data about the members of a given population.
What does the leaving of individuals from a population and moving out said?
An emigration is an act of leaving one’s own country and settling or residing in another country (abroad) permanently. The population density decreases when emigration is more.
'Homo erectus' is the zoological name of:

Java Ape Man was one of the first specimens of Homo erectus to be discovered. Eugene Dubois originally gave it the scientific name Pithecanthropus erectus. Later, Java ape-man was redesignated as Homo erectus.
Theory of spontaneous generation was supported by:

The theory of spontaneous creation was supported by Van Helmont. Van Helmont conducted an experiment involving placing a dirty shirt and grains of wheat in an open-mouthed jar, which he believed would give rise to mice. He observed the appearance of mice in the jar and attributed their generation to spontaneous generation, the idea that living organisms could arise spontaneously from non-living matter.
Which of the following is a ''living fossil''?

Limulus, also known as the horseshoe crab, is often referred to as a "living fossil." This is because Limulus species have existed relatively unchanged for hundreds of millions of years, making them excellent examples of organisms that have retained many primitive features over evolutionary time.
Which of these are correct regarding the evolution of animals?
Lobefins were ancestors of modern-day frogs and salamanders
Reptiles of same shapes and sizes evolved

Lobefins, specifically lobe-finned fish or Sarcopterygii, are indeed ancestors of modern-day amphibians, including frogs and salamanders. These early lobefin fishes evolved into tetrapods, which were the first vertebrates to colonize land and eventually gave rise to amphibians.
Which of the following is related to homology?

Homology refers to the similarity in structures, genes, or traits between different species that are derived from a common ancestor. These similarities suggest that the organisms share a common evolutionary history and have diverged from a common ancestral form. Homologous structures often perform different functions in different species but share a similar underlying anatomy, indicating their evolutionary relationship. Divergent evolution occurs when related species evolve different traits due to adapting to different environmental conditions or ecological niches, resulting in the formation of homologous structures with diverse functions. Therefore, homology reflects the process of divergent evolution, where ancestral traits are modified over time to adapt to different environments while retaining their underlying structural similarity.
Which of the following did not originate during the Triassic period?

Apes did not originate during the Triassic period. The earliest primates, from which apes eventually evolved, emerged much later, during the Paleocene epoch, which followed the extinction of the dinosaurs and marked the beginning of the Cenozoic era. Therefore, oviparous prototheria (mammals that lay eggs), mammals, and dinosaurs all have their origins or significant evolutionary developments during the Triassic period, apes appeared much later in geological history.
Which of the following is a vestigial organ in humans?

The vermiform appendix is a vestigial organ in humans. It is a small, finger-like projection located at the junction of the small and large intestines. While the appendix may have had a digestive function in the evolutionary ancestors of humans, it is now considered to have little or no significant function in modern humans. Despite its vestigial nature, the appendix can become inflamed, resulting in a condition known as appendicitis, which may require surgical removal.
Evolution of toothed birds occurred about ______ crore years ago.

Toothed birds, such as Archaeopteryx, which possessed teeth along with feathers and other bird-like features, appeared during the Late Jurassic period, approximately 150 to 148 million years ago. Converted into crore years, this timeframe would be approximately 5.4 to 5.9 crore years ago.

Which of the following is evidence of Evolution?

1. Fossil remains

2. Embryological support

3. Homology

4. Similarities in proteins and genes

Select the correct answer using the code given below.

Fossil remains, embryological support, homology and similarities in proteins and genes all are evidence of evolution. 

Fossils provide direct evidence of past life forms and evolutionary changes over time. By studying fossils, scientists can trace the evolution of various organisms and document transitions between different species.

Comparative embryology involves studying the developmental stages of different organisms to identify similarities and differences. 

Homology indicates descent from a common ancestor and provides evidence of evolutionary relationships.

Molecular biology has revealed striking similarities in DNA sequences and protein structures among different species. These molecular homologies support the concept of common ancestry and evolutionary relationships between organisms.
What occurred during the Cretaceous period of animal evolution?

The Cretaceous period, which occurred approximately 145 to 66 million years ago, ended with one of the most significant events in Earth's history: the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction event. This event, which marks the boundary between the Cretaceous and Paleogene periods, resulted in the mass extinction of many groups of organisms, including non-avian dinosaurs. While dinosaurs had evolved earlier during the Mesozoic Era and were prominent during the Cretaceous period, they became extinct at the end of the Cretaceous period. So, extinction of dinosaurs accurately reflects a major occurrence during the Cretaceous period of animal evolution.
Forelimbs of frog and lizard are the example of the __________ organs.

Forelimbs of frog and lizard are homologous organs. Homologous structures are anatomical features in different species that share a common evolutionary origin, despite potentially serving different functions. In this case, the forelimbs of frogs and lizards have similar skeletal structures, indicating a common ancestry despite their different functions (e.g., hopping in frogs and walking/crawling in lizards). Therefore, homologous accurately describes the relationship between the forelimbs of frog and lizard.
The absence of oxygen in the earth, made the atmosphere reduce. But it later became oxidizing in nature due to the emergence of ________.

Cyanobacteria, also known as blue-green algae, played a crucial role in the Earth's early atmosphere. These ancient photosynthetic organisms were among the first organisms to perform oxygenic photosynthesis, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. Over time, the accumulation of oxygen in the atmosphere led to the oxidation of Earth's atmosphere, transforming it from a reducing to an oxidizing environment. Therefore, the emergence of cyanobacteria contributed significantly to the oxygenation of the Earth's atmosphere.
The wings of an insect and a bird are an example of:

The wings of an insect and a bird are considered analogous organs. Analogous structures are anatomical features in different species that have similar functions but evolved independently, rather than from a common ancestor. Insects and birds belong to different evolutionary lineages, and their wings have evolved separately in response to similar environmental pressures, namely, the need for flight. Despite their different anatomical structures and developmental origins, the wings of insects and birds serve the same function: enabling flight.
What evolved during Oligocene epoch of animal evolution?

The Oligocene epoch, which occurred approximately 33.9 to 23 million years ago, was a period marked by significant evolutionary developments among mammals. One of the notable evolutionary events during this epoch was the emergence and diversification of anthropoid apes.

Anthropoid apes are a group of primates that includes gibbons, orangutans, gorillas, chimpanzees, and humans. These primates share a number of anatomical and behavioral characteristics, including a relatively large brain size, forward-facing eyes, and grasping hands with opposable thumbs. The Oligocene epoch saw the early ancestors of modern anthropoid apes evolve and begin to diversify, setting the stage for further evolutionary developments leading to the emergence of modern apes and humans.
Surgically removing the tails of mice over several generations does not yield mice without tails. This proves that _______.
Cutting tail does not cause genetic change. So it is not inherited.
Acquired characters during one's own life are not inherited

Surgically removing the tails of mice over several generations does not yield mice without tails. There is no way of cutting tails can change the genetic pattern of the mice. Besides tails, in mice, is an inherited trait. It is passed on from one generation to another through genetic factors. So cutting tail cannot be considered as an acquired character as mice do not naturally acquire it, but it is done in lab conditions.
Humans appeared during which of the following epoch?

Humans, specifically Homo sapiens, appeared during the Pleistocene epoch. The Pleistocene epoch, also known as the Ice Age, occurred approximately 2.6 million to 11,700 years ago. It is during this epoch that anatomically modern humans evolved and began to spread across the world. While earlier hominin species existed prior to Homo sapiens, it was during the Pleistocene that Homo sapiens emerged and eventually became the dominant hominin species.
Which of the following is not a characteristic of Dryopithecus?

Meat eater is not a characteristic of Dryopithecus. They are not typically characterized as a meat-eating primate. Instead, it is believed to have been primarily herbivorous or omnivorous, with a diet consisting mainly of fruits, leaves, and other plant materials.
What was the most significant trend, in the evolution of modern man (Homo sapiens), from his ancestors?

One of the most significant trends in the evolution of modern humans (Homo sapiens) from their ancestors is the increase in brain capacity. Over the course of human evolution, there has been a notable enlargement of the brain relative to body size. This increase in brain size is associated with the development of higher cognitive functions, such as problem-solving, language, and social complexity, which have been crucial to the success and adaptability of Homo sapiens as a species.
Ramapithecus and Shivapithecus were discovered from which place in India?

Ramapithecus and Shivapithecus were discovered from the Shivalik hills in India. These fossil finds are significant in the study of human evolution as they represent extinct hominids or hominoid species that lived during the Miocene epoch. The Shivalik hills, also known as the Outer Himalayas, are a mountain range spanning several states in northern India, where numerous important fossil sites have been discovered.

The extinct human who lived 1,00,000 to 40,000 years ago in Europe, Asia and parts of Africa, with short stature, heavy eyebrows, retreating foreheads, large jaws with heavy teeth, stocky bodies, a lumbering gait and stooped posture was:

Neanderthals were an extinct species of humans who lived in Europe, Asia, and parts of Africa approximately 100,000 to 40,000 years ago. They are characterized by several distinctive physical features, including short stature, heavy eyebrows, retreating foreheads, large jaws with heavy teeth, stocky bodies, a lumbering gait, and a stooped posture. Neanderthals were well-adapted to the cold climates of the Pleistocene epoch and were skilled hunters and toolmakers. They coexisted with early modern humans (Homo sapiens) for a period of time before eventually becoming extinct.
What is another name of human evolution?

Anthropogenesis is another term for human evolution. It refers to the process by which modern humans (Homo sapiens) evolved from earlier hominin ancestors over millions of years. Anthropogenesis encompasses the study of the anatomical, physiological, behavioral, and cultural changes that occurred within the human lineage throughout evolutionary history.
Which of the following is not among the characters of Homo habilis?
Their fossils were discovered by Dr. Leakey
They were found in 2 million years old rocks in Africa
The dental formula was different from man

Homo habilis, an early species of the genus Homo, is known for several characteristics, but having a different dental formula from modern humans is not one of them. Instead, Homo habilis is characterized by its smaller brain size compared to later Homo species, its use of primitive stone tools, and its bipedal locomotion.
Which of the following does not belong to Homo erectus?

Cro-Magnon man represents one of the earliest known populations of anatomically modern humans, who lived in Europe during the Upper Paleolithic period, approximately 40,000 to 10,000 years ago. They are characterized by their skeletal anatomy, which is virtually indistinguishable from that of modern humans, and their advanced tool-making abilities, art, and symbolic behavior.

Homo erectus, on the other hand, is an extinct species of early human that lived from approximately 1.9 million to 70,000 years ago. Homo erectus is known for its robust build, large brow ridges, and relatively primitive stone tool technology. They were widespread across Africa, Asia, and parts of Europe.

Therefore, Cro-Magnon man (early modern humans) and Homo erectus are separate and distinct species within the human evolutionary lineage.
Who among Homo erectus used fire for hunting, protection, and cooking?

Java Man, also known as Homo erectus erectus, is associated with the use of fire for various purposes, including hunting, protection, and cooking. Homo erectus populations, including those represented by Java Man, are believed to have been among the earliest hominins to control and utilize fire.
Who started doing agriculture during human evolution?

Modern man accurately identifies the group associated with the adoption and development of agriculture during human evolution. The transition to agriculture began during the Neolithic period, which occurred after the emergence of anatomically modern humans (Homo sapiens sapiens). While earlier hominin species, including Homo erectus and Neanderthals, engaged in hunting and gathering activities, it was modern humans who started practicing agriculture.

The shift from hunting and gathering to agriculture marked a significant milestone in human history, leading to settled societies, the development of complex civilizations, and major changes in human lifestyles and societies.

There are two opposing views about origin of modern man. According to one view Homo erectus in Asia were the ancestors of modern man. A study of variation of DNA however, suggested African origin of modern man. What kind of observation on DNA variation could suggest this?
Greater variation in Asia than in Africa
Greater variation in Africa than in Asia
Variation only in Asia and no variation in Africa

If the study of DNA variation suggests a similar level of variation in both African and Asian populations, it supports the idea that modern humans originated in Africa rather than Asia. This is because greater genetic diversity is typically expected in populations that have been established for a longer period of time. Since Africa is believed to be the birthplace of Homo sapiens, populations there would have had more time to accumulate genetic diversity compared to populations in other regions. So, similar levels of genetic variation in both Africa and Asia would support the hypothesis of an African origin of modern humans.
Which of the following is correct order of evolutionary history of man?
Peking man, Neanderthal, Homo sapiens, Heidelberg man

Peking man, Heidelberg man, Neanderthal, Cro-Magnon correctly reflects the general order of evolutionary history of humans.

Peking man (Homo erectus pekinensis): Peking man lived in China during the Middle Pleistocene, approximately 700,000 to 200,000 years ago.

Heidelberg man (Homo heidelbergensis): Heidelberg man lived in Africa, Europe, and possibly Asia during the Middle Pleistocene, approximately 600,000 to 200,000 years ago.

Neanderthals (Homo neanderthalensis): Neanderthals lived in Europe and parts of Asia during the Late Pleistocene, approximately 400,000 to 40,000 years ago.

Cro-Magnon (early Homo sapiens sapiens): Cro-Magnon refers to early anatomically modern humans who lived in Europe during the Upper Paleolithic period, approximately 40,000 to 10,000 years ago.
Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Australopithecus?

They essentially ate fruits accurately describes the dietary habits associated with Australopithecus .Australopithecus is believed to have been primarily herbivorous or omnivorous, with a diet consisting mainly of fruits, leaves, and other plant materials. There is evidence from dental morphology and stable isotope analysis that supports the idea that Australopithecus species consumed a significant amount of plant-based foods.
Which fossil of the ape was known as the connecting link between apes and man?

Australopithecus is often referred to as the "connecting link" between apes and humans because of its combination of ape-like and human-like features. Fossils of Australopithecus provide important insights into the evolutionary transition from ancestral apes to early humans.
Common origin of man and chimpanzee is best shown by:

The common origin of humans and chimpanzees is best demonstrated by similarities in their genetic material. Chromosomes are structures within cells that contain genetic information in the form of DNA. Humans and chimpanzees share a high degree of genetic similarity, and specific regions of their genomes, including chromosome numbers 3 and 6, exhibit similar banding patterns when analyzed.

By comparing the banding patterns of chromosomes in humans and chimpanzees, scientists can identify shared genetic features that support the hypothesis of a common evolutionary origin between the two species.
Which of the following processes is not involved in the industrial utilisation of microbes?

Demagnetisation process is not involved in the industrial utilisation of microbes.

Industrial utilisation of bacteria and other microbes involves three processes- laboratory-scale process, pilot plant scale and manufacturing unit. The development from the laboratory scale to the manufacturing unit is called as scaling up.
Which of the following is the container where fermentation is carried out?
The container where fermentation is carried out is called a bioreactor. It has an aeration system, pH correctors and temperature adjustors. Bioreactors are often large.
Added on the surface of the nutrient medium

Microorganisms are added in bioreactors in three ways:

i. Added on the surface of the nutrient medium

ii. Suspended in a nutrient medium

iii. Placed in calcium alginate beads
Who found out that beer and buttermilk are produced due to the activity of Yeast?
Louis Pasteur found for the first time that beer and buttermilk are produced due to the activity of yeast and yeast-like organisms. Saccharomyces cerevisiae is the most common yeast used.
What is the common name of Saccharomyces ellipsoidens?

Saccharomyces ellipsoidens is commonly known as wine yeast. Brewer’s yeast, Sake yeast and Ale yeast are known as Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Saccharomyces sake and Saccharomyces piriformis respectively.
What is the nutrient medium for beer?
The nutrient medium for beer is barley malt. Fermented cereals, molasses and juices are the nutrient medium for whisky, rum and wine respectively.
Which of the following is not a process of fermentation?
Fermentation occurs in 3 ways- batch process, continuous process and feed batch process. Feed batch process is an intermediate process between batch and continuous processes.
What is the alcohol content in beer?
In the case of beer, the fermented liquor has an alcohol content of 3-6%. The alcohol content is 10-27% in wines, 60-70% in brandy and 95% in rectified spirit.
What are the by-products of alcoholic fermentation?

The by-products of alcoholic fermentation are CO2 and ethanol. Several other chemicals can be formed with the change of nutritive medium, pH and aeration like n-propanol, butanol, glycerol, acetic acid, pyruvic acid, succinic acid, lactic acid, caproic acid, ethyl acetate etc.
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding beer?
Beer is allowed to age before pasteurisation
Beer contains 3-6% alcohol. Nutrient medium is barley. Beer is allowed to age before pasteurisation. Large beer is prepared by carrying out ageing in the cold.

The term antibiotics was coined by Waksman in 1942. Clinically, an antibiotic is a substance produced by a microorganism which is in low concentration and inhibits the growth and metabolic activity of pathogenic organisms without harming the host.
Who was the first person to discover an antibiotic?

The first antibiotic is generally associated with the name of Alexander Fleming when he discovered Penicillin from Penicillium notatum in 1928. Penicillium notatum did not allow the growth of Staphylococcus aureus.
Which of the following is not the characteristic of a good antibiotic?
Ability to destroy all the microflora in the alimentary canal of the host
A good antibiotic is harmless to host with no side effects, harmless to normal microflora of the alimentary canal of the host, Ability to destroy all strains of the pathogen and has a quick action.
From which of the following species an antibiotic is generally not obtained?

Antibiotics are generally obtained from lichens, fungi, eubacteria and actinomycetes. Over 7000 antibiotics are known. Every year some 300 new antibiotics are discovered using hypersensitive microorganisms.
Which of the following is a common antibiotic obtained from lichens?
The common antibiotics obtained from lichens is usnic acid from Usnea and Cladonia. Fungi yield several antibiotics like penicillin, polyporin, clavacin, clitocybin, etc.
Chemicals which influence the functioning of the living system
Chemicals which help in the feedback mechanism
Bioactive substances are those chemicals which influence the functioning of a living system and elicit a response for the same. E.g., statins, cyclosporine, streptokinase, lectins, etc.
Which of the following is the first organic acid produced through fermentation?
Lactic acid was the first organic acid produced through fermentation. It is obtained by the activity of several bacteria like Streptococcus lactis, Lactobacillus bulgaris, etc.
Which of the following organisms is responsible for the production of Citric Acid?
Species of Yeast like Mucor species, Aspergillus niger can ferment sugar to produce citric acid. Citric acid is a preservative and flavouring agent.
Which of the following organic acid is used for providing calcium to the infants?

Gluconic acid is manufactured by the agency of Penicillium purpurogenum, for use as calcium gluconate for providing calcium to infants, lactating mothers and treating milk fever in high milk yielding cows.
Which of the following is a function of pectinases?

Pectinases are obtained from fungi grown on pectin containing media. Pectinases are used in enhancing juice extraction from fruits, clearing of fruit juices, removing bitterness, retting of fibres and fermentation of green coffee.
Which of the following is the function of lipases?
Lipases are lipid digesting enzymes used in flavouring cheese, hydrolysing oils for manufacture of soap and in detergent formulations for removing fat-based stains.
Which of the following is not an industrial product of microbe?

Toddy is not an industrial product of microbes. Microbes are used to synthesise several products valuable to human beings. Some of the industrial products of microbes include antibiotics, bioactive molecules, enzymes, beverages, etc.
Who discovered the full potential of an antibiotic?

The full potential of an antibiotic (Penicillin discovered at that time) was established by Ernest Chain and Howard Florey. This antibiotic was extensively used to treat American soldiers wounded in World War II.
Which of the following organism is used to obtain Streptokinase?

The source of streptokinase is the bacteria Streptococcus. It is modified by genetic engineering and is used as a clot buster for removing clots from the blood vessels of patients who have suffered from myocardial infarction.
What is the full form of TPA?
Streptokinase is also called as Tissue Plasminogen Activator or TPA which is obtained from haemolytic Streptococcus species and modified genetically to be useful in human beings.
Which of the following is used as an immunosuppressant?
Cyclosporin A is used as an immunosuppressant agent in the organ transplant patients and is produced by the fungus Trichoderma polysporum.
What is the major component of waste-water?
A major component of this waste-water is human excreta. This municipal waste-water is also called as sewage. It contains a large amount of organic matter and microbes. Many of which are pathogenic.
Which of the following is not correct regarding the primary treatment of waste-water?
Initially floating debris is removed by distillation
Grit and pebbles are removed by sedimentation
Solids that settle form the primary sludge

In primary treatment, initially floating debris is removed by sequential filtration. Then grit and small pebbles are removed by sedimentation. All solids that settle form the primary sludge while the supernatant forms the effluent.
Where is the major part of sludge pumped in secondary treatment?

In the secondary treatment, a small part of the activated sludge is pumped back into the aeration tank to serve as inoculum. The remaining major part of the sludge is pumped into large anaerobic sludge digesters.
The symbiotic relationship between fungi and roots of higher plants is called:

Mycorrhiza is the symbiosis association between roots of higher plants and fungi. In this association fungal hyphae are found in the roots of higher plants. Both members are benefitted from this association, that's why it is called symbiosis or mutualism.
Which of the following enzymes are used to transcript a portion of the DNA into mRNA?

RNA polymerase is responsible for transcribing DNA into mRNA during the process of transcription. It binds to the promoter region of the DNA and synthesizes an mRNA molecule complementary to the template DNA strand. This enzyme plays a crucial role in gene expression by producing mRNA transcripts that carry genetic information from the DNA to the ribosomes for protein synthesis.
DNA generally acts as a template for the synthesis of:

DNA serves as a template for the synthesis of both RNA and DNA molecules. During transcription, DNA is transcribed into RNA by RNA polymerase. This process produces various types of RNA, including messenger RNA (mRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), and ribosomal RNA (rRNA). Additionally, during DNA replication, DNA serves as a template for the synthesis of a new complementary DNA strand.
Haploid chromosome number is 10. What will be its monosomy?

The haploid chromosome number refers to the total number of chromosomes in a single set of chromosomes in a cell. Monosomy occurs when a cell has only one copy of a particular chromosome instead of the usual two. Since the haploid chromosome number is 10, monosomy would result in a total chromosome count of 2n-1 = 2×10-1=19.
GUG specifies amino acid valine. However, when functioning as initiation codon it specifies _____________.

When serving as the initiation codon, GUG specifies the amino acid methionine, not valine. This process occurs during protein synthesis, where the start codon AUG initiates translation, specifying methionine. Initiation codon codes for that amino acid which is found in meat, fish, and dairy products, and it plays an important role in many cell functions.
Meselson and Stahl used which radio isotopes for their experiment?

Meselson and Stahl's experiment involved the use of the heavy isotope N15 (Nitrogen-15) to label DNA. Initially, they observed that after one round of replication, the DNA molecules exhibited intermediate density, indicating a semi-conservative mode of replication. Subsequent rounds of replication confirmed this pattern, with the proportion of labeled DNA remaining constant at 50%, supporting the semi-conservative replication model.
Which enzyme catalyses the synthesis of DNA from RNA?

Reverse transcriptase is the enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of DNA from RNA. It is commonly found in retroviruses and is used to convert the viral RNA genome into DNA during the process of viral replication. This enzyme plays a crucial role in the retroviral life cycle and is also utilized in laboratory techniques such as reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for the amplification of RNA sequences.
In the absence of Lactose, what is expected to happen according to lac operon model?
Repressor protein binds to the operator site
RNA polymerase interacts with DNA to initiate transcription
β-galactosidase, lactose permease and thiogalactoside transacetylase are synthesized

In the absence of lactose, according to the lac operon model, the repressor protein binds to the operator site on the DNA. This binding prevents RNA polymerase from interacting with the DNA to initiate transcription of the structural genes responsible for encoding enzymes involved in lactose metabolism, such as β-galactosidase, lactose permease, and thiogalactoside transacetylase. As a result, the synthesis of these enzymes is inhibited.
Proof reading enzyme during the synthesis of new bacterial DNA from template DNA is:

Proofreading during the synthesis of new bacterial DNA from template DNA is carried out by DNA polymerase. DNA polymerase has the ability to detect and correct errors in nucleotide base pairing that may occur during DNA replication, ensuring the accuracy of DNA synthesis. This proofreading function helps maintain the integrity of the genetic information passed on to daughter cells.
The number of nucleotides in the gene which code for dystrophin protein is:

The number of nucleotides in the gene which code for dystrophin protein is 2.4 million base pairs. Dystrophin is a rod-shaped protein, measuring about 150 nm, consisting of 3684 amino acids with a calculated molecular weight of 427 kDa.
In sickle cell anaemia due to point mutation, the sixth amino acid, glutamic acid in beta chain of haemoglobin is replaced by:

In sickle cell anemia, the sixth amino acid, glutamic acid, in the beta chain of hemoglobin is replaced by valine due to a point mutation. This mutation causes the hemoglobin molecules to form abnormal, rigid structures, leading to the characteristic sickle-shaped red blood cells. This structural change reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of the affected red blood cells and can cause various complications associated with sickle cell disease.

Barrett's syndrome is a rare form of mental retardation that can be more or less severe depending on the gender of the parent from whom it is inherited. This unusual kind of inheritance pattern is known as:

Brett's syndrome exhibits an inheritance pattern known as genome imprinting, where the severity of the condition varies based on the gender of the parent from whom it is inherited. This phenomenon involves the differential expression of genetic material depending on its parental origin, leading to distinct phenotypic outcomes.
In Prokaryotes, the predominant site for control of gene expression is:
Transfer of mRNA from nucleus to the cytoplasm

In prokaryotes, the predominant site for controlling gene expression is at the level of transcriptional initiation. This process involves the regulation of RNA polymerase binding to the promoter region of DNA, determining whether transcription will proceed or be inhibited. Transcriptional initiation allows prokaryotes to efficiently regulate the synthesis of mRNA and subsequently control the expression of specific genes in response to environmental cues.
The RNA polymerase is only capable of catalyzing the process of:

The RNA polymerase is only capable of catalyzing the process of elongation, where it synthesizes RNA molecules by adding nucleotides to the growing RNA chain. During elongation, RNA polymerase moves along the DNA template strand, unwinding it and synthesizing complementary RNA nucleotides. Initiation involves the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter region, while termination marks the end of transcription.
Which of the following occurs in the process of central dogma reverse?
Conversion of a strand of mRNA to DNA

The reverse process of the central dogma involves reverse transcription, catalyzed by reverse transcriptase, converting viral RNA into DNA. This DNA integrates into the host genome, facilitating viral replication. This mechanism is crucial for retroviruses like HIV to replicate within host cells.
In E. coli lac-operon, an operator gene combines with:
Inducer gene to switch on structural gene action
Inducer gene to switch off structural gene action
Regulator protein (repressor) to switch off structural gene action
Regulator protein to switch on gene action

In E. coli lac-operon, the operator gene combines with the regulator protein (repressor) to switch off structural gene action. This interaction prevents RNA polymerase from transcribing the structural genes responsible for lactose metabolism in the absence of lactose or its inducer molecule. When lactose is present, it binds to the repressor protein, causing a conformational change that releases the operator, allowing RNA polymerase to initiate transcription of the structural genes.
Genetic information is carried out by long chain molecule made up of:

Genetic information is carried out by long chain molecules made up of nucleotides. These nucleotides form the building blocks of nucleic acids like DNA and RNA, which encode the genetic instructions necessary for the development, functioning, growth, and reproduction of all known organisms.
Which of the following ensures the stability of the helical structure of a DNA?
Presence of repetitive structures of a DNA code
Stacking of one base pair over the other

The stability of the helical structure of DNA is ensured by the stacking of one base pair over the other. This stacking interaction, facilitated by the hydrophobic effect and van der Waals forces, helps maintain the integrity of the double helix by minimizing exposure of the hydrophilic bases to the surrounding aqueous environment.
By which bonds the purine & pyrimidine pairs of Complementary Strands of DNA held together?

The purine and pyrimidine pairs of complementary strands of DNA are held together by hydrogen bonds(H-bonds). These hydrogen bonds form between specific pairs of nitrogenous bases: adenine (purine) pairs with thymine (pyrimidine) via two hydrogen bonds, and cytosine (pyrimidine) pairs with guanine (purine) via three hydrogen bonds. This complementary base pairing is essential for maintaining the double helical structure of DNA.
Which of the following is not a part of the nucleotide?

Guanosine is a nucleoside, not a nucleotide. Nucleotides consist of three components: a phosphate group, a nitrogenous base, and a pentose sugar. Guanosine lacks the phosphate group, making it a nucleoside, which is composed of only a nitrogenous base and a pentose sugar.
What is the length of the DNA double helix, if the total number of bp (base pair) is 6.6 x 109?

The length of one complete turn of the DNA double helix, also known as the helical rise per base pair, is approximately 0.34 nanometers(nm). Therefore, to find the length of the entire DNA double helix, we multiply the number of base pairs (\(6.6 \times\) \(10^ 9 \mathrm{bp}\)) by the helical rise per base pair (0.34 nm):

Length \(=\) Number of base pairs \(\times\) Helical rise per base pair = \(6.6 \times 10^9 \mathrm{bp} \times 0.34 \mathrm{~nm} / \mathrm{bp}\)

Length \(\approx 2.2 \times 10^{\wedge} 9 \mathrm{~nm}\)

Converting nanometers to meters \(\left(1 \mathrm{~nm}=1 \times 10^-9 \mathrm{~m}\right)\), we get:

Length \(\approx 2.244\) meters

So, the length of the DNA double helix is approximately 2.2 meters.
The set of positively charged basic proteins called as:

The set of positively charged basic proteins is called histones. They play a crucial role in DNA packaging and chromatin structure organization within the cell nucleus. These proteins aid in gene regulation and DNA accessibility for transcription and other cellular processes.
The thread-like stained structures present in the nucleus known as:

The thread-like stained structures present in the nucleus are known as chromatin. Chromatin consists of DNA, histone proteins, and other associated proteins. It undergoes structural changes during various cellular processes such as transcription, replication, and cell division.
When the negatively charged DNA combines with the positively charged histone octamer, which of the following is formed?

When the negatively charged DNA combines with the positively charged histone octamer, a complex structure known as a nucleosome is formed. Nucleosomes consist of DNA wrapped around a core of histone proteins, forming the fundamental unit of chromatin organization. These structures play a crucial role in packaging DNA and regulating gene expression within the nucleus.
How many nucleosomes are present in a mammalian cell?

In a mammalian cell, there are approximately 30 million nucleosomes. These nucleosomes are composed of DNA wrapped around a histone octamer, forming the basic repeating unit of chromatin. Nucleosomes play a crucial role in compacting and organizing DNA within the nucleus, facilitating various cellular processes such as gene expression, DNA replication, and DNA repair.
Which of the following chromatins are said to be transcriptionally active and inactive respectively?

Euchromatin is transcriptionally active, meaning it undergoes frequent transcription and gene expression. It appears less condensed and contains actively transcribed genes. In contrast, heterochromatin is transcriptionally inactive, with a more condensed structure and fewer active genes. Heterochromatin is involved in maintaining chromosomal stability and regulating gene expression by silencing genes or preventing access to transcriptional machinery.
What are the additional set of proteins which are required for the packaging of chromatin at the higher levels known as?

Non-histone chromosomal proteins are the additional set of proteins required for the packaging of chromatin at higher levels. While histone proteins play a central role in chromatin structure by forming the nucleosome core, non-histone chromosomal proteins contribute to chromatin condensation, gene regulation, DNA repair, and other chromosomal functions. These proteins interact with DNA and histones to modulate chromatin structure and regulate gene expression, providing additional levels of chromatin organization and control.
Which of the following bacterium is responsible for causing pneumonia?

Streptococcus pneumoniae, also known as pneumococcus, is the bacterium responsible for causing pneumonia. It is a leading cause of bacterial pneumonia, particularly in adults, children, and the elderly. This pathogen can also cause other respiratory infections like sinusitis, bronchitis, and ear infections.
Which of the following is responsible for transforming the R strain into the S strain?

The purified bio-chemicals from heat-killed S-strain contain factors that transform the non-virulent R-strain into the virulent S-strain. This transformation, observed in Griffith's experiment, is a classic example of bacterial transformation, demonstrating the transfer of genetic material between bacterial cells. Heat-killing the S-strain releases these factors, allowing them to convert the R-strain into the virulent form.
Which of the following is responsible for the inhibition of transformation in organisms?

DNase is responsible for the inhibition of transformation in organisms by degrading DNA. It breaks down extracellular DNA, preventing its uptake by bacterial cells during transformation processes. This degradation ensures that foreign DNA is not incorporated into the recipient organism's genome, thereby inhibiting transformation.
Which was considered to be as the genetic material prior to the works done by Oswald Avery, Colin MacLeod and Maclyn McCarty?

Prior to the works done by Oswald Avery, Colin MacLeod and Maclyn McCarty, the genetic material was thought to be as the protein. Nucleoids are the irregular shaped structures in the prokaryotic cell. They contain nearly all of the genetic material of the prokaryotes. Nucleons are present inside the nucleus of an atom, alongside with the protons. Chromosome carries the genetic information of the genes.
Which substances are formed along with humus due to the decomposition process?
The substances are formed along with humus due to the decomposition process are inorganic nutrients. This gives rise to many metal ions such as iron, cobalt, potassium, selenium, zinc, etc.
What is the process of release of inorganic substances both minerals and non-minerals from organic matter called?

The process of release of inorganic substances both minerals (H2O, CO2, etc.) and non-minerals from organic matter (e.g. Ca2+, NH4, Mg2+, K+, etc.) is called mineralization. It is the last step in the process of decomposition. These minerals are again used by plants for food production.
How many steps are involved in the process of decomposition?

The physical and chemical process of break down complex organic remains (dead or decaying organisms) into inorganic substances is called decomposition. The decomposition is a 5 step process. The steps are fragmentation, leaching, catabolism, humification, and mineralization respectively.

The process of break down complex organic matter (dead or decaying organisms) into inorganic substances is called decomposition. It is an aerobic process and is largely dependent on the availability of oxygen.
What is the only source of energy for all ecosystems on Earth?

The only source of energy for all ecosystems on Earth is the sun. The radiant light and heat from the sun is the primary, original source for most of organisms and is used for the production of electricity, fuel, thermal energy, agriculture, etc.
Which is an exception in an ecosystem where the sun is not the source of energy?

The deep-sea hydro-thermal ecosystem is an exception in the ecosystem where the sun is not the source of energy. The chemo-synthesis, marine snow, and whale falls are the three main sources of energy and nutrients for deep-sea communities.
What is the spectral range of solar radiation in that photosynthetic organisms are able to use in the process of photosynthesis called?

The spectral range of solar radiation in that photosynthetic organisms are able to use in the process of photosynthesis is called as Photosynthetically Active Radiation. It is designated as PAR and ranges from 400nm to 700nm.
What percent of the incident solar radiation is photosynthetically active radiation (PAR)?
Almost less than equal to 50% of the incident solar radiation is photosynthetically active radiation (PAR). It ranges from 400nm to 700nm.
What percent of PAR is captured by plants?
The spectral range of solar radiation that photosynthetic organisms are able to use in the process of photosynthesis is called PAR (400 to 700nm). Almost 2-10% of PAR is captured by plants.
On what are the organisms are dependent on their food?

All organisms directly or indirectly are dependent on producers for their food production. Producers are organisms that make their own food with the help of energy obtained from chemicals or the sun, water, and air. They are also known as autotrophs.
How is the flow of energy from the sun to producers and then to consumers?

The movement of energy from the higher trophic levels and its distribution and loss as heat to the lower trophic levels in the environment is unidirectional. It means the energy moves in one direction only that is from the higher to the lower-most level.
From which law of energy the ecosystem are not exempted?
Ecosystems are not exempted from the Second Law of thermodynamics since they require a constant energy supply for the synthesis of food. This increases the tendency toward disorderliness.
What are the green plants in the ecosystem termed as?

Usually, the green plants present in the ecosystem are termed as the producers. Producers (autotrophs) are organisms that make their own food with the help of energy obtained from chemicals or the sun, water, and air.
Who are the major producers in a terrestrial ecosystem?

The green plants (herbaceous and woody plants) are the major producers in a terrestrial ecosystem. Producers (autotrophs) are organisms that are capable of producing their own food (organic molecules) with the help of energy obtained from chemicals or the sun, water, and air (inorganic sources).
How sunlight is much is reflected back out of the total sunlight reaching Earth?

The Earth absorbs most of the energy reaching its surface, and a small fraction is reflected. In total, approximately 70% of incoming radiation is absorbed by the atmosphere and the Earth's surface while around 30% is reflected to space and does not heat the surface.
How much percent of light reaches the Earth’s surface out of the total sunlight?

Approximately 56-60 percent of light reaches the Earth’s surface out of the total sunlight. The heat and light from the sun is the original, primary source for most of organisms and is used for the production of electricity, fuel, thermal energy, agriculture, etc.
What amount of sunlight is held the ozone layer, water vapor, and atmospheric gases out of total sunlight reaching Earth?

10% of sunlight is held by the ozone layer, water vapor, and atmospheric gases out of total sunlight reaching Earth. The radiant light and heat from the sun is the primary, original source for most of organisms.
What does this statement “The energy passed from producers to consumers (herbivores) does not go back to producers (autotrophs)” state about the flow of energy?

The statement “The energy passed from producers to consumers (herbivores) does not go back to producers (autotrophs)” tells us that the flow of energy is unidirectional. It means the energy moves in one direction only that is from the higher to the lower-most level.
Which one of the following represents a pyramid of energy?

The pyramid of energy is said to be the best representation of an ecosystem because it indicates the rate of energy flow through the food chain. Depending upon the nature of the food chain, the pyramid is always upright.
Which one of the following represents a pyramid of numbers?

The pyramid of numbers represents the number of individuals at every trophic level (producers forming the base and top carnivores forming the tip). Depending upon the nature of the food chain, the pyramid is either inverted or upright.
What is the sequence of successional stages occurring in water called?
The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession. It is also known as hydrosere and starts in a newly formed pond or lake.
Which of the following succession starts with the colonization of phytoplankton in the water?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. It usually starts with the colonization of small phytoplanktons. These organisms act as the pioneering species in hydrosere.
Who replaces the phytoplanktons in a hydrarch succession?

A hydrarch succession starts with the colonization of small phytoplanktons. These phytoplanktons, later with time are replaced by rooted-submerged plants in a hydrarch succession. Some examples of the rooted-submerged plants are Ceratophyllum, Chara, Elodia, Potamogeton, etc.
Who replaces the rooted-submerged plants in a hydrarch succession?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. The rooted-submerged plants with time are replaced by rooted-floating angiosperms. An example of a rooted-floating angiosperm is water lily.
Who replaces the rooted-floating angiosperms in a hydrarch succession?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. The rooted-floating angiosperms with time are replaced by free-floating plants in a hydrarch succession. Some examples of floating plants are Pistia, Nymphaea, Pistia, Nymphaea, etc.
Who replaces the free-floating plants in a hydrarch succession?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. The free-floating plants with time are replaced by the reed-swamp in a hydrarch succession. Some examples of reed-swamp plants are Bothrioclova, Phragmites(Reed), Typha, etc.
Who replaces the reed swamp in a hydrarch succession?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. The reed-swamp with time is replaced by the marsh-meadow in a hydrarch succession. Some examples of the marsh-meadow plants are Caltha, Gallium, Mentha, Cicuta, etc.
What is the woodland stage replaced by in a hydrarch succession?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. The woodland stage in a hydrarch succession is replaced by the trees. This results in the formation of a forest.
What is the climax community in a hydrarch succession?

The sequence of successional stages occurring in water is known as hydrarch succession or hydrosere. The climax community in a hydrosere is a forest. It consists of various trees such as Acer, Quercus, etc.
To which climax community does succession in water lead to?

The hydrarch succession finally leads to the formation of a mesic community. It consists of a moderate or well-balanced supply of moisture. Few examples of mesic habitat are streamsides, wet meadows, springs, irrigated fields, etc.
Hard outer layer of pollen is called intine.

'Tapetum nourishes the developing pollen' is correct.

Tapetum is the innermost layer and completely surrounds the sporogenous tissue. The cells of Tapetum have dense cytoplasm and generally more than one nuclei. Tapetum nourishes the developing pollen grains.
The total number of nuclei involved in double fertilisation in angiosperms are:

Double fertilisation is an event unique to angiosperms. 

  • It involves the fusion of one male gamete (haploid) with egg (haploid) to form zygote (diploid) that gives rise to an embryo.
  • It is accompanied with fusion of other male gamete (haploid) with two polar nuclei (secondary nucleus) to form the primary endosperm nucleus (PEN)  which gives rise to a nutritive tissue called endosperm.

So, total of 5 haploid nuclei are involved in double fertilisation process.
Fusion of one of the male gametes with egg nucleus is referred to as:

Fusion of one of the male gametes with the egg nuclei is referred to as generative fertilisation and syngamy.

Fertilisation is also known as generative fertilisation, insemination, pollination, syngamy, and impregnation and it is the fusion of gametes to initiate the development of a new individual organism. The cycle of fertilisation and development of new individuals is called sexual reproduction.
Intine layer of pollen grain is made up of:

Intine layer of pollen grain is made up of inner cellulose, outer pectin.

Pollen grains are a mass of microspores in a seeded plant which appears in the form of fine dust. Each pollen grain is a minute body with varying shape and structure which are formed in the anthers of angiosperms.

It consists of two layers:

  1. Intine or inside layer is a thin and continuous layer made of cellulose or hemicellulose and pectin.
  2. Exine or outer layer a highly decay-resistant chemical called sporopollenin.
During the process of fertilisation, the pollen tube of the pollen grains usually enters the embryo sac through:

During the process of fertilisation, the pollen tube of the pollen grains usually enters the embryo sac through the micropyle.

After arriving at the wall of the ovary, the pollen tube enters the ovule either through the micropyle or by some other route. The entrance of the pollen tube through the micropyle is the normal condition and is known as porogamy.

Albuminous seeds are found in Wheat, Barley, Castor.

  • On the basis of the presence or absence of endosperm, both Dicotyledonous and Monocotyledon seeds are endospermic or endospermic.
  • Albuminous seeds or endospermic seeds are the seeds that retain some part of endosperm because it is not completely consumed during embryonic development and endosperm stores food. In endospermic seeds, cotyledons are usually smaller and less developed. For example, Zea mays(Maize), Triticum Vulgare(Wheat), Barley, Oryza sativa(Rice), Cotton, Ricinus communis(Castor) and onion.

The ovary is half-inferior in the flowers of plum.

A half-inferior ovary is embedded or surrounded by the receptacle. Such flowers are termed perigynous or half-epigynous. In some classifications, half-inferior ovaries are not recognized and are instead grouped with either the superior or inferior ovaries.

Select the plants pollinated by water.

a. Water Hyacinth

b. Zostera

c. Amorphophallus

d. Vallisneria

e. Yucca
Zostera is mainly called marine eelgrass and is pollinated by water method. This process is known as Hydrophily. Vallisneria is epihydrophily which occurs through the surface of the water.

Pollination in Vallisneria is epihydriphilous. 

It is a type of hydrophily which occurs on the surface of water. The female flower have a very long pedicel, therefore it reaches the surface of water. Male flowers after breakage floats on the surface of water. Pollen grains are released on to the surface of water. They are carried passively by water currents, some of them eventually reach the female flowers and the stigma.
Develops into the root of the embryo
Forms the suspensor that anchors the embryo and transfers nutrients
Results from the fertilization of polar and sperm nuclei and develops into the endosperm
Divides to form the two cotyledons of the proembryo

The basal cell in a zygote forms the suspensor that anchors the embryo and transfers nutrients.

A zygote is the cell formed when two gametes fuse during fertilization. The DNA material from the two cells is combined in the resulting zygote. The zygote undergoes an asymmetric transverse cell division that gives rise to two cells - a small apical cell resting above a large basal cell. The large basal cell is on the bottom and consists of a large vacuole and gives rise to the hypophysis and the suspensor. The suspensor connects the endosperm to an embryo and helps in transfer of nutrients.
Which of the following statements is not correct?
Pollen grains are released from anthers at 2-celled stage
Sporogenous cell directly behaves as the megaspore mother cell
Megaspore divides twice to form an eight nucleate embryo sac
Egg and synergids always lie near the micropylar end of ovule

The functional megaspore is the first cell of female gametophyte. The cell enlarges and undergoes three free nuclear mitotic division. The first division produces two nucleate embryo sac. The two nuclei shift to the two ends and divide twice forming four nucleate and then eight nucleate structure. One nucleus from each side moves to the middle, they are called polar nuclei. The remaining three nuclei form cells at the two ends, 3 celled egg apparatus at the micropylar end and three antipodal cells at the chalazal end. The middle binucleate part organise itself into central cell. Embryo sac developed from a single megaspore is called monsporic.

Consider the following statements.

Apomixis is phenomenon in which:

1. Fertilization occurs regularly

2. Fertilization does not occur at all

3. Embryo is formed directly from an egg or male gamete

4. Formed embryo may be haploid or diploid

Which of the statements is/are correct?

Apomixis can be defined as the replacement of normal sexual reproduction by asexual reproduction. Apomixis mimics sexual reproduction without fertilization. The seed of the plant is developed without fertilisation. It can be observed in blackberries, mat grass, hawkweeds, and many others. It can be useful in forming hybrid seeds. There are several ways of development of apomitic seeds. In some species, the diploid egg cell is formed without reduction division and develops into the embryo without fertilisation. So, the correct statements are 2, 3, and 4.
Vegetative cell is larger than generative cell.
Intine is made of cellulose and pectin.
Pollen grains of some plants remain viable for months.
Double fertilization is absent where pollen is shed in 2 - celled stage.

'Double fertilization is absent where pollen is shed in 2 - celled stage' is incorrect.

During the development of microspores into pollen grains, each microspore undergoes a mitotic division to form two cells, a large vegetative cell, and a small generative cell. The entire generative cell resides within the cytoplasm of the vegetative cell. These two cells form the juvenile pollen grain or the male gametophyte. At this stage, pollens are said to be 2-celled. Later, the generative cell divides by mitosis to form two sperm cells which remain in the cytoplasm of the vegetative cell. This three-celled structure is the mature male gametophyte or pollen grain. Pollens at this stage are said to be 3-celled. In most of the angiosperms, pollen grains are released at the 2-celled stage and the generative cell divides in the pollen tube to form two male gametes, which then fuse with the egg cell and secondary nucleus. So, double fertilization occurs when the pollens are shed at 2-celled stages.
What is the liquid part of green coconut?

Endosperm is the liquid part of green coconut.

Endosperm is a tissue produced inside the seeds of most flowering plants around the time of fertilization. It surrounds the embryo and provides nutrition in the form of starch, though it can also contain oils and protein. In coconut, the endosperm is present in liquid form.
Ovule is attached to the placenta by a stalk named as:

Funicle is a short stalk through which the ovule adheres to the placenta.

  • Petiole is a stalk of leaf by which it is attached to the stem.
  • Pedicel is a stalk of the flower by which it is attached to the stem of the plant.
  • Placenta is an organ that forms in the womb, also called the uterus, during pregnancy.
Which of these is a condition that makes flowers invariably autogamous?

A condition that makes flowers invariably autogamous is Cleistogamy.

Autogamy is possible only when the anther and stigma are close together and there is synchrony in pollen release and stigma receptivity. As in the case of cleistogamous flowers, the flowers remain closed so that anthers and stigmas are never exposed. The flowers undergo only self-pollination. No external pollinating agency is required.
The different cells of embryo sac are:
Egg apparatus, central cell and antipodal cells

The different cells of embryo sac are egg apparatus, central cell and antipodal cells.

A mature embryo sac is a 7-celled and 8-nucleate structure. The 8 nuclei are arranged in precise positions. One nucleus is located in the egg cell near the opening of embryo sac. Two nuclei are located in two synergid cells which flank the egg cell. The synergids and egg cell together constitute the egg apparatus. Two nuclei are located in a single cell called central cell present in the middle of the embryo sac and are called polar nuclei. The other three nuclei reside in the cells called antipodals which are located at the end of embryo sac, opposite to egg cell.
Outer wall of pollen grain is made up of:

Outer wall of pollen grain is made up of Sporopollenin.

Sporopollenin is a major component of the tough outer walls of plant spores and pollen grains. It is chemically very stable.
The division of zygote in the development of crucifer type embryo is:

The division of the zygote in the development of crucifer-type embryos is transverse.

The zygote in crucifers divides transversally to produce terminal and basal cells. The terminal cells divide vertically to produce 4 celled embryo and the basal cell produces suspensors and in some plants produces hypocotyl. Each four cell divides transversally and produces 8 celled embryo. The 8 cells further divide to form the inner and outer cells of the embryo. Thus, the correct answer is option A.
What does the filiform apparatus do at the entrance into ovule?
It helps in the entry of pollen tube into a synergid.
It prevents entry of more than one pollen tube into the embryo sac.
It brings about opening of the pollen tube.
It guides pollen tube from a synergid to egg.

Filiform apparatus is a prolongation of the synergids beyond the summit of the embryo sac. It helps in guiding the entry of pollen tube into the synergids. Schacht first described this as 'fertilization threads'.

Hypanthodium inflorescence is pollinated by Blastophaga.

Hypanthodium is one of the special types of inflorescence. In this type of inflorescence, the receptacle is fleshy and forms a hollow ball-like structure with an apical opening. The inner surface of the receptacle is arranged with three types of flowers. The female flowers are towards the base, male flowers are towards the opening and short-styled sterile female flowers are in between above two. This inflorescence is an adaptation for insect pollination. The inflorescence is pollinated by a gall wasp (Blastophaga). Ficus is an example of this kind of inflorescence.

In ovule, meiosis occurs in Megasporocyte.

In the ovule or megasporangium, during the process of megasporogenesis, a hypodermal cell functions as a archesporium cell and becomes more prominent due to large size, denser cytoplasm and large nucleus. In tenuinucellate ovules, archesporial cell directly functions as megaspore mother cell while in crassinucellate ovules, archesporial cell divides periclinally to form an outer parietal cell and inner primary sporogenous cell that functions as megaspore mother cell. Megaspore mother cell is also called megasporocyte which divides by meiosis to form four haploid megaspores. Thus, in ovule meiosis occurs in megasporocyte.
Type of division that occurs during formation of megaspore is:

Type of division that occurs during formation of megaspore is Meiosis.

Megaspore is formed from Megaspore mother cell. Megaspore mother cell develops in the nucellus and is diploid. The diploid Megaspore mother cell then undergoes meiosis to form four haploid megaspores.
Heterostyly as a contrivance for cross-pollination is found in:

Heterostyly as a contrivance for cross-pollination is found in Primula vulgaris.

Heterostyly is the presence of 2−3 types of flower with different heights of styles and stamens. In diheterostyly (dimorphic heterostyly), there are two types of flower, pin eyed (long style and short stamens) and thrum eyed(short style and long stamens), e.g., Primula vulgaris (primrose), jasmine.
The part of gynoecium that determines the compatible nature of pollen is:

The part of gynoecium that determines the compatible nature of pollen is stigma.

  • The stigma is found in the flower's gynoecium. 
  • Its major role is to use its sticky tip to catch pollen grains from the air so that reproduction can take place.
  • It also checks the compatible nature of pollen.
  • Style is a long, tube-like structure that connects to the ovary.
  • The ovary is the larger basal part of the pistil, a flower's female organ.
  • Ovules are found in the ovary, and when fertilised, they grow into seeds. 
  • The ovary will mature into a dry or meaty fruit that will enclose the seeds.
  • Synergid cells are two specialized cells in the female gametophyte of angiosperms that reside next to the egg cell and play an important role in pollen tube guidance and function.
Megasporangium along with its protective integuments is called:

Megasporangium along with its protective integuments is called Ovule.

The ovule is a small structure attached to the placenta by means of a stalk called funicle.  Each ovule has one or two protective envelopes called integuments. Integuments encircle the ovule except at the tip where a small opening called the micropyle is present. Megasporangium along with its protective integuments is called Ovule.
Mature ovules are classified on the basis of funiculus. If micropyle comes to lie close to the funiculus the ovule is termed as:

Mature ovules are classified on the basis of funiculus. If micropyle comes to lie close to the funiculus the ovule is termed as Anatropous.

  • Depending upon the configuration and orientation of the body of ovule in relation to funiculus, there are six types of ovule - orthotropous(atropous, erect), anatropoys (inverted), hemitropous(half inverted), campylotropous (body curved), amphitropous (both body and embryo sac curved) and circinotropous(funiculus is coiled around the ovule).
  • Anatropous or inverted ovule is the most common type of ovule found in angiosperms(in 82% of angiosperm families). Here, body of the ovule gets inverted and micropyle is on lower side. Further micropyle and funiculus lie side by side and micropyle is close to hilum.
When micropyle, chalaza and hilum lie in a straight line, the ovule is said to be:

When micropyle, chalaza and hilum lie in a straight line, the ovule is said to be Orthotropous.

  • Anatropous ovule: The body of the ovule becomes completely inverted during the development. So that the micropyle lie very close to the hilum. e.g. gamopetalous members
  • Orthotropous ovule: The body of the ovule is erect or straight. The hilum, chalaza, and the micropyle lie in a straight line. e.g. Polygonum
  • Amphitropus ovule: The body of the ovule is very much curved that the embryo sac and the ovule itself take the shape of a horseshoe. e.g. Allismaceae
  • Campylotropous ovule: The body of the ovule is curved or bent round so, that the micropyle and chalaza do not lie in the same straight line. e.g. Leguminosae.
Fragrant flowers with well developed nectaries are an adaptation for:

Fragrant flowers with well-developed nectaries are an adaptation for entomophily. In entomophily, insects are the pollinating agents. These are the most common biotic agents of pollination. Bees are the most common insect which acts as pollinating agents. Other insect pollinators are butterflies, flies, beetles, wasps, ants, moths. Majority of insect-pollinated flowers are large-sized. These flowers are colorful and possess fragrance to attract the insects. Nectar is given as a reward to insects.
Pollen kit is generally found in:

Pollen kit is generally found in Entomophilous flowers.

In the pollen grains of an insect pollinated plant, the exine is covered by a yellowish, viscous, sticky and oily layer called pollen kitt. It is made up of lipids and carotenoids. Pollen kitt is secreted by tapetum.
The bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis is widely used in biology as:

The bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) is widely used in biology as an insecticide. It produces proteins called Cry proteins, which are toxic to certain insects when ingested. These proteins have been harnessed for use as insecticides in agriculture to control pests such as caterpillars, beetles, and flies.
The protein coded by gene Cry IAb controls:

The protein coded by gene Cry IAb, derived from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), is known to control corn borer, an insect pest that damages corn crops. This protein is toxic to corn borer larvae when ingested, making it an effective means of pest control in agriculture.
The Ti plasmid, used for producing transgenic plants, is found in:
Rhizobium of the roots of leguminous plants

Ti plasmid used for making transgenic plants is found in the bacterium Agrobacterium. It is used as a vector for gene transfer to plant cells. It has a vir region responsible for virulence towards host and a tDNA region, which is transferred to the host.
The genetically modified brinjal in India has been developed for:

The genetically modified brinjal in India has been developed primarily for insect resistance. This genetically modified variety of brinjal, also known as Bt brinjal, contains genes from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), which produce proteins toxic to certain insect pests.

The GEAC refers to genetic engineering approval committee. It is established under the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change in India and assesses the environmental safety aspects of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and grants approvals for their release after thorough evaluation.
Which of the following is not used as a biopesticide?

Xanthomonas campestris is not typically used as a biopesticide. It is a plant pathogen causing diseases in various crops rather than being employed as a biological control agent for pest management. On the other hand, Bacillus thuringiensis, Trichoderma harzianum, and Nuclear Polyhedrosis Virus are commonly utilized as biopesticides for controlling pests in agriculture.
The source of DNA polymerase used in PCR:

DNA polymerase used in PCR is typically derived from bacteria, particularly thermophilic species like Thermus aquaticus. These bacteria inhabit hot environments, allowing their enzymes, including DNA polymerase, to withstand the high temperatures used in PCR cycles.
A transgenic food crop which may help in solving the problems of night blindness is:

Night blindness, caused by vitamin A deficiency, can indeed be prevented by consuming foods rich in vitamin A, such as golden rice. This crop is genetically modified to produce beta-carotene, a precursor of vitamin A. Consuming golden rice can help address vitamin A deficiency and prevent conditions like night blindness in populations where vitamin A-rich foods are scarce.
What is the term for the process by which an additional short chain of peptides is attached to a hormone, rendering it inactive?

Prohormone refers to an inactive precursor of a hormone, formed by the addition of a short peptide chain. This modification renders the hormone biologically inactive until it undergoes further processing to become active. They are typically converted into active hormones through enzymatic cleavage or other biochemical modifications.
The crops engineered for glyphosate are resistant/tolerant to:

The crops engineered for glyphosate resistance are tolerant to herbicides, particularly glyphosate. This trait allows the crops to withstand the application of glyphosate-based herbicides, enabling effective weed control without harming the crop plants.
Which of the following vector can maintain the largest fragment of foreign DNA?

Yeast Artificial Chromosome are vectors used to clone large DNA fragments, ranging from hundreds of thousands to over a million base pairs in length. They are particularly useful for maintaining and manipulating large DNA inserts due to their ability to replicate autonomously within yeast cells. This feature makes YACs suitable for studying large genomic regions and genes, as well as for applications such as gene therapy and genomic sequencing.
Crystals of Bt toxin produced by some bacteria do not kill the bacteria themselves because:
Bacteria encloses toxin in a special sac
Crystals of Bt toxin produced by some bacteria do not kill the bacteria themselves because toxin is secreted in inactive form which gets activated in alkaline conditions of the gut of gallworms.
Which of the following is correct regarding Retrovirus?
An RNA virus that can synthesise DNA during infection.
A DNA virus that can synthesise RNA during infection.

An RNA virus that can synthesize DNA during infection. Retroviruses are RNA viruses that have the unique ability to convert their RNA genome into DNA using the enzyme reverse transcriptase during infection. This DNA form integrates into the host cell genome, allowing the virus to replicate along with the host cell's DNA.
The genes cryIAb and cryII Ab produce toxins against are respectively:

The genes cryIAb and cryIIAb produce toxins effective against corn borer and cotton bollworm, respectively. These toxins are derived from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) and are widely used in biotechnology to confer insect resistance in crops, reducing the need for chemical pesticides and promoting sustainable agriculture practices.
ADA is an enzyme which is deficient in a genetic disorder SCID. What is the full form of ADA?

Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is an inherited disorder that damages the immune system. It's an enzyme crucial for the breakdown of adenosine to inosine. In Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), a genetic disorder, deficiency of ADA leads to impaired immune system function. This enzyme deficiency affects the development and function of T and B lymphocytes, leaving individuals vulnerable to infections.
Insulin hormone is a protein consisting of 51 amino acids in the form of polypeptide chain. How many polypeptide chains are present in it?

Insulin is composed of two polypeptide chains, an A chain and a B chain, linked together by disulfide bonds. These chains are synthesized separately as precursor molecules, proinsulin, which is then cleaved to form the mature insulin molecule during post-translational processing. Each chain contributes to the overall structure and function of insulin, with the A chain containing 21 amino acids and the B chain containing 30 amino acids. Together, they form the active hormone responsible for regulating blood sugar levels.
One of the characteristics of Bt cotton is:
High yield and production of toxic proteins crystals which kill dipteran pests

Bt cotton is genetically modified to produce Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) toxin, which forms toxic protein crystals lethal to certain pests like dipterans (flies and mosquitoes).
