Bio-fortification: It is the process of enhancing the nutrient content in the food crops through selective breeding, genetic modifications, or used of enhanced fertilizers etc. It is a feasible method for delivering micronutrients to the population.
The biggest constraint of plant breeding is:
availability of desirable gene in the crop and its wild relatives

Plant breeding is the process where the desired gene from the wild type is introduced in the plants. The genes can only be transferred from the wild type when it is a related species.

Here some of the factors that have to be kept in mind are:

  • The selection of the variety of crops and their genetic constituents.
  • The wild variety which is taken should be disease free.
The enzyme which has the fibrinolytic effect is:

Streptokinase is an enzyme used to break down fibrin clots, a key component of blood clots, by converting plasminogen to plasmin, the enzyme responsible for clot breakdown.

Streptokinase produced by the bacterium Streptococcus and modified by genetic engineering is used as a 'clot buster' for removing clots from the blood vessels of patients who have undergone myocardial infarction leading to heart attack.
Use of certain chemicals and radiation to change the base sequences of genes of crop plants is termed:

Mutation Breeding: It is the process of breeding by artificially inducing mutations with chemicals or radiations to obtain new varieties of plants having the desirable characteristics.

  • Certain chemicals and radiation (gamma radiation) are used to change the base sequences of genes of crop plants.
  • Example- In mung beans, resistance to yellow mosaic virus and powdery mildew were induced using mutation breeding.
Cells that release histamine and other vasoactive substances in response to allergens are:

The cells that release histamine and other vasoactive substances in response to allergens are mast cells.

  • Mast cells are a type of white blood cell that is found in connective tissue and mucous membranes.
  • When allergens bind to IgE antibodies attached to the surface of mast cells, it triggers the release of histamine, leukotrienes, prostaglandins, and other vasoactive substances.
Retrovirus have RNA genomes that replicate via DNA intermediate.
Viral RNA is converted into DNA copy by reverse transcryptase.
HIV selectively infects and kills B-lymphocytes: This is incorrect. HIV primarily infects and destroys T-lymphocytes (specifically CD4+ T cells), not B-lymphocytes.
Which of the following is not a type of manure?

Platinum manure is not a type of manure.

Manure is a semi-decayed organic matter which is added to the soil to maintain its fertility, crumb structure, aeration and hydration capacities. There are three types of manure commonly found in the farms-farmyard manure, compost manure and green manure.
Which of the following is not used as a bio-fertiliser?

Algae is not used as a bio-fertiliser.

Bio fertilisers are organisms that enrich the nutrient quality of the soil. The main sources of bio-fertilisers are bacteria, fungi and cyanobacteria.
Which of the following is not a free-living Nitrogen-fixing bacteria?

Xanthomonas is not a free-living Nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

Some of the free-living Nitrogen-fixing bacteria are-Azotobacter, Clostridium, Klebsiella and Beijerinckia. Rhizobium, Xanthomonas and Frankia are some of the symbiotic Nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
Which of the following is an aerobic nitrogen-fixing bacterium?

Some of the aerobic nitrogen-fixing bacteria are Azotobacter and Beijerinckia. Some of the anaerobic nitrogen-fixing bacteria are Clostridium, Rhodospirillum and Rhodopseudomonas. Soil is enriched through exudation and formation of nitrates after their death and decay.
Which of the following bacteria cannot fix atmospheric nitrogen?

Lactobacillus cannot fix atmospheric nitrogen.

Cyanobacteria are autotrophic microbes widely distributed in aquatic and terrestrial environments many of which can fix atmospheric nitrogen like Nostoc, Anabaena and Oscillatoria.
Which of the following statements is not related to mycorrhiza?
Many members of genus Glomus forms mycorrhiza
There is an overall increase in plant growth and development

Fungi are known to form symbiotic associations with plants known as mycorrhiza. Many members of genus Glomus form mycorrhiza. The fungal symbiont absorbs phosphorous from the soil and passes it on to the plant. Plants having such associations show resistance to root-borne pathogens and an overall increase in plant growth and development.
The injecting of foreign gene in an animal gives rise to:

The injecting of foreign gene in an animal gives rise to transgenic animal. Transgenic animals are animals that have had a foreign gene deliberately inserted into their genome. Such, animals are most commonly created by micro-injection of DNA into the pronuclei of a fertilized egg which is implanted into the oviduct of a pseudopregnant surrogate mother.
The method of biopiracy is known as:

The method of bio-piracy is illegal collection of biological sample. Biopiracy is the term used to refer to the use of bio-resources by multinational companies and other organisations without proper authorisation from the countries and people concerned without compensatory payment.
The term 'clone' cannot be applied to offspring formed by sexual reproduction because:
Offspring do not possess exact copies of parental DNA
DNA of only one parent is copied and passed on to the offspring
DNA of parent and offspring are completely different

The term 'clone' cannot be applied to offspring formed by sexual reproduction because offspring do not possess exact copies of parental DNA. Cloning is the process of producing genetically identical individuals of an organism either naturally or artificially. During sexual reproduction, fertilization creates a single-celled zygote which includes genetic material from both gametes.
Which of the following biomolecules can be analysed by ELISA test?

Biomolecules including peptides, hormones and antibodies can be analysed by ELISA test. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), also known as an enzyme immunoassay (EIA), is a biochemical technique used mainly in immunology for detecting and quantifying substances such as peptides, proteins, antibodies and hormones. They are termed as an analyte.

A transgenic animal is one that carries a foreign gene that has been deliberately inserted into its genome. \(95 \%\) percent of all transgenic animals are mice and rats, according to the Foundation for Biomedical Research (FBR).
What does the second critical research area of biotechnology provide?

The second critical research area of biotechnology provides optimum conditions for the catalyst. This involves optimizing factors such as temperature, pH, substrate concentration, and enzyme concentration to maximize the efficiency of biotechnological processes. By fine-tuning these conditions, researchers can enhance the activity and stability of enzymes or other catalysts used in biotechnological applications, leading to improved yields and product purity.
Which of the following best defines GMOs (Genetically Modified Organisms)?
Organisms that have undergone natural genetic mutation
Organisms that have been genetically altered using biotechnology techniques
Organisms that are artificially created in laboratories
Organisms that are resistant to genetic modification

GMOs are organisms whose genetic material has been artificially altered in a laboratory through genetic engineering techniques. This alteration allows scientists to introduce new traits or characteristics into the organism that are not naturally occurring.
Why does a patient with ADA deficiency require a repeated infusion of genetically engineered lymphocytes?

ADA deficiency is also called adenosine deaminase deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder. It results in immunodeficiency. 

The immune response of an individual is hampered. Its symptoms include pneumonia, chronic diarrhea, skin rashes. It can be treated by a bone marrow transplant in which healthy immune cells are used to replace the defective immune cells. Other treatment includes a repeated infusion of genetically engineered peripheral blood lymphocytes as they are unable to produce WBC.
Peptide A and peptide B is linked by how many disulfide linkages in insulin?

Peptide A and peptide B is linked by two disulfide linkages in insulin. Proinsulin is made up of 81 residues and formed by three distinct chains. The A chain, B chain, and the area connecting the two are named the C peptide. The correct structure of proinsulin is crucial for the correct folding of mature insulin, as the placement of the C peptide sets the molecule up to create correctly positioned disulfide bonds in and between the A and B chains.

Genetic modification (GM) has been utilized to create tailor-made plants with desired traits, such as increased resistance to pests or improved yields. It has also been employed to develop alternative resources for various industries, such as biofuels. Additionally, GM technology has been used to enhance the nutritional value of food, providing benefits like increased vitamin content or improved protein quality.
An important objective of biotechnology in the area of agriculture is:

An important objective of biotechnology in agriculture is to produce pest-resistant varieties of plants. This goal is aimed at reducing the reliance on chemical pesticides and promoting sustainable agricultural practices. By incorporating genetic modifications that confer resistance to pests and diseases, biotechnology helps enhance crop yields while minimizing environmental impacts and ensuring food security.
Bt toxin is produced by a bacterium called:

Bt toxin is produced by a bacterium called Bacillus thuringiensis. This bacterium is known for its insecticidal properties and is widely used in agriculture to control pests. Bt toxin, derived from Bacillus thuringiensis, is effective against a variety of insect pests and is commonly incorporated into genetically modified crops to confer resistance to insect damage.
_______ a crown gall bacterium, is called as 'natural genetic engineer' of plants.

Agrobacterium tumefaciens, a crown gall bacterium, is called as 'natural genetic engineer' of plants. A soil-inhabiting plant bacterium Agrobacterium tumefaciens is a pathogen of several dicot plants.  It is able to transfer a piece of DNA known as 'T-DNA' into the plant cells.  The T-DNA causes tumours, the tumours are called crown galls. As gene transfer occurs without human effort, the bacterium is called natural genetic engineer of plants.
Which one of the following is not a correct match?
DNA probe - Identifies the desired DNA fragment

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a molecular biology technique used to amplify a specific DNA sequence. It involves cycles of denaturation, annealing, and extension, which do not typically involve DNA staining. DNA staining is a separate process used to visualize DNA fragments after electrophoresis, typically with dyes like ethidium bromide or SYBR Green. Therefore, PCR and DNA staining are not directly related.

Agro-chemical based agriculture is used to increase the food production. It includes use of agro-chemicals such as fertilizers and pesticides. They are chemical agents used on farmlands to improve the nutrients in the field or crops. They are implemented in all forms of farming sectors such as horticulture, dairy farming, poultry, crop shifting, commercial planting, etc.
Which of the following genes were introduced in cotton to protect it from cotton bollworms?

Cotton plants have been genetically modified to produce insecticidal proteins from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), specifically the CryAc and CryAb proteins. These proteins are toxic to cotton bollworms (Helicoverpa armigera), a common pest that damages cotton crops. The introduction of these genes into cotton confers resistance to bollworm infestation, reducing the need for chemical insecticides and promoting more sustainable agriculture.
Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) strains have been used for designing novel:

Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) strains have been utilized to create genetically modified crops, known as bio-insecticidal plants. These plants are engineered to produce insecticidal proteins derived from Bt, such as Cry proteins, which are toxic to certain insect pests. By incorporating Bt genes into crops like cotton, corn, and soybeans, these plants become resistant to specific insect pests, reducing the need for chemical insecticides and promoting environmentally friendly pest control strategies.
Human insulin is being commercially produced from a transgenic species of:

Human insulin is being commercially produced from a transgenic species of Escherichia. In 1983, Eli Lilly an American company, first prepared two DNA sequences corresponding to A and B chains of human insulin and introduced them in plasmids of Escherichia coil to produce insulin and chains.
Insect resistance transgenic cotton has been developed by inserting a piece of DNA from:

Insect-resistant transgenic cotton has been developed by inserting a piece of DNA from a soil bacterium, specifically Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt). This bacterium naturally produces insecticidal proteins known as Cry proteins, which are toxic to certain insect pests. By incorporating genes encoding these proteins into cotton plants, scientists have created transgenic cotton varieties that are resistant to pests like cotton bollworms and budworms.
Rules of conduct that may be used to regulate our activities in relation to the biological world is called:

Rules of conduct that may be used to regulate our activities in relation to the biological world is called Bioethics. It may be viewed as the set of standards that may be used to regulate various activities based on their effects on the biological world.  This is because biotechnology has aroused social as well as political concerns, which have ranged from biotechnology being unnatural to detrimental to biodiversity.
The transgenic plant ‘Flavr savr’ tomato carries an artificial gene for:
Both delaying ripening process and added flavours

The transgenic plant "Flavr Savr" tomato carries an artificial gene for delaying the ripening process. This genetically engineered tomato variety was developed to have a longer shelf life by slowing down the ripening process, thereby reducing spoilage and extending the time for distribution and consumption. While the Flavr Savr tomato does not have added flavors, its delayed ripening trait enhances its freshness and quality.
Tobacco plants resistant to a nematode have been developed by the introduction of DNA that produced:

Tobacco plants resistant to a nematode have been developed by the introduction of DNA that produced both sense and anti-sense RNA in the host cells. This approach utilizes RNA interference (RNAi) technology, where both sense and anti-sense RNA molecules are produced within the plant cells. These RNA molecules bind to complementary sequences in the nematode's mRNA, leading to the degradation of the target mRNA and ultimately suppressing the expression of genes essential for the nematode's survival. This mechanism confers resistance to the nematode in the transgenic tobacco plants.
The first clinical gene therapy was done for the treatment of:
SCID (Serve Combined Immuno Deficiency resulting form deficiency of ADA)

The first clinical gene therapy was done for the treatment of SCID (Serve Combined Immuno Deficiency resulting form deficiency of ADA). The first clinical gene therapy was given in 1990 to a 4-years old girl with adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency. This enzyme is very important for the immune system to function. ADA deficiency can lead to severe combined immune deficiency (SCID).
A variety of rice grown along the yellow river in China
Long stored rice having yellow cocur tint
Wild variety of rice with yellow colored grains

Golden rice is a transgenic rice having gene for \(\beta\)-carotene. It is a transgenic variety of rice (Oryza Sativa) which contains good quantities of \(\beta\)-carotene ( provitamin A- inactive state of vitamin A). \(\beta\)-carotene is a principle source of vitamin A. Since the grains (seeds) of the rice are yellow in colour due to \(\beta\)-carotene, the rice is commonly called golden rice.

Transgenic plants carry desirable traits like herbicide resistance. This is achieved by introducing specific genes into the plant's genome, often derived from other organisms, which confer resistance to herbicides. This trait allows the transgenic plants to survive herbicide treatments, providing farmers with effective weed control options while minimizing damage to the crop. Herbicide-resistant transgenic plants have been widely adopted in agriculture to improve crop yield and reduce reliance on manual weed control methods.
The Bt toxin is used for killing nematodes in crop plants. But, it is non-toxic to humans. Select the correct reason for this.
The pro Bt-toxin activation requires temperature above human body temperature
The pro Bt-toxin activation requires pH lower than that present in the human stomach.
Conversion of pro Bt-toxin to Bt-toxin takes place in highly alkaline conditions.

The Bt toxin is used for killing nematodes in crop plants. But, it is non-toxic to humans due to conversion of pro Bt-toxin to Bt-toxin takes place in highly alkaline conditions. Bt toxins are used to kill insects but for humans, it is non-toxic because it behaves as a dietary protein. These breakdown very rapidly due to high acidic conditions in the human stomach and are harmless. As human stomach digests the concerned protein, therefore, it is not toxic to humans.
Adenosine deaminase deficiency can be permanently cured by which of the following methods?

Adenosine deaminase deficiency can be permanently cured by gene therapy at early embryonic stages. This deficiency can be treated by bone marrow transplantation, or by enzyme replacement therapy, in which functional ADA is given to the patient by injection. But permanent treatment can be done by introduction of gene isolated from bone marrow cells, which produces ADA, into the cells of the patient at early embryonic stage.
A desirable change in the genotype of an organism is obtained by:

rDNA technology, also known as recombinant DNA technology, involves the manipulation of DNA molecules to create new combinations of genetic material. This technology allows scientists to introduce desirable genes into an organism's genome, resulting in a desirable change in its genotype. By inserting specific genes into an organism's DNA, researchers can confer new traits or improve existing ones, such as disease resistance, increased yield, or enhanced nutritional value. It has revolutionized biotechnology and has numerous applications in agriculture, medicine, and industry.
Which of the following is a recombinant therapeutic used to treat diabetes?

Recombinant DNA technology has enabled the production of insulin through genetically engineered bacteria or yeast. Insulin produced in this way is identical to human insulin and is used as a therapeutic agent to manage diabetes by regulating blood sugar levels.
A human protein which is obtained from transgenic animals and is used to treat emphysema is:

A human protein which is obtained from transgenic animals and is used to treat emphysema is \(\alpha-1\)-antitrypsin. Transgenic animals, particularly goats and sheep, have been genetically engineered to produce human \(\alpha-1\)-antitrypsin in their milk. This recombinant protein can then be extracted from the milk and used as a therapeutic treatment for individuals with A1AT deficiency, helping to alleviate symptoms and slow the progression of emphysema.
Grazing benefits the grasses. The term for this interaction should be:

Grasses and grazers have evolved mutualism to the extent that one group would not have been possible without the other. The discovery by Dyer says that saliva produced by grazers stimulates grass growth is interpreted as a mutualistic adaptation by which both grass and grazer benefit. Other such adaptations include a basal meristem which is out of reach of most grazers, high palatability of grass leaves and shoots and vegetative reproduction, all of which, we suggest, are responses to selection by grazers and which increase the fitness of individual grass plants.
Which of the following processes will be most adversely affected if microorganisms are removed from forest ecosystem?
Nitrogen fixation and decomposition of organic matter

Nitrogen fixation is the process of fixing atmospheric nitrogen with the help of microorganisms. The atmospheric nitrogen is made available to the plant for its use. Decomposition is the process of breaking down organic matter into simpler form. This process is carried by microorganisms. Hence, if microorganisms are removed from forest system, nitrogen fixation and decomposition of organic matter will be adversely affected. Thus, the correct answer is 'Nitrogen fixation and decomposition of organic matter'.
In a population the rate of addition of new members is more than the members lost. The population shows:

When in a population, the birth rate increases than the death rate, population tends to expand. So, the number of new members that can be added in a population increases than the number of members lost. This causes exponential growth of population.
Organisms which can tolerate narrow range of temperature are called:

Stenothermal organisms are those which are capable of living or growing within a limited or narrow range of temperature. Stenothermal can be divided into two types; polythermal with higher temperature tolerance and oligothermal with lower temperature tolerance. The opposite is a eurytherm, an organism, often specifically an ectotherm, that can function at a wide range of different body temperatures. Example for stenothermal organism is Chionoecetes opilio.
All the following interaction are mutualism, except:
Association of algae and fungi in lichens.
Association of fungi and roots of higher plants in mycorrhiza.
Association of cattle egret and grazing cattle.

Mutualism is the positive interaction in which two organisms live close together and benefit each other equally such as mycorrhiza, plant and animal relation for pollination and lichens. Whereas, cattle egret and grazing cattle possess the symbiotic relationship but not mutualistic because they show commensalism in which cattle egret feed on the bugs and flies that irritate the grazing cattle. In such relation, one organism gets the benefit and other is unaffected.
Organisms in a particular environment have special teeth structure, feet, body shape and body coverings. These adaptations are called __________.

Organisms in a particular environment have special teeth structure, feet, body shape and body coverings. These adaptations are called Structural adaptations.

Structural adaptations are how the animal's body functions or looks on the outside. Body parts (like feet and ears) and body coverings (like fur and scales) are structural adaptations. Blanding's Turtles and other species of turtles have a structural adaptation that is very easy to see — their shells.
Which one of the following is an example of mutualism?
Mutualism is a positive interaction in which both partners are benefited. Lichens are the mutualistic association of fungi and cyanobacteria in which both are benefited.
Which of the following animals is not poikilotherms?

Poikilotherms animals are Sea horse, Salamander and Tortoise.

Poikilotherms, also known as cold-blooded animals, are animals that make use of external sources of heat to regulate their internal temperature. Due to this, their internal temperature varies greatly according to its surroundings. This a reason why they are also known as ectotherms. The organisms belonging to the classes Pieces, Amphibia and Reptilia are poikilotherms.

The term ecology, silent spring and ecosystem were coined by Haeckel, Carson and Tansley respectively. The term biome was not coined by Hutchinson. Biome, as coined and applied by Clements, was not the ecosystem.
Which of these forests are found between the equator and the Tropic of Cancer?

Tropical forests are found between equator and tropic of cancer. The region between them is called tropics and ecosystem found in this area is mostly tropical rain forests, seasonal tropical forests, dry, spiny forests, deserts etc.

The tropics are divided into paleotropics and neotropics which together is called as pantropic.
The relation between algae and fungi in a lichen is:

In lichens, the interaction between algae and fungi is a symbiotic relationship. Algae feed fungi that lack chlorophyll pigments. Fungi, on the other hand, help algae by providing protection and aiding in water absorption.
What is an attribute of the organism that enables the organism to survive and reproduce in its habitat called?

Any attribute of the organism that enables the organism to survive and reproduce in its habitat called adaptation. It is an evolutionary process that takes place from generation to generation. It involves a character or feature or trait that helps an organism in a given habitat.
What are the plants living in the desert called?
The plants grown in the desert are called Xerophytes. They have morphological and physiological features to adapt to an environment with scarce water, such as in deserts or snowy mountains.
In which plants do stomata open at night?

The stomata open during the night in succulents. These plants show an inverted stomatal rhythm as compared to normal plants. The succulents are usually seen in desert areas. To reduce transpiration these plants secrete waxes or resins.
Which is the adaptive radiation is used by poikilotherms to protect against extreme heat?

The poikilotherms use aestivation as a protective mechanism against extreme heat. The suspension of metabolic activities during summer is called aestivation. It helps in maintaining body temperature and avoids water loss in mostly cold-blooded animals such as snails, bees, tortoise, crocodile, etc.
In which plants do sunken stomata is seen?
Sunken stomata are a feature of xerophytes. It is an adaptation made by desert or icy area plants to avoid water loss. Some examples of xerophytes are some Gymnosperm plants, cacti, pineapple, etc.
Which of the following animal excretes solid urine?

Solid urine is excreted by kangaroo rat to avoid excess loss of water. They are rodents and their kidneys have developed mechanisms to highly concentrate their urine. They have longer papilla in their kidneys.
What are plants adapted to grow in the sand called?
The plants adapted to live in the sand are called psammophytes. They have an adventitious root system. They are also found along seas, sands along rivers and large lakes where sand is available.
Light is important for which of the following functions?

Light is an important abiotic factor required by organisms. Light is important for photosynthesis, transpiration, movements, flowering and germination in plants. The main source of light for organisms is sunlight.
Water is important for which of the following functions?

Water is a universal solvent. It determines the growth and development of an organism by maintaining pH clarity, salt content and other solute concentration. It is also required for osmotic regularity.
Which one of the following is an abiotic factor?

The wind is an abiotic factor. It is the motion in the air which helps in flattening of plants against the ground, an example is grasses. Increase in wind leads to excess transpiration which may lead to desiccation of plants.
Which of the following organism requires high humidity for growth?
The plants requiring high humidity for proper growth are known as hygrophytes. Orchids, mosses, lichens need high humidity. The rate of transpiration increases with a decrease in humidity.
What is a group of individuals belonging to the same species within an ecosystem called?

A group of individuals belonging to the same species within an ecosystem is called population. The population is the level of the organization after an organism. Various organisms come together and start residing at the same place known as population.
For what is the interaction among organisms is necessary?
The interaction among organisms is necessary for survival within their environment. Survival is the state of being alive. Organisms are inter-depending on one another of their well-being.
Maximum productivity is found in which of the following ecosystem?
Maximum productivity is found in an ecosystem of tropical rainforests. It is a place where there is no dry season and continuous precipitation. It is also known as evergreen forests.
What are the functional units of nature, where organisms interact with each other and their surroundings?

The functional unit of nature, where organisms interact with each other and their surroundings is called an ecosystem. An ecosystem consists of biotic and abiotic components that interact within a system. The components are linked together with various nutrient cycles and energy flows.
Which of the following process is responsible for fluctuation in population density?

Mortality is responsible for fluctuation in population density. It is the number of individuals died in a population at a specific time. For humans, it is described as a number of deaths per 1000 of the population per year.
The statement, “Two closely related species competing for the same resources cannot coexist indefinitely and the competitively inferior will eventually be eliminated,” was made by whom?

Gause’s competitive exclusion principle provides the above clause. It claims that two species with the same resources cannot coexist under the same population levels. Natural selection will gradually remove the subpar species.
What is the name of the interaction between species when one’s fitness dominates the other’s existence and fitness?

Interspecific competition is the competition between individuals of different species. Under this competition type we also recognize two types of competition but the interaction is between individuals of different species and not individuals of the same population as is the case in intraspecific competition.
Where does direct rivalry between individuals arise when there is interference?
One person limits the reproduction of others
Two different species compete for the same resources and habitat

Interference competition occurs when one person stops others from reproducing. In addition to this, it also hinders the survival of other species. Aggression is one way it might happen, and it’s believed to stabilize consumer-resource systems.
What methods are used to prevent the meeting of a sperm and an egg by the use of a barrier?
The barrier methods create a barrier between the female and male fluids. This acts as a physical barrier that prevents fertilization.
Condoms are examples of barrier methods. A condom is a thin sheath made of latex (rubber), polyurethane (plastic), or natural (animal) membrane that is worn over the erect penis during sex.
What part of male genitalia is covered by a condom?

Condom is an external barrier. It prevents the mixing of seminal and vaginal fluids during intercourse. In males, it is a rubber sheath that covers the penis and thus holds semen at the end of coitus.
What part of female genitalia is covered by a condom?
The condoms work for both males and females. These act as a physical barrier between sperms and eggs. In females, they cover the vagina and cervix, thus holding the ejaculated semen of the males.
Which is a popular brand of condoms designed for males?
Nirodh is a well-known brand name of condoms for males in India. This was popularized across India by many organizations to encourage the use of contraceptives.
Apart from preventing conception, condoms are also known to prevent transmission of ______.

Condoms prevent the mixing of female and male fluids during intercourse. Thus any pathogens are also prevented from being transferred. The Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs) are thus prevented by condoms.
STDs are sexually transmitted diseases. These diseases transfer via sexual contact. The use of contraceptives like condoms can prevent this transmission.

AIDS stands for Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome. It is a syndrome comprised of many diseases that target the immune system by rendering it deficient for any attack. Thus, the body of the patient is prone to many opportunistic infections.
Which of the following is not a property of condoms?

Both males and females can use condoms. Being external barriers and non-invasive, they can be self-inserted and thus provide privacy to the user. Additionally, being made of rubber or latex, they can be disposed of easily.
Which of the following barrier device is not made of rubber?
Cervical caps, vaults, and diaphragms are female contraceptive devices made of rubber. These are barrier contraceptives. CuT is an Intra-Uterine Device made of copper.
Diaphragms, cervical caps, and vaults are used to cover _______
Diaphragms, vaults, and cervical caps are barrier methods for females. They cover the cervix during coitus, thus preventing fertilization and pregnancy.
Which of the following barrier method is not reusable?

Cervical caps, vaults, and diaphragms cover the female cervix. These are made of rubber and inserted inside. These are reusable. Condoms, on the other hand, are designed for one-time use and hence disposable.
What methods are inserted into the uterus through the vagina to prevent pregnancy?
Intrauterine devices are inserted into the uterus through the vagina. Expert doctors do this. It is a contraceptive measure.
IUDs stand for Intra Uterine Devices. These are designed to be inserted through the vagina into the uterus.
Which of the following is a non-medicated IUD?
Lippes loop is a non-medicated IUD. It is made of an inert plastic material and can be used for longterm use.
Which of the following is not a copper releasing IUD?
The copper releasing IUDs include Cu7, CuT, and Multiload 375. LNG-20 instead releases progestin, which is a hormone.
Which of the following IUDs work by releasing hormone?
Proestasert is an IUD. It works by releasing the hormone progesterone. This prevents pregnancy and hence acts as a contraceptive measure.
By preventing mixing of vaginal and seminal fluids

IUDs are intrauterine devices. They do not act as a barrier between vaginal and seminal fluids. Also, they do not affect the ovary or the egg. They work by enhancing the phagocytosis of sperms and thus reducing the probability of sperm entering the fallopian tube to fertilize the egg.
How do Cu ions in copper releasing IUDs prevent fertilization?
By reducing the motility of the sperms
By increasing the motility of the sperms
By causing the females to expel out the sperms

Copper releasing IUDs include Cu7, CuT, and Multiload 375. These work by dampening the motility of the sperms. This reduces the ability of sperm to cross the barriers of the uterus before reaching the fallopian tube and thus prevents fertilization and pregnancy.
What is the unique feature of hormone-releasing IUDs?
Increasing the release of sperms by male
Rendering the uterus unsuitable for the fertilized egg to implant

The hormone-releasing IUDs are very strong and have fewer side-effects. These stimulate the body’s mechanisms to prevent fertilization. They render the cervix hostile for sperms and also make the uterus not suitable for the blastocyst to the implant. Thus, even if fertilization occurs, the chances of it leading to pregnancy are almost nil.
What are the contraceptives delivered via the oral cavity called?

Oral contraceptives are delivered via the oral cavity. These come in the form of tablets or pills. They pass through the digestive tract and hence come in capsules that protect it from the acidic environment of the stomach. They are released in the small intestine where it is absorbed through the villi.
Which of the following hormonal dosage is given as an oral administration to prevent pregnancy?

Oral administration is hormonal shots of progesterone, estrogen, and their combinations. These are contraceptives for females. Progesterone is normally released by corpus luteum in the case of an unfertilized egg to prevent further development of the uterine wall and to stimulate contractions of the uterus to expel the egg. Progesterone shots do the same job and forces the fertilized egg out in the form of menses.

Oral contraceptives are delivered in the form of tablets. Hence these are called oral pills. They come in the form of capsules since the drug has to pass through the digestive tract which has an extremely low pH. The capsule is designed so that the drug is released only in the small intestine, where it is absorbed into the blood.
At what phase of the menstrual cycle should the dosage of pills start?

Pills are oral contraceptives. They should be taken daily for 21 days from the onset of menses. The first pill should be taken in the menstrual phase. This will prevent the release of egg in the next cycle.
When should a female take an oral pill?

The oral pills are weak contraceptives and should be taken daily by the female for a period of the first 21 days of the menstrual cycle. This has to be continued across all cycles until which the female wants to prevent conception.
Which of the following is not the function of an oral pill?
Oral pills are hormonal doses and work by many different routes. These range from inhibiting ovulation, implantation, and preventing entry of sperms through the cervix.
What is the nature of components in Saheli?
Saheli is an oral contraceptive that has been widely popularized in India. It is safe with very few side effects. It is made up of non-steroidal compounds.
What is the frequency of intake required for Saheli to work?

The oral contraceptive called Saheli is different from other hormone-releasing oral pills in the sense that it is non-steroidal. This gives it the advantage of having high dosage content, and thus lesser frequency of intake is needed. It can be taken once a week.
What contraceptives are placed under the skin?

Implants are placed under the skin. They release hormonal doses to inhibit pregnancy. Although effective, they have many side-effects ranging from irregular menstruation, weight gain, abdominal pain, headaches, depression and so on.
What contraceptive cannot be used after unprotected intercourse?
Condoms are aimed at preventing the mixing of vaginal and seminal fluids. They will not prevent pregnancy after intercourse. Pills, implants, and injections can do the job.
If a flower is modified shoot, floral organs calyx, corolla, androecium and gynoecium are:

If a flower is modified shoot, floral organs calyx, corolla, androecium and gynoecium are Modified leaves only.

The flower is considered to be a modified shoot that is borne on the condensed thalamus. The thalamus shows four nodes with highly condensed internodes. These four nodes give rise to four whorls of the flower. So, the calyx, corolla, androecium and gynoecium are modified leaves that perform the function of protection, attraction, production of gametes respectively.
Proximal end of the filament of stamen is attached to the:

Proximal end of the filament of stamen is attached to the thalamus or petal.

Thalamus is the basal thickened part of the stem to which all floral appendages are found attached. Petals are the colored structural unit of the corolla.  The placenta is the region of the wall of the ovary to which ovules are found attached. A stamen consists of anther and filament. Anther is a broad knob part of the stamen that contains two long and cylindrical microsporangia in its lobes. The middle parenchymatous tissue that joins two anther lobes together is termed as connective tissue. The proximal ends of the filament are found attached to thalamus or petals while the distal end carries anther.
The most common type of ovule in Angiosperms is:

The most common type of ovule in Angiosperms is Anatropous.

Anatropous ovule - In this type, the body of the ovule becomes completely inverted during the development such that micropyle lies very close to the funicle. For example, gamopetalae members.
The flower which does not open for pollination are called as:

The flower which does not open for pollination are called as cleistogamous.

Some flowers do not open at all. Self-pollination is the only means of pollination in these flowers. These flowers are called Cleistogamous flower. The other flowers that open for pollination are called Chasmogomous flower.
A typical flower with superior ovary and other floral parts inferior is:

A typical flower with a superior ovary and other floral parts inferior is hypogynous.

  • A typical flower which has ovary placed superior with respect to the other floral organs is called hypogynous. The other floral organs are attached below the ovary to the receptacle. 
  • Epigynous flowers have an inferior ovary.
  • Perigynous flowers have a half-inferior and half-superior ovary.

Insect pollinated flowers are colorful and contain nectar.

Insect-pollinated flowers are large, have brightly colored petals, are often sweetly scented, usually contain nectar- to attract insects.  Its pollen are often sticky or spiky - to stick to the legs and body of insects.
Which of the following flower contain both stamens and pistils?

Perfect flowers contain both stamens and pistils.

A bisexual flower is a flower that contains all the four whorls such as petals, sepals, the male reproductive structure (stamen) and female reproductive structure (pistil). So, it is also called as a complete or perfect flower.
The process of removing stamens of a flower during the hybridization process is called:

Emasculation is the removal of stamens or anthers or killing the pollen of a flower is known as emasculation. 

In bisexual flowers, emasculation is essential to prevent self-pollination. In monoecious plants, male flowers are removed or male inflorescence is removed.

A typical angiosperm embryo sac, at maturity, though 8-nucleate is 7-celled. 

At the time of fertilization, the female gametophyte has 3 antipodal cells + 2 synergids + 1 egg cell + 1 central cell, which equals a 7-celled structure. But the central cell has 2 polar nuclei, which makes it 8-nucleate. Therefore,  at maturity, the gametophyte is 7-celled and 8-nucleated.
Even in absence of pollinating agents seed-setting is assured in:

Even in absence of pollinating agents seed-setting is assured in Commelina.

  • Salvia is pollinated by insects by the turn pipe mechanism.
  • Fig is pollinated by a wasp. The wasp lays egg in the fig fruits and in turn fig is pollinated.
  • Commelina is a cleistogamous flower which never opens. The pollen from anther lobe fall on the stigma of the same flower and thus, pollination is not dependent on any external agency i.e. pollinators.
  • Zostera is a marine grass which is pollinated inside water.
Male and female flowers are present on different plants (dioecious) to ensure xenogamy, in:
The plants in which male and female flowers are brone on separate individuals, are referred to as dioecious plants. e.g. papaya, date palm. Dioecious plants, exhibit xenogamy.

Feathery stigma occurs in wheat.

Wheat is an anemophilous plant. Its flowers are not very showy. They do not have petals or sepals. Each female flower consists of an ovary from which two styles emerge, finished with two feathery sticky stigmas to catch pollen.
Plants with ovaries having only one or a few ovules are generally pollinated by:

Plants with ovaries having only one or a few ovules are generally pollinated by wind.

Wind pollinated flowers generally have one or few ovules in ovaries, it increase the probability of successful pollination of each ovule.
Which of the following is not a water pollinated plant?

Cannabis is not pollinated by water instead it is pollinated by wind.

Characteristics of wind-pollinated plants are:

  • Flowers are small and dull in colour
  • Flowers do not produce nectar and fragrance
  • Anther produces large quantities of light, dry pollen grains that can be carried by the wind easily
  • Stigma is large, branched, feathery, and hangs outside the flower to trap the pollen grains easily.
Spiny or sticky pollen grains and large, attractively colored flowers are associated with:

Spiny or sticky pollen grains and large, attractively colored flowers are associated with Entomophily.

  • Entomophily takes place through the agency of insects.
  • The pollen grains are sticky or spiny to easily get attached to the body of pollinators.
  • When the insects visit the flowers, their body gets dusted with pollen grains, and when they fly and visit other flowers, they brush against the stigma which being sticky, receives the pollen grains from their body.

Endospermic seeds are found in castor, barley and coconut.

Endospermic seeds are those that have an endosperm in the mature seed. It is fleshy, oily, surrounds the embryo, and functions as the sole food storage organ. Inside the seed coat, a thin and papery cotyledon is present. Monocot plants have endospermic seeds.
In albuminous seeds, food is stored in ________ and in non-albumious seeds, it is stored in ___________.

In albuminous seeds, food is stored in Endosperm and in non-albumious seeds, it is stored in cotyledons.

Albuminous seeds are the seeds which have food stored in the special nourishing tissue called as endosperm that remains persistent till maturity. Cotyledons only act as food sucking organs and not food storage organs e.g., Castor seed. Non-albuminous seeds are the seeds which have the stored food and the cotyledons in a special structure called as a kernel. It does not remain until the embryo is mature. e.g. Pea seed.
Peristent nucellus is called as _________ and is found in _________.

Peristent nucellus is called as Perisperm and is found in black pepper.

In some seeds, remains of nucellus persist. This residual nucellus which persists in the seed is called perisperm, e.g., black pepper, coffee, castor, cardamom, Nymphaea.
Identify the wrong statements regarding post fertilization development.
The outer integument of the ovule develops into tegmen.
The fusion nucleus (triple nucleus) develops into endosperm.

'The outer integument of the ovule develops into tegmen' is wrong.

After fertilization has occurred in the ovule, many post fertilization changes take place like:

  • Ovary wall develops into the pericarp of the fruit.
  • Outer integument develops into testa and inner integument develops into tegmen.
  • Ovule develops into the seed.
  • Ovary develops into the fruit.

Polyembryony commonly occurs in citrus.

Polyembryony refers to the phenomenon of having more than one embryo in the same seed. In Citrus, a seed has 2−40 embryos, one normal embryo and the rest adventitive embryos(mostly nucellar). In adventitive embryony, an embryo develops directly from a diploid cell other than egg like that of nucellus and integument, e.g., Citrus, Opuntia.
Which of the following is the correct sequence of events of sexual reproduction in a flower?

The sequence of events in reproduction in flowers:

(1) Pollination - It is the process by which pollen is transferred from anther and stigma.

(2) Fertilization - Is the process of fusion of male and female gamete. Once the pollen tube enters into synergid male gametes are released. One male gamete fuses with an egg and forms a diploid cell zygote and this is called syngamy. Other male gamete fuses with two polar nuclei to form endosperm and this is called triple fusion because of the fusion of three haploid nuclei. The whole process is called double fertilization.

(3) Embryo formation - Development of embryo from the zygote.

(4) Seedling - Seed enclose embryo and covered by a seed coat.
How many meiotic divisions are required for the formation of 100 pollen grains?

25 meiotic divisions are required for the formation of 100 pollen grains.

Each microspore mother cell or pollen mother cell (PMC) or reduction division(meiosis) gives rise to 4 pollen grains. Hence, to form 100 pollen grains, 25 meiotic divisions are required.
One of the most resistant biological material present in the exine of pollen grain is:

One of the most resistant biological material present in the exine of pollen grain is Sporopollenin.

Outer layer (exine) of pollen grain is made of a highly resistant substance called sporopollenin. Sporopollenin is not degraded by any enzyme. It is not affected by high temperature, strong acid or string alkali. Because of sporopollenin, pollen grains are well preserved as fossils.
What is the function of germ pore?

The function of germ pore is Initiation of pollen tube.

Germ pore is the place on pollen grains exine, where the sporopollen is absent. It helps in formation of pollen tube by intine.
________ of the pollen grain divides to form two male gametes.

Generative cell of the pollen grain divides to form two male gametes.

The development of the male gametophyte in angiosperms is called as micro gametogenesis. Pollen grain is the first cell of a male gametophyte. This cell undergoes only two divisions, with the result of first division two cells are formed - a large vegetative cell and a small generative cell. The second division is concerned with generative cell only. This division may take place either in pollen grain or in the pollen tube and gives rise to two male gametes. So, the correct answer is 'Generative cell'.
When pollen grain is shed at 3-celled stage, name the cells it contains:

When pollen grain is shed at 3-celled stage, name the cells it contains 1 vegetative cell and 2 male gametes. 

It usually appears as fine dust. Each pollen grain varies in shape and structure. It is found in the male structure of the angiospermic plant. In gymnosperm it is found in male cones. Pollen itself is not a male gamete. It comprises one or more vegetative cells and a reproductive cell.
_______ flowers are invariably autogamous as there is no chance of cross pollen landing on the stigma.
Cleistogamous are a type of automatic self-pollinating plants that can conduct pollination through non opening self-pollinating flowers, especially in peanuts and peas.
___________ is the transfer of pollen grains from anther to the stigma of another flower of the same plant.

Xenogamy is defined as the transfer of pollen grains from the anther of one plant to the stigma of a different plant. This type of pollination helps in breeding genetically different types of pollens.
_______ is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of another flower of the same plant.
Geitonogamy is a kind of self-pollination wherein the fertilization of a flower is done by a pollen from another flower on the same or genetically identical plant.
________ flowers produce assured seed set even in the absence of pollinator.
Cleistogamous plants are self- pollinating flowers that do not open and fertilize within the bud. Some examples of flowers that propagate cleistogamy-peanuts and peas.
What did David Tilman’s experimental plot show?
More variation from year to year in the total biomass
More species showed less variation from year to year in the total biomass

George David Tilman is an American ecologist. He performed long-term ecosystem experiments using outdoor plots. Through his plots, he provided some tentative answers such as more species showed less variation from year to year in the total biomass.
For what reason is rich biodiversity important?

Biodiversity is the variety and variability of all the levels of biological organization (plant and animal life) on Earth. Throughout the world, the diversity of plants and animals is not uniform that is uneven distribution is observed. For ecosystem health, rich biodiversity is essential.
Paul Ehrlich, a Stanford ecologist gave the ‘Rivet popper hypothesis’. This hypothesis provides a perspective on what might happen if a few species of the planet are extinct.

An ecosystem is joined by thousands of species, if a problem occurs causing a species to become extinct, it may not affect the proper functioning of the ecosystem initially, but as more and more species are removed, the ecosystem becomes dangerously weak over a period of time. Which hypothesis gave this sentence?

Paul Ehrlich, a Stanford ecologist gave the ‘Rivet popper hypothesis’. It states that an ecosystem is joined by thousands of species and if a problem occurs leading to the extinction of few species, it may not affect the ecosystem initially but as more and more species are removed, the ecosystem becomes weak. This will hamper the survival of living species to a greater extent.
What is considered as the rivet in the ‘Rivet popper hypothesis’?

Paul Ehrlich, a Stanford ecologist gave the ‘Rivet popper hypothesis’. In this hypothesis, he considered species as a rivet. This hypothesis provides a perspective on what might happen if a few species of the planet are extinct.
What will happen if instead of 20,000 we have only 15,000 species of birds on Earth?
Serious threat to the safety of the ecosystem

An ecosystem consists of biotic and abiotic components that interact within a system. If there is a decrease in the number of bird species, the prey (food that birds eat) and predator (animals eating those specific birds) both will be affected causing serious harm to the safety of the ecosystem.
What would happen if the Western Ghats ecosystems are less functional?

An ecosystem consists of biotic and abiotic components that interact within a system. The Western Ghats ecosystems are the biodiversity-rich regions. If they become less functional, it will cause damage to the ecosystem leading to the extinction of many important species.
How is the diversity of plants and animals throughout the world?

Biodiversity is the variety and variability of all the levels of biological organization (plant and animal life) on Earth. Throughout the world, the diversity of plants and animals is not uniform that is uneven distribution is observed.
For many groups of animals or plants, which is the most well-known pattern in diversity?

The latitudinal gradient has the most well-known pattern in diversity having many groups of animals and plants. A decrease in the diversity of species is observed while moving from the equator toward the poles.
What happens to species diversity as we move away from the equator towards the poles?

The diversity observed at the species level is known as the species diversity. It is the number and abundance of each species in a particular area. A decrease in the diversity of species is observed while moving from the equator towards the poles.
How many species of birds are located in Colombia that is located near the equator?

Colombia which is located near the equator harbors 1,400 species of birds. Columbia is a country located in South Carolina, USA. It is the second most mega-diverse country in the world, ranking first in bird species.
How many species of birds are located in Greenland?

Greenland is located between the Arctic and the Atlantic Ocean is the world’s largest island. The island is sparsely populated in vegetation and is home for 56 bird species of which most of them are seabirds.
Which place has the greatest biodiversity on Earth?

The tropical Amazonian rainforest situated in South America has the maximum biodiversity on Earth. Situated in the tropical region, it is home for 378 reptiles, 427 amphibians and mammals, 1,300 birds, 3,000 fishes, 40,000 plants, and 1,25,000 invertebrate species.
Which environments are less seasonal, relatively more constant, and predictable?

The less seasonal, more constant, and predictable environments are the tropical environments. Due to such environmental consistency, they promote specialization in the niche and lead to a greater diversification of species.
What energy available in the tropics contributes to higher productivity?

The solar energy contributes to higher productivity in the tropical regions. This leads to more food production which in turn leads to specialization in the niche and leads to a greater diversification of species.
Which region had a long evolutionary time for species diversification?

Tropical environments have remained undisturbed for millions of years that are a long evolutionary time. Due to such environmental consistency, they promote specialization in the niche and lead to a greater diversification of species.
Who observed that within a region species richness increased with increasing the area explored, but this increase is only up to a limit?

Alexander von Humboldt a German naturalist and geographer explored the South American jungles. Through his observations, he concluded that with the increasing explored area, the species diversification increased. But this increase in the diversity of species was seen only up to a limit.
On a logarithmic scale, how is the equation S = CAz described?
log C + Z log A = log S
-Z log A – log C = log S
On a logarithmic scale, S = CAz is described as log S = log C + Z log A. Here S = Species richness, A = Area explored, Z = slope of the line (regression coefficient), and C = Y - intercept.
In the given figure, if a log-log scale is considered, which line correctly indicates the equation S = CAz?

On a logarithmic scale, S = CAz is described as log S = log C + Z log A. Here S = Species richness, A = Area explored, Z = slope of the line (regression coefficient), and C = Y-intercept. The red line correctly indicates the logarithmic equation S = CAz.
In which range does the value of Z lies?
According to ecologists, the value of Z ranges from 0.1 to 0.2. It is regardless of the taxonomic region or group and the slopes of the regression line are mostly similar.
The Earth consists of how many ant species?
Ants are eusocial (highly social) insects. They live together in organized colonies. There are approximately 20,000 species of ants on the Earth.
How many species of beetles are present on the Earth?
Beetles are a group of winged insects that eat almost everything. They are prominent decomposers, and there are approximately 3,00,000 species of beetles on the Earth.
How many species of fishes are present on Earth?
Fishes are limbless cold-blooded vertebrate gill-bearing aquatic craniate animals. They commonly have fins and are covered with scales. There are approximately 28,000 species of fishes on Earth.
How many species of orchids are present on Earth?

An orchid growing on epiphyte is an example of commensalism. Epiphytes grow on trees for air and sunlight while the tree is not harmed due to its presence. Another epiphyte growing on trees is a fern. There are approximately 20,000 species of orchids on Earth.
Which of the following statements is true?
Diversity exists only at the species level
Diversity exists only at the macromolecular level
Diversity exists at all levels of biological organization
Diversity exists at the genetic level only

Biodiversity is the variety and variability of all the levels of biological organization (plant and animal life) on Earth. The diversity exists not only at the genetic level but at all levels of biological organization.
Edward Wilson popularized the term biodiversity. Biodiversity is the variety and variability of all the levels of biological organization (plant and animal life) on Earth.
Vikramshila Gangetic Dolphin Sanctuary is located in which of the following states of India?

Vikramshila Gangetic Dolphin Sanctuary is in Bhagalpur District of Bihar, India. The sanctuary is 60 kilometers stretch of the Ganges River from Sultanganj to Kahalgaon in the Bhagalpur district. It was notified as Vikramshila Gangetic Dolphin Sanctuary in 1991. Major attractions are the Ganges river dolphins which are classified as endangered on the 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The sanctuary also contains a rich diversity of other threatened aquatic wildlife, including the Indian smooth-coated otter (Lutrogale perspicillata), gharial (Gavialis gangeticus), and a variety of freshwater turtles, and 135 species of waterfowl.​
Keibul Lamjao National Park is located on which lake?

Keibul Lamjao National Park, the only floating park in the world, is located in the Loktak lake. Keibul Lamjao National Park is the only floating National Park in the world. It is the home of the brow-antlered deer which is one of the most endangered deer in the world. It is located in the Bishnupur district of Manipur in India. It is an integral part of Loktak Lake.
Silent Valley National Park is located in:

Silent Valley National Park is located in the Palakkad district in the Nilgiri Mountains of Kerala. It is at the heart of Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve and consists of areas of South Western Ghats rain forests and tropical wet evergreen jungle. River Kunthi passes through it. Silent Valley Park is known for many highly endangered species such as lion-tailed macaque, tiger, gaur, leopard, wild boar, panther, Indian Civet, and Sambhar.
The Buxa Tiger Reserve is located in ___________.

Buxa Tiger Reserve was established in 1983. It was the then 15th tiger reserve in India. Animals found in Buxa Tiger Reserve Indian leopard, Bengal tiger, clouded leopard, giant squirrel, gaur, chital, and wild boar. National Park/Wildlife Sanctuary in West Bengal are West Sunderban Wildlife Sanctuary, Gorumara National Park, Neora Valley National Park, Singalila National Park, Sunderban National Park (STR) Tiger Reserve, and Jaldapara National Park.
The mode of transmission of Hepatitis C is _______.

Hepatitis C is a member of the hepatitis virus group targeting the liver. Transmission occurs primarily through contact with infected blood, such as blood transfusions or the use of contaminated syringes. Consequently, the most common mode of transmission is through contaminated blood.

Minamata disease, also known as Chisso-Minamata disease, is a neurological syndrome resulting from severe mercury poisoning. Symptoms include ataxia, numbness in the hands and feet, muscle weakness, vision impairment, and damage to hearing and speech.
Which of the following diseases has been eradicated worldwide?

Smallpox, a deadly and highly contagious viral disease, afflicted approximately 300 million people throughout the 20th century. The last documented case occurred in Ethiopia in 1977. Following rigorous global vaccination efforts, smallpox was officially declared eradicated in 1980, marking a significant achievement in public health.
Which of the following medicines is widely used in India to treat malaria?
To treat Malaria in India, hydroxychloroquine is used. This medicine is effective, where the disease of Malaria is still prevalent.

Kwashiorkor is a severe deficiency disease caused by a protein deficiency in the diet. Kwashiorkor is a protein deficiency disease that primarily affects infants and children between 1 to 3 years of age. 

Symptoms-

  • Anemia
  • Underweight children
  • Stunted growth
  • Poor brain development 
  • Loss of appetite
For prevention of which disease, BCG vaccine is given?

BCG, short for Bacille Calmette-Guérin, is a vaccine primarily designed to combat tuberculosis (TB) disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, commonly affecting the lungs. It was initially proposed by the WHO Expert Committee on Biological Standardization and has since become one of the most widely used vaccines globally. Notably, the BCG vaccine demonstrates documented effectiveness in protecting children against meningitis and disseminated TB.
Which of the following is the most fatal non-infectious disease?

Cancer is the most fatal non-infectious disease. In 2017, 9.6 million people are estimated to have died from various forms of cancer. While AIDS is the most fatal infectious disease affecting nearly 36.9 million people worldwide. Diabetes and Obesity are also non-infectious diseases but not the most fatal.
Which of the following is not a biological agent that causes disease?
Radiations are physical agents that cause disease along with electricity, pressure, heat, cold, etc. Mycoplasma, virus and fungi are biological agents or pathogens that cause various diseases.
Infectious diseases are transmitted from one person to another by droplet infection, direct contact with infected persons, animal bite, contact with soil or by transplacental transmission.
Which of the following is a Congenital Disease?

Sickle-cell anaemia is a congenital disease. Congenital diseases are contracted before birth due to chromosomal abnormalities or gene mutations or defect in development. Goitre and Kwashiorkor are caused due to deficiency of an essential element while Rheumatoid Arthritis is an autoimmune disease.
Which property is not exhibited by a disease-causing pathogen?

Co-operation is a property not exhibited by a pathogen. Invasiveness of a pathogen is its ability to gain entry into a host and grow. Virulence is the ability of a pathogen to produce disease. Toxigenicity is the power of a pathogen to form toxins capable of damaging host cells.
Which of the following is not a Degenerative disease?
Degenerative diseases are those diseases which are caused by ageing resulting in malfunctioning or decreased deficiency. For example-Hypertension, Atherosclerosis, Alzheimer’s disease etc.
Which of the following does not affect health?

Genetic Disorders are the deficiencies or the defects with which a child is born or inherits them from parents. Infections are also a disease caused by the invasion of microorganisms. Life Style includes how much exercise we do daily and how much healthy do we eat every day. So Genetic Disorders, Infections and Lifestyle affect our health.
Haemophilus influenzae causes Pneumonia. Salmonella typhi, Myxovirus influenzae and Bordetella pertussis cause Typhoid, Influenza and Whooping Cough respectively.
Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding Pneumonia?

Pneumonia occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in alveoli. Its symptoms include Fever, Chills, headache, cough, and lips and nails turn bluish. However, blood in faeces does not occur in Pneumonia.
Clostridium tetani releases which type of toxins which further cause tetanus?
Clostridium tetani releases Tetanospasmin which is a neurotoxin, acting on the neuromuscular junctions and thus causing paralysis of the muscles. It causes severe pain and is fatal.
Which of the following is the combined vaccine given to children for protection against Tetanus, Whooping cough and Diphtheria?

DPT vaccine is the combined vaccine given to children for protection against tetanus, whooping cough and diphtheria. D here stands for Diphtheria, P here stands for Pertussis (Whooping Cough) and T stands for Tetanus. DPT vaccine should be given within 6 weeks of the birth of the baby.
Which of the following is incorrect regarding Typhoid disease?
Symptoms include High fever, weakness, constipation and loss of appetite
Intestinal perforation and death may occur in severe cases

Salmonella typhi causes typhoid disease. It is a gram-negative bacterium. These pathogens generally enter the small intestine through contaminated food and water and migrate to other organs through blood.
Which of the following tests is used to confirm Typhoid Fever?
Widal Test is used to confirm Typhoid Fever. Schick Test is used to confirm Diphtheria, Pap Smear Test is used to detect cervical cancer and Tourniquet Test is used to diagnose Dengue fever.
Which of the following is the carrier of Plague bacteria?

Plague spreads from rat through rat flea-Xenopsylla. They carry the pathogen Yersinia pestis. When the infected rats die, the fleas leave their body and can even bite the man and inject plague germs into his/her blood.
Which of the following is not a type of plague?

Plague is of three basic forms- Bubonic plague is the most common type in which formation of buboes or swelling of lymph nodes occur in the neck and armpit regions. Septicemic plague causes the rupturing of blood vessels causing black patches on the skin and pneumonic plague is the only form of plague that can be transmitted from person to person.
What is the full form of BCG vaccine?

The full form of BCG vaccine is Bacillus Calmette–Guérin. It is an attenuated vaccine. It is commonly used for the prevention of tuberculosis disease. It is generally given between birth to six months of the baby.

Leprosy was first discovered by Hansen and that’s why it is commonly known as Hansen’s disease. Karl Joseph Eberth was the first person to discover typhoid, Robert Koch was the first person to discover tuberculosis and Dr Jay Levy’s group played an important role in the discovery of HIV.
Which medication is commonly given to treat Leprosy?

DDS (diamino-diphenyl sulphone) is commonly given to patients suffering from Leprosy. Ibuprofen is used to treat inflammation, pain and fever. Ciprofloxacin is given to patients suffering from typhoid fever and Isotretinoin is an antibiotic used to treat severe form of acne.
Food poisoning is commonly caused by which species of Clostridium?

Clostridium botulinum commonly causes food poisoning in human beings. Clostridium tetani and Clostridium perfringes cause tetanus and gangrene respectively. Clostridium butyricum is a great prebiotic for our gut and maintains the health of our brain.
What is the first sign or symptom of tetanus?

Stiffness of neck is the first symptom of Tetanus. Then there is difficulty in swallowing and chewing. Subsequently, spasms of muscles of the jaw and face take place. There is severe pain. It is often fatal disease.
Small Pox vaccine is which kind of vaccine?

Small Pox vaccine is an Attenuated Vaccine. Attenuated Vaccines are made by weakening the virulent properties of the pathogen. These vaccines provide Artificial Active Immunity and vaccination is the best preventive remedy for Small Pox.
Malignant tertiary malaria is caused by Plasmodium:

Malignant tertian malaria, also known as severe or complicated malaria, is primarily caused by the Plasmodium falciparum parasite. Plasmodium falciparum is the most dangerous and responsible for the majority of severe malaria cases in humans, even though all four Plasmodium species can cause malaria in humans.
Which blood cells reproduce HIV and produce progeny viruses?

HIV replicates and produces progeny viruses in CD4+ T Cells, also known as T- helper cells (TH cells). These cells play a crucial role in the body’s immune system and are essential for fighting off infections. Without them, the body’s immune system would become weakened and unable to fight off infections.
Which of the following is used in the production of the recombinant Hepatitis B vaccine?

The production of the recombinant Hepatitis B vaccine involves the use of yeast. Specifically, the yeast species Saccharomyces cerevisiae is commonly used as a host organism for the production of recombinant Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), which is a key component of the Hepatitis B vaccine.
Sunlight is the main source of energy of autotrophs. These are the organisms (producers) that can produce their own food using light, water, carbon dioxide, or other chemicals.
The phytoplankton, zooplankton, and fungi are components of which ecosystem?
The phytoplankton, zooplankton, and decomposers are components of a pond ecosystem. Phytoplankton are autotrophs; zooplankton are heterotrophs while fungi act as decomposers.
The decomposers decompose and mineralize the organic dead matter. They break down this organic matter into simple components that are reused by autotrophs as their source of nutrition and energy.
The autotrophic components are consumed by heterotrophs. A heterotroph (consumer) is an organism that cannot produce its own food and therefore derives its intake of nutrition from other sources.
What is the movement of energy towards the higher trophic levels and its distribution and loss as heat to the lower trophic levels in the environment?

The movement of energy from the higher trophic levels and its distribution and loss as heat to the lower trophic levels in the environment is unidirectional. It means the energy moves in one direction only that is from the higher to the lower-most level.
What is the rate at which solar energy is converted and stored by the producers per unit area over a time period called:

The rate at which solar energy is converted and stored by the producers per unit area over a time period is called primary productivity. The solar energy is converted into usable form by plants with the help of photosynthesis.
What is the rate of biomass production called:

Productivity is the rate of new biomass production by an individual, population, or community within an ecosystem. The productivity of an ecosystem depends on several environmental factors such as light, water, temperature, precipitation, etc.
Which of the following is a unit of primary productivity?

The unit of primary productivity is the weight (g-2) or weight (kcal m-2). The rate at which solar energy is converted and stored by the producers per unit area over a time period is called primary productivity.
What are the two types of primary productivity?

Gross primary productivity and net primary productivity are the two types of primary productivity. The rate of production of organic matter during photosynthesis is defined as the gross primary productivity, while the net primary productivity is the energy left after the respiration i.e. the gross primary productivity subtracted by respiration losses.
By what letter is the gross primary productivity designated?
The gross primary productivity is designated by the GPP. The rate of production of organic matter during photosynthesis is defined as the gross primary productivity.
By what letter is the net primary productivity designated?
The net primary productivity is designated by NPP. The net primary productivity is the energy left after the respiration i.e. the gross primary productivity subtracted by respiration losses.
What is the available biomass for the consumption of heterotrophs?

The available biomass for the consumption of heterotrophs is the net primary productivity (NPP). The heterotrophs are herbivores and decomposers. NPP is the gross primary productivity subtracted by respiration losses.
NPP is the energy left after the respiration i.e. the gross primary productivity subtracted by respiration losses. NPP = GPP – R.
What is the rate of production of new organic matter by heterotrophic organisms (consumers) called?

The rate of production of new organic matter by heterotrophic organisms (consumers) is called secondary productivity. The secondary producers feed on primary consumers to fulfill their energy requirements.
Which of the following contributes to the highest rate of primary productivity?

The grasslands contribute to the highest rate of primary productivity. Grasslands or transitional landscapes are the open areas of land where the vegetation is dominated by grasses and other herbaceous (non-woody) plants.
What is a frog that feeds on insects example of?
A frog that feeds on insects is an example of a secondary consumer. The secondary consumers feed on primary consumers to fulfill their energy requirements.
What is the balance between photosynthesis and respiration and other plant losses as death referred to?

The balance between photosynthesis and respiration and other plant losses as death is referred to as the net primary productivity. The NPP is the energy left after the respiration i.e. the gross primary productivity subtracted by respiration losses.
What is the rate of storage of organic matter not used by consumers?

The rate of storage of organic matter not used by consumers (heterotrophs) is called net productivity. It is equal to the net primary production minus consumption by the heterotrophs in a unit of time.
Which of the following is a unit of net productivity?
The unit of net productivity is the production of \(\frac{C}{g}\) m2/day. The rate of storage of organic matter not used by consumers (heterotrophs) is called net productivity.
Which organism is said to be a farmer’s friend?

The earthworm is said to be a farmer’s friend. The earthworm is a tubular, segmented invertebrate organism commonly found in soil that survives on eating live and dead organic matter. They improve the health of the soil by breaking down soil substances and loosening it.
Which are the organisms called those who are responsible for the breakdown of complex organic matter into inorganic substances?

The organisms that are responsible for the breakdown of complex organic matter (dead or decaying organisms) into inorganic substances are called decomposers (detritivores). The decomposers or detritivores may include invertebrates, fungus, or bacteria.
What is the process of break down complex organic matter into inorganic substances called?

The physical and chemical process of break down complex organic remains (dead or decaying organisms) into inorganic substances is called decomposition. It is carried out by organisms called decomposers (invertebrates, fungus, or bacteria).
What are the complex organic remains such as dead animal remains, dead plant remains, and fecal matter called?

The organic remains such as dead plants, dead animal remains and fecal matter is called detritus. It acts as the raw material for various organisms such as decomposers. In terrestrial ecosystems, it is called “soil organic matter” while in the aquatic system, it is known as “marine snow”.
Which organisms carry out the fragmentation of detritus?

The process of fragmentation of detritus is done by detritivores. These are also known as decomposers and are the organisms responsible for the break down complex organic matter (dead or decaying organisms) into inorganic substances.
Which of the following is an example of detritivore?

Among the above-given options, a termite is one of the best examples of detritivores. They are essential as they keep the forests healthy. They feed on dead decaying plants and aerate the soil as they move through it.
What is the process of secretion of digestive enzymes by decomposers to convert insoluble complex organic molecules into simple soluble organic and inorganic molecules called?

The process of secretion of digestive enzymes by decomposers to convert insoluble complex organic molecules into simple soluble organic and inorganic molecules is called catabolism. It is the catabolic metabolism in which degradation occurs.
What is the process called when detritivores feed on larger pieces and leave smaller fragments behind?

The process when detritivores feed on larger pieces and leave smaller fragments behind is called fragmentation. It is carried out by many detritivores such as carrion beetles, earthworms, termites, etc.
What is the process of the formation of a dark-colored amorphous substance called?
The process of formation of dark-colored amorphous substance is called humification. This substance is called humus which is highly resistant to any microbial action and decomposes at a slower rate.
What is the dark amorphous organic matter rich in cellulose and lignin that is highly resistant to any microbial action and decomposes at a slower rate called?
