The dark amorphous organic matter rich in cellulose and lignin that is highly resistant to any microbial action and decomposes at a slower rate is called humus. It is formed due to the decomposition of organic remains such as dead plant remains, dead animal remains, and fecal matter.
What is the percolation of the soluble substances formed due to decomposition called?

The percolation of the soluble substances formed due to decomposition into deeper layers of soil is called leaching. In this process, the water-soluble inorganic nutrients get precipitated as unavailable salts by going down into the soil horizon.

The European Federation of Biotechnology (EFB) has given a definition of biotechnology as ‘The integration of natural science and organisms, cells, parts thereof, and molecular analogues for products and services’.
What are the two views does the definition of Biotechnology encompass?

The European Federation of Biotechnology (EFB) has given a definition of biotechnology that encompasses both traditional view and modern molecular biotechnology. Traditional biotechnology is mainly based on fermentation technology using micro-organisms. Modern biotechnology is a combination of biology and production technology based on genetic engineering.
The two core techniques that enabled the birth of modern biotechnology are _____.
genetic engineering and maintenance of a sterile environment

Genetic engineering and maintenance of a sterile environment are the two core techniques that gave birth to modern biotechnology. Genetic engineering uses techniques to alter the chemistry of genetic material and exploit them.

Vaccine is a product of biotechnology. The maintenance microbial contamination-free environment is necessary for chemical engineering processes. This environment enables the growth of the desired organism only. Thus, producing the organism in large quantities for the manufacture of biotechnological products like antibiotics, vaccines, enzymes, etc.
The techniques of _______ overcome the limitation of traditional hybridization procedures.

Genetic engineering is used to overcome the limitation of traditional hybridisation and allows us to isolate and introduce only one or a set of desirable genes without introducing undesirable genes into the target organism.

In a chromosome, there is a specific DNA sequence called the origin of replication, which is responsible for initiating replication. DNA ligase is an enzyme which helps in joining of DNA. Termination sequences are the site at which DNA replication terminates while histones are the proteins around which DNA is wound.
_____ is an autonomously replicating circular extra-chromosomal DNA.

Plasmid is typically a small circular DNA strand in the cytoplasm of a bacterium or protozoan. It is a genetic structure in a cell that can replicate independently of the chromosomes. They are commonly used in recombinant DNA technology.

Restriction enzymes are molecular scissors. They are also known as restrictase. They are short nucleotide sequences that recognize the specific sites and cleave the DNA at or near specific recognition sites within molecules.
Plasmid DNA acts as _____ to transfer the piece of DNA attached to it into the host organism.

A vector is a DNA molecule used as a vehicle to artificially carry foreign genetic material into another cell. Plasmid DNA is commonly used as a vector to insert the gene of interest in the desired organism.
Making multiple copies of the desired DNA template is called ___________.

The term cloning means making multiple copies of the desired DNA template which are genetically identical. This process can be natural or artificial. The clone then replicates itself inside the host body.
Plasmid used to construct the first recombinant DNA was isolated from which bacterium species?

The first recombinant DNA was constructed by Stanley Cohen and Herbert Boyer in 1972. They cut the piece of DNA from a plasmid carrying antibiotic resistance gene in the bacterium Salmonella typhimurium and linked it to the plasmid of Escherichia coli.
In genetic engineering, restriction enzymes cleave the DNA at a specific site known as ________.
Restriction enzymes cleave the DNA at a specific sequence known as recognition sequence. These sequences are highly specific for each enzyme.
Restriction enzymes are also known as restriction endonucleases or restrictase. They are chemical knives (scissors) used in genetic engineering or recombinant DNA technology.
Restriction enzymes belong to a larger class of enzymes called __________.
Restriction enzymes belong to a larger class of enzymes called nucleases. There are two types of nucleases. They are: exonucleases and endonucleases.
The _______ in DNA are base pair sequences that are the same when read forward or backward from a central axis of symmetry.
Palindromes are a group of letters that form the same words when read forward (left to right) or backward (right to left). For example: NAYAN, MALAYALAM, etc.
Fragments of DNA formed after treatment with endonucleases are separated by the technique of _______

DNA is a charged molecule. When fragmented, it can be separated by the technique called gel electrophoresis. It is a technique in which the molecules are separated based on the charge present on that molecule.
Plasmids and ________ have the ability to replicate within bacterial cells independent of the control of chromosomal DNA.

Plasmids and bacteriophages can replicate within bacterial cells without the help of chromosomal DNA. Thus they are self-replicating and autonomous in nature. They have their own replication machinery.
Bacteriophages or simply phages are the viruses that infect bacteria. They are self-replicating in nature. Archaea is a domain of bacteria. pUC is a vector.

The term used to refer to the use of bio-resources by multinational companies and other organizations without proper authorization from the countries and people concerned without contemporary payment is:

The term used to refer to the use of bio-resources by multinational companies and other organizations without proper authorization from the countries and people concerned without contemporary payment is Bio-piracy. It happens when biological resources are taken or exploited without official sanction.
Selectable markers are the genes which code for resistance to _______.

Genes coding for resistance to antibiotics are usually used as selectable markers. They are introduced in an organism especially bacteria along with plasmid. They help in the identification of transformants.
The process by which a foreign DNA is introduced into bacteria is called ______.

Transformation is a process in which a foreign DNA is directly picked up by the bacteria from the surrounding environment. It leads to a change in the characteristics of bacteria. It was first observed by Griffith in 1928.

Antibiotics are the substances that either inhibit the growth or kill bacteria. They are widely used to treat diseases caused by bacteria. Some examples of antibiotics are kanamycin, ampicillin, penicillin, tetracycline, etc.
Insertion of recombinant DNA within the gene encoding for β–galactosidase leads to ________.

Insertional inactivation is the process in which the gene is inactivated due to the insertion of other genes within it or within its coding sequence. This leads to loss of function of that specific gene. Thus, insertion of recombinant DNA within the gene encoding for β–galactosidase will lead to insertional inactivation.
What may complicate the process of gene cloning within the cell?

Recognition site is the sequence of DNA where the DNA is cleaved. The presence of more than one recognition site will lead to several cuts within DNA leading to fragmentation of DNA. This will complicate the process of gene cloning.

Agrobacterium tumifaciens is the bacteria which transfers ‘T-DNA’ within plants. It mostly infects dicot plants. This ‘T-DNA’ is responsible for the formation of transformed cells called tumors from normal plant cells.
Which plasmid of Agrobacterium tumifaciens leads to tumor formation in dicots?

The Ti plasmid in Agrobacterium tumifaciens leads to tumor formation in dicots. ‘Ti’ stands for tumor-inducing. It may contain more than one T-DNA region. This plasmid is modified and used as a cloning vector.
The molecule which dissolves in water is called _______.

The molecule which dissolves in water is called hydrophilic molecules. They are polar in nature which helps them in dissolution in water. Being hydrophilic in nature DNA cannot pass through the cell membrane.
DNA is an example of a hydrophilic molecule. Hydrophilic molecules are water-loving and tend to dissolve in water easily. They carry a positive or negative charge.
Which divalent cations are usually used to make competent cells?

The divalent cations of calcium are used to make cells competent. Calcium is used in the form of a salt of calcium chloride. It increases the efficiency of the bacterial membrane to allow the passage of foreign DNA.
The cells which have the ability to incorporate foreign DNA within them are called ______.
Some bacterial cells have the ability to incorporate foreign DNA within them. These cells are called competent cells. This leads to the alteration of the genetic material of the cell.

HIV finds the white blood cells, called CD4 cells. HIV gets inside the CD4 cell and makes copies of itself. Then, HIV kills the CD4 cell and the new HIV copies find other CD4 cells to get inside and start the cycle again. HIV kills immune system cells that help the body fight infections and diseases.

Poliomyelitis, often known as polio or infantile paralysis, is an infectious disease caused by the poliovirus. Poliovirus is composed of a single-stranded RNA genome and a protein capsid. The genome is a single-stranded positive-sense RNA genome that is about 7500 nucleotides long. The viral particle is about 30 nm in diameter with icosahedral symmetry. Polio is caused by a Virus with a single strand RNA.
In the immune system, interferons are a part of :

Interferons are proteinaceous in nature. These are released by the virally infected cell as a response to the attack. Interferons  belong to the large class of proteins known as cytokines - the molecules used for communication between cells to trigger the protective defenses of the immune system that help eradicate pathogens.
Conjunctivitis can spread through the use of common:

Conjunctivitis is the inflammation of the conjunctiva which is caused due to bacteria. The bacterial growth in the eye may result in reddening, swelling and watering of the eyes. The infection is contagious and spreads from one infected person to other. The towel or the handkerchief which is used to wipe the eye is the source of transmission of the bacterial infection. The other person using the items may also suffer from infection.
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) effects which organ of Human body?

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) primarily affects the liver, It can cause both acute and chronic disease. The virus is transmitted through contact with the blood or other body fluids of an infected person. A vaccine against Hepatitis B has been available since 1982.
Which of the following is a bacterial disease?
Measles, smallpox, and rabies are viral diseases. Tuberculosis is a bacterial disease and it is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
AIDS is caused by HIV. Among the following, which one is not a mode of transmission of HIV?

HIV is transmitted through the exchange of body fluids. This is not involved during shaking hands.

HIV passes between people through blood and certain other body fluids, including semen, pre-seminal fluid, rectal fluids, vaginal fluids, and breast milk. For transmission to occur, the HIV in these fluids must get into the bloodstream of an HIV-negative person through a mucous membrane (found in the rectum, vagina, mouth, or tip of the penis), through open cuts or sores or by direct injection (from a needle or syringe).

Anopheles is Exogenous host for Plasmodium.

Malaria is caused by the protozoan parasite Plasmodium. The life cycle of Plasmodium is characterized by an exogenous sexual phase (sporogony), in which multiplication occurs in female Anopheles mosquitoes and an endogenous asexual phase (schizogony) which take place in the RBCs of the infected host.

Lymphatic filariasis, also known as elephantiasis is a human disease caused by parasitic worms such as Wuchereria bancrofti (most common),  Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori. Symptoms include severe swelling in the arms, legs, breasts, or genitals. The worms are spread by the bites of infected mosquitoes (such as female Culex).
Which branch of biology is helpful in prevention of cancer by identification of certain genes?

Molecular biology is the branch of biology which deals with the structure and function of the essential macromolecules. The major application of molecular biology to prevention and early detection of cancer and other diseases by identification of certain genes.

Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease affecting humans and other animals caused by Plasmodium species. In the female Anopheles mosquito,  gametocytes are taken up with the blood and mature in the mosquito gut. The male and female gametocytes fuse and form an ookinete—a fertilized, motile zygote. Ookinetes develop into new sporozoites that migrate to the insect's salivary glands, ready to infect a new vertebrate host.

Salmonella typhi is responsible for typhoid fever, diagnosed through the Widal test. Streptococcus, a Gram-positive bacterium, is associated with pneumonia, sepsis, and other infections. Giardia, a microorganism found in soil, contaminated food, and water, causes giardiasis. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of tuberculosis, a deadly infectious disease.
Alzheimer disease in humans is associated with the deficiency of :

Alzheimer disease in humans is associated with the deficiency of Acetylcholine.

In studies related to Alzheimer disease, Acetylcholine (ACh), a neurotransmitter essential for processing memory and learning, has been found decreased in both concentration and function in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
Protein products of macrophages, which destroy microbes
Proteins secreted by virus infected cells, which protect non infected cells from viral infection

Interferons are released by host cells in response to the presence of pathogens, such as viruses, bacteria, parasites or tumour cells. It is generally specific to the virus-infected cell. It belongs to the large class of proteins known as cytokines, molecules used for communication between cells to trigger the protective defences of the immune system that help eradicate pathogens.
________ are disease-causing organisms that are so small you need a microscope to see them.

A pathogen is an organism that can produce disease. It is also referred to as an infectious agent or a germ. These include infectious microorganisms such as a virus, bacterium, protozoan, or fungus, which can be observed only under a microscope.
Man in the life cycle of Plasmodium is :

Man in the life cycle of Plasmodium is Secondary host.

A secondary host or intermediate host is a host that harbours the parasite only for a short transition period, during which (usually) some developmental stage is completed. The primary host of Plasmodium is female Anopheles mosquito which first takes in the parasite by feeding on the blood of an infected person. Plasmodium undergoes sexual phase in the mosquito and produces sporozoites. When this mosquito bites the human, the sporozoites are released. Thus, man and other vertebrates are a secondary host.
Which of the following is a large bean-shaped lymphoid organ in the human body?

The spleen, the largest lymphatic organ, maintains fluid balance and hosts red and white pulp tissues. Red pulp filters old red blood cells, while white pulp contains immune cells (B and T cells) that combat infections. Bean-shaped, it stores erythrocytes, lymphocytes, and phagocytes, recycling old red blood cells and storing white blood cells. Additionally, the spleen plays a role in fighting bacterial infections like meningitis and pneumonia.
Which type of pathogen causes the water-borne disease Ascariasis?

Ascariasis, a water-borne disease caused by parasitic pathogens known as roundworms, predominantly affects children. The infection occurs through the ingestion of food or water contaminated with Ascaris eggs found in human feces. Symptoms include abdominal pain, swelling, shortness of breath, fever, and diarrhea. Ascariasis, classified as a neglected tropical disease, is widespread globally, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions.
What percentage of alcohol in human blood causes death?

5.0 percentage of alcohol in human blood causes death. Blood alcohol content/concentration (BAC) is a measurement of alcohol intoxication used for legal or medical purposes. In general, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of .30 or above will put someone at risk for death.
Female culex mosquito is the carrier of which of the following diseases?

Filariasis is an infectious tropical disease caused by thread-like parasitic roundworms, primarily Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. Transmitted by the bite of female culex mosquitoes carrying the larval form of the parasite, it induces swelling in the human body.
Which of the following drug is used in immobilising large animals?

Phencyclidine is a veterinary medicine used in immobilising large animals. A dose of 5 mg causes excitement, analgesia, dysarthria, a feeling of estrangement, a horizontal or vertical oscillation of eyeball, vasospasm of cerebral arteries, insomnia, and chronic schizophrenia.

Which of the following statements is or are true for "Malaria"?

(a) Plasmodium causes malaria.

(b) Malaria pathogen resides in the Red Blood Cells.

(c) Malaria pathogen spreads through a vector.

Malaria, a potentially fatal disease, is caused by various species of Plasmodium parasites transmitted through the bite of female Anopheles mosquitoes. These parasites multiply in human red blood cells, leading to symptoms such as fever, chills, muscle pain, headaches, fatigue, and more severe complications like anaemia and jaundice. Treatment typically involves antimalarial drugs, with chloroquine being one of the most effective options. Prevention strategies include using insect repellents, mosquito nets, screens on doors and windows, and wearing protective clothing to reduce the risk of mosquito bites.
Which of the following is the most accurate and safest technique to diagnose cancer?

MRI is the most accurate and safest techniques to detect cancer of the internal organs. MRI uses strong magnetic fields and non-ionising radiations to accurately detect the presence of any abnormality in the living tissue.
Reena is suffering from vomiting and lack of appetite. The doctor diagnoses it as a viral disease caused due to contamination of water. Reena is suffering from:

Hepatitis is a viral disease. It is inflammation of the liver tissue and it is of two types - acute (resolves within six months) and chronic (lasts longer than six months). It disturbs various metabolic processes such as bile production, excretion, fat and protein metabolism, activation of enzymes and synthesis of proteins. 

Symptoms of Hepatitis:- Fatigue, Vomiting, lack of appetite, Abdominal pain, Dark urine and pale stool, Weight loss.
Which of the following drug is given to patients who have undergone surgery?

Morphine is a very effective sedative and a painkiller. It is very useful in patients who have undergone surgery as it dulls the pain, cause sedation and induces sleep. Effect of its overdose can be overcome by intravenous naloxone.
Which of the following opioids is used as a De-addiction drug?
Methadone is a synthetic opioid used in relieving chronic pain. It is often used as a De-addiction drug for morphine and heroin addicts. However, repeated use may cause addiction.
Which of the following is not an autoimmune disorder?
Influenza is not an autoimmune disorder as it is caused by a virus, Myxovirus Influenzae. Rheumatoid arthritis, Multiple Sclerosis and Chronic hepatitis are some of the autoimmune diseases.
In which of the following diseases the autoantigens are β-cells?
In Insulin-dependent diabetes, the autoantigens are β-cells. Autoantigens are substances of the patient’s body that develop antigenic activity and hence destroy the patient’s body cells and tissues.
In Myasthenia gravis, antibodies start attacking the ______________.

In Myasthenia gravis, antibodies start attacking the acetylcholine receptors present on the sarcolemma, due to which the neurotransmitter i.e. acetylcholine could not bind to its receptors and hence, could not initiate nerve transmission. The skeletal muscles of the patient become weak and lead to paralysis.
Which of the following is a common characteristic of a psychological dependence on drugs?
Craving or overwhelming desire to have drugs

In psychological dependence, the drug gives mental satisfaction. Even the smell, sight or thought of the drug brings about craving or overwhelming desire to have the same. Therefore, psychological dependence is difficult to overcome.
In the production of test tube babies:
Fertilization is internal and fetus formation is external.
Fertilization is external and fetus formation is internal.

The Test tube baby programme involves IVF procedure in which an egg is fertilized with sperm outside the body, under laboratory conditions and then it is implanted in a women's uterus for the development of foetus. So, the fertilization is external but development of foetus is internal.
The Test-tube baby techniques uses one of the following.
The test-tube baby programme employs the technique of in vitro fertilisation (IVF) and zygote intra fallopian transfer (ZIFT) technique.

The study of abnormalities by taking out the amniotic fluid of an embryo is called amniocentesis. It is also referred to as amniotic fluid test or AFT. It is a medical procedure used in prenatal diagnosis of chromosomal abnormalities and determining hereditary diseases of embryo.
To prevent the sperm to come in contact with ova
To prevent the ova to come in the uterus.

Action of vaginal diaphragm is to prevent the sperm to come in contact with ova.

A vaginal diaphragm is a shallow, bendable cup that you put put inside your vagina. It covers your cervix during sex to prevent pregnancy. It help in stopping sperm from joining an egg. In order to work best, it must be used with spermicide( a gel or a cream).
Surgical removal or cutting and ligation of the ends of oviduct is known as:

Surgical methods, also called as sterilisation, are generally advised for the male/female partner as a terminal method to prevent any more pregnancies. 

Surgical intervention blocks gamete transport and thereby prevent conception. Sterilisation procedure in the male is called as vasectomy and that in the female, tubectomy.

Direction: In the following question, two statements are given. One is assertion and the other is reason. Examine the statements carefully and mark the correct answer according to the instructions given below.

Assertion: Periodic abstinence is a natural method where couples abstain from coitus.

Reason: Coitus from days 5-10 should be avoided because this is the time of ovulation.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion
Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect

Periodic abstinence or rythm method is one of the natural method of contraception. In this method the couples are advised to abstain from coitus. This period generally lasts between 10-17 th day of menstrual cycle, a few days before and after ovulation.
Which of the following cannot be detected in a developing foetus by amniocentesis?

Amniocentesis includes extraction of amniotic fluid by insertion of the needle through the abdomen into the uterus and amniotic sac during 14-16 week old pregnancy. Jaundice is metabolic disorder and can not be detected using amniocentesis.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by spirochaetal bacterium Treponema pallidum. Transmission of syphilis is almost always through sexual contact or congenitally through the placenta to a fetus or at birth from an infected mother.
Which of the following STDs are not completely curable?

AIDS, genital herpes and hepatitis B are not completely curable STDs. AIDS is caused by Human Immunodeficiency Virus. Genital herpes is caused by Herpes Simplex Virus and hepatitis B is caused by Hepatitis B Virus.
Which one of the following statements is correct regarding sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)?
A person may contact syphilis by sharing milk with one already suffering from the disease.
Genital herpes and sickle-cell anaemia are both STDs.
The chances of a 5 -years boy contracting a STD are very rare.

Syphilis is caused by bacterium Treponema pallidum. It is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) which is transmitted through sexual intercourse with infected person. Haemophilia is an X-linked genetic disorder of blood, It is not transmitted via any sexual practice. Genital herpes is an STD while sickle-cell anaemia is an autosomal hereditary disorder. The chances of a 5 years old boy contacting an STD are very rare since he is unlikely to have sex at this age. So, the correct answer is 'The chances of a 5-years boy contracting a STD are very rare'.
Main disadvantage of intrauterine contraceptive devices is:
The devices are permanently placed in Uterus and cannot be removed even if couple want to have children
The device has to be inserted by physician in the uterus through vagina
The devices are expelled out without the knowledge of the wearers

There are certain disadvantages of the intrauterine devices. These are expelled without the knowledge of the wearer in about 10 to 15% of the women and they run the risk of becoming pregnant. There is risk of perforation of uterus and infection. They can cause excess menstrual bleeding and pain.
Which of the following statements is wrong regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP)?
In India it is legal up to the 20 th week of pregnancy.
MTPs are considered to be relatively safe during the first trimester.
It needs the assistance of qualified medical practitioners.

The wrong statement is MTPs can't be done without surgery.

MTPs can be done by two methods first is by taking the combination of two hormonal pills but it is feasible up to 9 weeks of pregnancy. Second method is surgical method after 9 weeks of pregnancy surgical method takes place in which fetus and placenta are removed surgically from the uterus.
Which of the following is a non invasive technique to detect fetal disorders during early pregnancy?

Fetal ultrasound is a test done during the pregnancy to check the status, details, and defects of the fetus. In this process, the colored or black and white sonogram (picture) of the fetus, placenta, and amniotic fluid is displayed on a TV screen.
In the rhythm method of birth control, the couple abstain from intercourse:
One week days before and after ovulation

In rhythm method of birth control a couple plans when they will have sexual intercourse based on the female partner's menstrual cycle and avoids intercourse during ovulation, or the time someone's most likely to get pregnant. When done correctly, the rhythm method can be very effective. If egg and sperm can't meet to fertilize, there is no chance of pregnancy. Abstinence has to be practiced on more than just one or two days as the egg is able to be fertilized for one to two days.
Mrs. Mehra, who is 32 years old underwent a surgery to get her oviducts removed after having a girl. Now, she wants another baby. Do you think she can have another baby?
Yes, she can have another baby as her ovaries are still functional to produce an egg.
No, she cannot have another baby because of fertilization of egg place in the oviducts.
No, she cannot have another baby as the hormones associated with the oviduct will not be present.

Mrs. Mehra cannot have the baby as her oviducts have been removed in a surgery. Oviducts receives the eggs ovulated by the ovary which is further implanted in the uterus of the female. If she undergoes a treatment of organ transplant where a new oviduct is placed she can sustain the pregnancy.

MMR stands for maternal mortality Ratio. Maternal mortality ratio = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) × 100,000 The maternal mortality ratio can be calculated directly from data collected through vital registration systems, household surveys or other sources.

IMR stands for Infant mortality rate. It refers to the death rate of infants owing to poor health, developmental deficits, or infections. Increased medications and hygienic conditions have resulted in a decline in IMR.
A rapid decline in which of the following is not associated with a rise in population?

Highly developed medications, treatment options, quick transports, increased number of hospitals have all resulted in a decrease in death rate, MMR, IMR, and infertility. This has resulted in a longer lifespan of humans and also a rise in population.
What is the rate at which the population of a region increased called?

Population growth rate is a measure used to measure the current rate of increase in population in a given region. This can also be used to predict the population for the coming years. This helps in planning and taking appropriate steps to accommodate the new growth.
What is the most effective step to reduce the population growth rate?
Contraceptive methods are promoted by various organizations for small families. These are the most comfortable and most effective methods that can be used to keep the population in check.
Which of the following is not a step taken to keep a check on the population?
Marriageable age rises of females to 18 years and of males to 21 years

To maintain the growth rate of the Indian population, various steps have been taken by the government. An increase in the marriageable age of males and females is one such step. Also, programs like Hum Do Humaare Do and One chid norm also play a role. Contraceptives have been promoted via Television, radio, and newspapers. Reservation of women candidates at workplaces has to do with another issue of inequality and injustice.
What is the principle of natural contraceptive methods?
Contraceptive methods are not harmful. Natural methods of contraception aim to prevent the meeting of ovum and sperm in the fallopian tube.
What contraceptive method prevents coitus during the ovulation period?

One of the natural methods of contraception called periodic abstinence is used to prevent coitus during the 10th to 17th day of the menstrual cycle. This avoids the presence of sperm in the oviduct during the release of an egg.
What is the period 5 days prior, and post-ovulation called?

The period from 5 days before ovulation to 5 days after ovulation is called the fertile period. During the period, there are high chances that if coitus occurs, the sperm can fertilize the released egg.
What is the scientific term for the withdrawal of penis from vagina before ejaculation?

Withdrawal of the penis from the vagina before ejaculation is an example of a natural method of birth control. It prevents sperm from entering the genital tract. Since this, in principle, prevents coitus, it is called “coitus interruptus.”
Withdrawal of the penis from the vagina before ejaculation
Withdrawal of the penis from the vagina after ejaculation

Coitus interruptus is basically a natural contraceptive method. Its purpose is to prevent pregnancy. It works by avoiding the insemination of the female genital tract. During coitus interruptus, the male partner withdraws the penis from the vagina before ejaculation.
What is the absence of menstruation called?

The absence of menstruation occurs after the baby has been delivered, and the mother is lactating to nourish the baby. During this period, the mother cannot get pregnant. This lack of menstruation is called lactational amenorrhea.

Lactational amenorrhea is the inability of a female to menstruate after parturition. This is the time when the female lactates extensively to support the growth and nourishment of the baby. Lack of menstruation removes the burden of blood loss and weakness and also acts as a measure to prevent another pregnancy before the baby is grown sufficiently to feed himself/herself.
Which of the following is not a natural contraceptive method?
Condom is an example of a barrier method. Periodic abstinence, coitus interruptus, and lactational amenorrhea are natural methods.
Natural methods have ______ side-effects and have _____ rate of failure.

Natural methods do not interfere with the normal functioning of the human system in any way. They do not rely on external devices or medications. Hence, they have least or no side-effects. However, they come up with high chances of failure.
The viruses that affect bacteria are known as:

The viruses that affect bacteria are known as bacteriophage. They have the capability to both enter the bacterium and reproduce inside them. Alfred Hershey and Martha Chase worked with these kinds of viruses.
Who proved that DNA was indeed the genetic material through experiments?

Alfred Hershey and Martha Chase conducted groundbreaking experiments in 1952 using bacteriophages to confirm that DNA, not protein, is the genetic material. They labeled the DNA and protein of bacteriophages with radioactive isotopes and found that only the radioactive DNA was transferred to bacterial cells upon infection, conclusively demonstrating DNA's role as the carrier of genetic information.
Which of the following is not a stage in the “Hershey-Chase experiment”?

Conjugation is not a stage in the Hershey-Chase experiment. Instead, the Hershey-Chase experiment focused on bacteriophages, which are viruses that infect bacteria. The experiment demonstrated that DNA, not protein, is the genetic material of bacteriophages.
What will happen when the radioactive DNA is injected into the bacterium?

When radioactive DNA is injected into a bacterium, only radioactive DNA components could be found. This is because the injected radioactive DNA serves as the genetic material that is replicated and transcribed within the bacterium. The radioactive labeling allows for the tracking of DNA molecules and their components, providing evidence of DNA replication and gene expression processes.
Which of the following can be observed alongside with radioactive bacterium as a result of centrifugation?
Radioactivity cannot be detected in the supernatant
Radioactivity can be detected in the supernatant

In the Hershey-Chase experiment, following centrifugation, radioactivity is detected in the pellet containing bacterial cells, indicating that the radioactive DNA has entered the cells. Conversely, the supernatant does not contain detectable radioactivity, confirming that the injected DNA, not RNA, is responsible for bacterial transformation. This outcome supports the conclusion that DNA, rather than protein or RNA, is the genetic material responsible for heredity.
The mRNA first binds to ________ to initiate translation.

The mRNA first binds to the smaller ribosomal subunit to initiate translation. This binding occurs at the ribosomal binding site on the mRNA, allowing subsequent assembly of the larger ribosomal subunit and the initiation of protein synthesis.
Which of the following criterion needn’t be fulfilled by the genetic material?
Should be able to express itself in the form of “Bohr’s characters”
Provision of scope for the mutation that is required for evolution
It should be chemically and structurally stable

A genetic material must be both chemically and structurally stable. It must be able to replicate. It should provide scope for the evolutionary changes. But it should also be able to express itself in the form of “Mendelian characters” and not “Bohr’s characters”. These Mendelian characters refer to the three laws that were proposed by Gregor Mendel.
Which of the following is responsible for the transmission of genetic information?

RNA, particularly messenger RNA (mRNA), plays a crucial role in transmitting genetic information from DNA to the protein synthesis machinery in cells. Through the process of transcription, RNA is synthesized from DNA, carrying the genetic code in the form of nucleotide sequences. This mRNA then serves as a template for protein synthesis during translation, thereby transmitting genetic information to ribosomes where proteins are assembled.
At what rate does the RNA mutate as compared to DNA?

Mutations can be seen in both DNA and RNA. But RNA mutates at a much faster pace in comparison to the DNA. This is due to the lack of stability that is seen in RNA. Likewise, the viruses which contain RNA as their genetic material also mutate at a faster rate.
Which of the following statements is correct regarding DNA and RNA?
DNA is a better genetic material than RNA

DNA is a better genetic material than RNA. DNA is more stable than RNA due to its double-stranded structure and the presence of thymine instead of uracil, which reduces errors in replication. Additionally, DNA has proofreading mechanisms that enhance its fidelity. It provides a stable archive of genetic information, whereas RNA is more versatile in its functions, including catalysis, regulation, and protein synthesis.
A nucleoside differs from a nucleotide. It lacks the:

A nucleoside differs from a nucleotide in that it lacks the phosphate group. A nucleoside consists of a nitrogenous base (such as adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine, or uracil) attached to a pentose sugar (either ribose or deoxyribose), while a nucleotide includes an additional phosphate group attached to the sugar molecule. This phosphate group is crucial for the polymerization of nucleotides into nucleic acid chains, but it is absent in nucleosides.
Which process is termed as “semiconservative DNA replication”?
Presence of only newly synthesised strands in DNA
Presence of only parental strands in DNA
Presence of both parental and newly synthesised strands in DNA
Presence of a hybrid variety of strands

The term semiconservative DNA replication means that the DNA molecule has both a parental and newly synthesised strand by the process of replication. During replication, the template strand of the DNA (the separated strand from the double helical structure) will help in the synthesis of complementary strands.
In which organism was the “Semiconservative theory of DNA replication” first observed?

The “Semiconservative theory of DNA replication” first observed in Escherichia coli. It was proved by Watson and Crick that the DNA replicates semi-conservatively. Later, the same concept was observed in plants and human cells too.
Which organism was used to detect the presence of thymidine on the newly formed DNA in 1958?

Taylor and his colleagues conducted an experiment on Vicia faba in 1958. They used radioactive thymidine to detect the distribution of newly synthesised DNA in the chromosomes of the cells. They proved that the DNA which is present inside the chromosomes replicate semi conservatively.
What does the failure of cell division after DNA replication resulted?
The failure of the cell cycle process results in polyploidy. Polyploidy is a chromosomal abnormality in which two paired sets of chromosomes are present in the cells.
The central dogma of molecular biology (genetic information flow) was modified by the discovery of which of the following?

The central dogma of molecular biology originally described the unidirectional flow of genetic information from DNA to RNA to protein. However, the discovery of reverse transcriptase challenged this notion by revealing that certain viruses, like retroviruses, could convert RNA into DNA. This process, known as reverse transcription, enables these viruses to integrate their genetic material into the host genome.
In which phase of the cell cycle does the process of replication take place in E.coli?
The process of replication will take place during the S phase of the E. Coli bacterium’s cell cycle. During this time, the replication of the DNA and the cell cycle should be highly coordinated.
What will happen if any abnormal changes or mistakes occur during the process of replication?

If any abnormal changes have to occur during the process of replication, mutations in the cells will arise. These changes occur if the DNA polymerase is not fast enough and also if the catalysis process is not done with high rate of accuracy.
Which of the following is the initial “start site“ for the process of transcription?

The promoter region which is present towards the 5’ end of the coding strand is the start site for transcription to occur. These are regions on the DNA where the RNA polymerase enzyme will bind. This leads to the process of transcription.
What is the role of RNA polymerase III?

RNA polymerase III is responsible for transcribing transfer RNA (tRNA) genes into precursor tRNA molecules, which are then processed into functional tRNA molecules. These tRNA molecules play a crucial role in protein synthesis by carrying amino acids to the ribosome during translation. RNA polymerase III is one of the three types of RNA polymerases found in eukaryotic cells and is specifically involved in transcribing small non-coding RNAs, such as tRNAs and some small structural RNAs.
What is the name of the process where the introns are removed and the exons are joined together in a defined order?

The primary transcript consists of both the exons and the introns, and they are non-functional. And so, the introns are removed and the exons are arranged in a well-defined manner. This process is called as splicing.
Which of the following types of RNA undergoes an additional process of capping and tailing during transcription?

Heterogeneous nuclear RNA (hnRNA), also known as pre-mRNA, undergoes additional processing steps such as capping and tailing during transcription in eukaryotic cells. This processing involves the addition of a 5' cap, which consists of a modified guanine nucleotide added to the 5' end of the transcript, and a poly-A tail, which is a string of adenine nucleotides added to the 3' end.
Which of the following is the unusual nucleotide that is added to the 5’-end of the hnRNA during capping?

During capping of heterogeneous nuclear RNA (hnRNA), a modified guanosine nucleotide called Methyl Guanosine Triphosphate (m7G) is added to the 5'-end. This process involves the addition of a methyl group to the guanine base, providing stability to the mRNA transcript and facilitating its recognition by the translation machinery during protein synthesis.
What is the approximate count of the total number of adenylate residues that are added to the 3’-end of the hnRNA during the process of tailing?

During the process of tailing of heterogeneous nuclear RNA (hnRNA), approximately 200-300 adenylate residues are added to the 3'-end. This polyadenylation process, mediated by poly(A) polymerase, contributes to mRNA stability, export from the nucleus, and regulation of gene expression.
Which of the following refers to a proposition which directs the sequence of amino acids during protein synthesis?

Genetic code is responsible for directing the sequence of amino acids during protein synthesis. The change in nucleic acids is responsible for the change in amino acids in the protein. This observation led to the proposition of genetic code.
Who had given the idea of “adapter molecule”?

Amino acids do not have any structural specialties to read a code. Francis Crick came up with an ideology that an adapter molecule will be present. This adapter molecule is capable of both reading the code and also on binding itself to the specific amino acid.
What does the anticodon loop of the tRNA contain?
A site for binding the amino acids
Bases that are complementary to the code

The anticodon loop of tRNA contains nucleotide bases that are complementary to the codon sequence on the mRNA. This complementary pairing allows the tRNA to recognize and bind to the specific codon on the mRNA molecule during translation. By aligning with the mRNA codon through complementary base pairing, the anticodon loop ensures the correct amino acid is added to the growing polypeptide chain according to the genetic code.
In which of the following levels can gene expression not be exerted?

In eukaryotes, the regulation of gene expression occurs at various levels. They are transcriptional level, processing level, transport of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and translational level. Reverse transcriptional level refers to the process by which RNA is converted back into DNA. The gene expression can not be exerted in Reverse transcriptional level.
Which of the following is responsible for the switching on and off of the lac operon?

Lactose is responsible for the switching on of the lac operon in bacteria. In the absence of glucose and the presence of lactose, the lac repressor protein undergoes conformational changes, allowing it to dissociate from the operator region of the lac operon. This de-repression enables RNA polymerase to bind to the promoter region and initiate transcription of the genes involved in lactose metabolism. However, when glucose is present, cAMP levels decrease, resulting in decreased expression of lac operon genes, regardless of lactose availability.
Which of the following methodology is used to identify all the genes that are expressed as RNA in Human Genome Project (HGP)?

The methodology used to identify all the genes that are expressed as RNA in the Human Genome Project (HGP) is Expressed Sequence Tags (ESTs). These are short sequences of cDNA (complementary DNA) generated from mRNAs that represent the expressed genes in a particular tissue or organism.

Darwin's Finches is an example of adaptive radiation. Darwin’s finches also referred to as Galapagos finches, these are many groups of species of Passerine birds. They were first collected by Charles Darwin on the Galapagos Islands during the second voyage of the Beagle. When he saw the birds, he found all of them belonged to the same species but had evolved differently due to their requirements of eating food or saving themselves. As they had adapted new features for their survival, species were diversified into various forms, therefore they were referred to as adaptive radiation.
Which of the following is called the first human-like being (hominid)?

Homo habilis is called the first human-like being (hominid). Homo habilis means ''able man'' or ''handyman'' in Latin. They had human-like hands & feet, which indicates their ability to handle objects with great precision. Their first fossils were found at Olduvai Gorge in northern Tanzania (East Africa). They had a brain capacity of 650 - 800 cc.
Which of the following animal was used by Lamarck to prove his Theory of Acquired Characters?

'Giraffe' was used by Lamarck to prove his Theory of Acquired Characters. It was stated that the giraffe ancestors stretched their necks to reach out to the leaves on higher branches of a tree. The ones with longer neck were more successful in getting food and produced offspring with longer necks. This theory formed the early basis of biological evolution and also influenced Darwin's theory. It was rejected later in the mid-twentieth century because of lack of experimental proof.
Who demonstrated that life originated from pre-existing cells?

Louis Pasteur demonstrated that life originated from pre-existing cells. He determined through his different experiments that life on earth has originated from different living organisms. He performed an experiment to test whether nutrient broth could spontaneously generate microbial life or not. In these experiments, he used swan-necked flasks, in which he killed all the microorganisms. But, within a short time, they got infected again with the regeneration of new microorganisms.
The most accepted line of descent in human evolution is _______.
Ramapithecus → Homo habilis → Homo erectus → Homo sapiens
Australopithecines → Ramapithecus → Homo erectus → Homo habilis → Homo sapiens

The most accepted line of descent in human evolution is: Ramapithecus → Homo habilis → Homo erectus → Homo sapiens

Ramapithecus were primates that existed 15 million years ago. They were hairy and walked like present-day apes such as gorillas and chimpanzees. Ramapithecus were more man-like.

Homo habilis are the first known hominid (human-like) species that existed about 2 million years ago. They had a brain capacity of 650-800 cc. Their bones were discovered among that of Australopithecines.

Homo erectus existed around 1.5 million years ago. They had a large brain size of 900cc. They used to eat meat. Their fossils were discovered in Java in 1891. As their name suggests, they were the first hominid species to have an upright posture.

Homo sapiens existed in Africa and spread to other continents. Modern man (Homo sapiens sapiens) arose during the ice age between 75,000 - 10,000 years ago.
Who proposed that the first form of life could have come from pre-existing non-living organic molecule?

The theory of biogenesis was proposed by Oparin and Haldane. It states that life could have come from pre-existing non-living organic molecules (e.g. RNA, protein, etc.) and that formation of life was preceded by chemical evolution, i.e. formation of diverse organic molecules from inorganic constituents.
In the origin of species by Darwin the concept of competition was taken from which of the following?

In the origin of species by Darwin, the concept of competition was taken from T. R Malthus. He was an English economist who proposed the famous Malthusian theory of population growth. According to this theory, a population grows exponentially while the resources to sustain that population remains linear, resulting in a calamity that reduces back the population. Darwin wrote the book 'On the Origin of Species' in which he explained the theory of evolution by natural selection as 'descent with modification'.

The Malthusian theory influenced Darwin’s theory of evolution where he stated that there exists a ‘struggle for existence’ in nature and ‘survival of the fittest’. ‘Struggle for existence’ refers to the competition for available resources required for survival.
Which of the following does not belong to the Hardy-Weinberg principle?

The statement 'Allele frequency varies from species' does not belong to the Hardy-Weinberg principle. According to the Hardy Weinberg principle, the frequency in a population is always fixed or constant. Any population’s alleles and total genes stay constant and so stable. When a population is in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium for a gene, it is not evolving and allele frequencies will stay the same across generations. This theory states that the frequency of occurrence of alleles of a gene is constant. The gene pool remains constant. The total sum of allelic frequencies remained fixed through generations.
The type of natural selection where more individuals acquire a value other than the mean character value is known as:

The theory of natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin as a mechanism of evolution. The type of natural selection where more individuals acquire a value other than the mean character value is known as directional selection. It occurs when individuals with a trait at one extreme of the phenotypic range have a higher fitness, leading to a shift in the population towards that extreme. It typically results in the gradual reduction or elimination of individuals with traits closer to the mean value, driving evolutionary change in a specific direction.

Select the incorrect statements:

A. The essence of Darwinian theory of evolution is natural selection.

B. Evolution is a directed process in the sense of determinism.

C. The geological history of Earth is not related with the biological history of Earth.

D. During evolution the rate of appearance of new forms is linked to the life cycle.

Evolution is not a directed process in the sense of determinism. It is a random process based on chance events in the environment and chance mutations in organisms. The geological history of Earth closely correlates with its biological history.
Miller in his experiment, synthesized simple amino-acid from:

Miller in his experiment, synthesized simple amino-acid from hydrogen, methane, ammonia, water.

Miller took molecules, which were believed to represent the major components of the early Earth's atmosphere and put them into a closed system. The gases they used were methane \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_4\right)\), ammonia \(\left(\mathrm{NH}_3\right)\), hydrogen \(\left(\mathrm{H}_2\right)\) and water \((\mathrm{H}\) \({ }_2 \mathrm{O}\) ). Next, he ran a continuous electric current through the system, to simulate lightning storms believed to be common on the early earth. Analysis of the experiment was done by chromatography. At the end of one week, Miller observed that as much as \(10-15 \%\) of the carbon was now in the form of organic compounds. Two percent of the carbon had formed some of the amino acids, which are used to make proteins.
According to spontaneous generation, life originated from:

According to spontaneous generation, life originated from only spontaneously. This theory states that life originates from nonliving things or decaying matter like mud, straw etc. spontaneously. This understanding of the origin of life is supported by evidence from fields such as paleontology, molecular biology, and biochemistry, providing a coherent framework for explaining the diversity of life on Earth. It was theory which had no specific explanation.
Which of the following was not included in theory of special creation?
All the living organisms that see today were created as such
The diversity was always the same since creation and will be the same in future
The solar system came from a massive body

Theory of special creation said that life has not changed a bit since its origin. The theory of special creation typically proposes that each species was independently created by a divine force or entity. This theory contrasts with scientific explanations, such as the theory of evolution by natural selection and the Big Bang theory, which are supported by extensive evidence from various scientific disciplines. Our solar system was formed from Big bang and not from a massive body.
Chance elimination of alleles from small population is referred to:

Chance elimination of alleles from small population is referred to genetic drift. When the migration of a section of the population to another place and population occurs, gene frequencies change in the original as well as in the new population. New genes/alleles are added to the new population and these are lost from the old population.  There would be a gene flow if this gene migration, happens multiple times. If the same change occurs by chance, it is called genetic drift. It is expected to be of significance only in small populations.
_______ was the name of the ship in which Darwin sailed around the world.

H.M.S Beagle was the name of the ship in which Darwin sailed around the world. He had set voyage around the world in a ship named H.M.S Beagle. He traveled to different islands to research about evolution. He found out that the existing living organisms had many similarities with life forms that existed millions of years ago.
Which of the following correctly defines evolution?
History and development of race along with variations

Evolution is defined as history and development of race with variations. The term 'evolution' in Biology means gradual changes over generations. Evolution is the change in genetic composition of a population over successive generations, which may be caused by natural selection, inbreeding, hybridization, or mutation.
Which kind of fitness was the fitness referred by Darwin for natural selection?

According to Darwin, reproductive fitness was the fitness required to survive in nature. It is the ability to adapt and get selected by nature. It encompasses traits that enhance an individual's chances of passing on its genes to the next generation. Essentially, organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive, reproduce, and pass on those traits to their offspring. Thus, reproductive fitness reflects the ability of organisms to adapt to their environment and increase their chances of being selected by natural processes to pass on their genetic material.
The name of the island where Darwin visited and discovered adaptive radiation was:

The name of the island where Darwin visited and discovered adaptive radiation was Galapagos. During his voyage on the HMS Beagle in the 1830s, Darwin observed diverse species of plants and animals on these islands. He noted variations among closely related species, which he later identified as adaptive radiation-a process where a single ancestral species diversifies into multiple species to exploit different ecological niches. Darwin's observations on the Galapagos Islands played a pivotal role in the development of his theory of evolution by natural selection.
Miller - Urey experiment is associated with which of the following?

Miller - Urey experiment is associated with evolution. 

The Miller-Urey experiment, conducted in 1952 by Stanley Miller and Harold Urey, aimed to simulate the conditions of early Earth's atmosphere and oceans. They created a laboratory apparatus containing water, methane, ammonia, and hydrogen, which were thought to be abundant in the early Earth's atmosphere. They then subjected this mixture to electric sparks to simulate lightning. The experiment produced organic compounds, including amino acids, which are the building blocks of proteins and essential for life. This experiment provided crucial evidence supporting the hypothesis that the basic building blocks of life could have formed spontaneously under early Earth conditions, thus contributing to our understanding of the origins of life and the process of evolution.
Which food habit of Darwin’s finches lead to the development of many other varieties?

Seed eating habit of Darwin’s finches lead to the development of many other varieties. Darwin finches show a variety of beaks suited for eating large seeds, flying insects and cactus seeds but the ancestral stock of Darwin finches were seed eaters who dwelled on land. To meet their nutritional and ecological demands in order to survive better, they developed beaks modified for eating insects, cactus, fruits, etc.
_______ marsupials were taken as examples of adaptive radiation.

Australian marsupials were taken as examples of adaptive radiation. These were the marsupials which were each different from each other but had a common ancestral stock. They were all within the Australian island continent. The adaptive radiation of Australian marsupials serves as a compelling illustration of evolutionary processes shaping biodiversity in response to environmental challenges and opportunities.
Lemur is a placental mammal that resembles _______ of Australian marsupials.

Lemur resembles spotted cuscus. Lemurs are primates native to Madagascar, while spotted cuscus are marsupials found in Australia and New Guinea. The similarity in their appearance is likely a result of convergent evolution rather than adaptive radiation. The physical resemblance between lemurs and spotted cuscus is likely due to adaptations to similar ecological roles, such as arboreal (tree-dwelling) lifestyles, rather than shared ancestry from adaptive radiation.

Adaptive radiation does not confirm convergent evolution. Adaptive radiation involves the diversification of a single ancestor into various forms to exploit different ecological niches. Convergent evolution, on the other hand, occurs when unrelated species develop similar traits due to similar selective pressures. While adaptive radiation leads to the proliferation of related species in diverse habitats, convergent evolution results in analogous structures or behaviors in unrelated organisms. Although they are distinct concepts, they can occur simultaneously in evolutionary processes, as organisms adapt to their environments through both divergence and convergence.

The interaction of which among the following processes resulted in the evolution of man?

1. Mutation

2. Genetic Recombination

3. Natural Selection

4. Reproductive isolation

The evolution of humans was shaped by the interaction of mutation, genetic recombination, natural selection, and reproductive isolation.

Mutation is a way through which new alleles can be created. Thus, it helps in evolution. 

Genetic Recombination can alter gene activity or protein function can introduce different traits in an organism. Thus, it also helps in evolution. 

Natural selection is the process through which populations of living organisms adapt and change. Thus, it also helps in evolution. 

Reproductive isolation allows organisms to evolve to be different enough that they become distinct species that can no longer interbreed if their populations become contiguous again. Thus, it also helps in evolution
The concept of ''Branching descent'' was given by:

The concept of ''Branching descent'' was given by Charles Darwin. Charles Darwin made a sea voyage around the world on a ship named H.M.S. Beagle. When he arrived at an island called the Galapagos island, he saw some finches and observed differences in the shapes of their beaks. He concluded that this change is due to the different eating habits of the finches thus, he gave the concept of Adaptive radiation or Branching descent.
_________ refers to the gradual change in living organisms over successive generations through mechanisms such as natural selection, genetic drift, and mutation.

Biological evolution refers to the gradual change in living organisms over successive generations through mechanisms such as natural selection, genetic drift, and mutation. These processes lead to the accumulation of genetic changes within populations, driving adaptation to environmental pressures. Evolutionary changes can result in the divergence of species from common ancestors and the formation of new species over time. It is a fundamental concept in biology, explaining the diversity of life on Earth and how organisms have adapted to various environments. Evolutionary theory is supported by a vast body of evidence from fields such as genetics, paleontology, and comparative anatomy.
Which mechanism of evolution involves the differential survival and reproduction of individuals based on their heritable traits?

Natural selection is the process by which organisms with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing on their traits to future generations. This mechanism leads to the adaptation of populations to their environments over time.
Which mechanism of evolution introduces new genetic variation into a population by the movement of individuals or gametes between populations?

Gene flow occurs when individuals or gametes migrate between populations, leading to the transfer of genetic material. This process can homogenize populations genetically or introduce new alleles, influencing the evolutionary trajectory of populations. It is the transfer of genetic material (alleles) between populations through the movement of individuals or gametes. This movement can occur due to various factors such as dispersal, immigration, or pollen transfer.
Which mechanism of evolution is a source of genetic variation, resulting from changes in the DNA sequence of genes?

Mutation is the ultimate source of genetic variation in populations, as it introduces new alleles by altering the DNA sequence of genes. While most mutations are neutral or harmful, some may confer advantages under certain environmental conditions, driving evolutionary change through natural selection.
Use and disuse theory was given by _______ to prove biological evolution.

According to Lamarck, the evolution of life forms had occurred but driven by use and disuse of organs. It was among Lamarck’s basic concepts. Using an organ continuously increases its development whereas disuse of it results in its degeneration.
Genetic diversity is important among various levels of biodiversity. High genetic diversity can be seen only in a single species.
What is the feature of the biosphere?

The biosphere is the total surface and atmosphere integrating all living beings and their relationships of the Earth. The biosphere is heterogeneous in nature and shows immense diversity. Thus heterogeneity is a feature of the biosphere.
How many strains of rice does India have?
India consists of approximately 50,000 strains of rice. Rice is an edible starchy cereal grain, seed of the grass species Oryza. Rice is said to be the most widely consumed staple food.
How many varieties of mangoes does India have?
Mango is an edible stone fruit (drupe) belonging to the flowering plant genus Mangifera. They grow mostly in tropical areas. India consists of approximately more than 1000 varieties of mango.
What is the feature of the biosphere?

The diversity observed at the species level is known as the species diversity. It is the number and abundance of each species in a particular area. Species diversity is one of the important features of the biosphere.
Which organism’s species have greater diversity in the Western Ghats than in the Eastern Ghats?

Amphibians have more species diversity in the Western Ghats than in the Eastern Ghats. A chain of mountains running parallel to India’s western coast (Sahyadri) and the mountain ranges running parallel to the Bay of Bengal are the western and eastern ghats respectively.
What is the feature of the biosphere?

Ecological diversity is one of the important features of the biosphere. It deals with the variations in ecosystems and their overall impact on human existence and the environment within a geographical area.

Evolution is the result of the process of slow and gradual changes in millions of years. As evolution proceeds, organisms become more and more complex. The complexity of organisms can be given by studying various processes of biological organization.
Which community should show less variation in productivity from year to year?

A group of populations is known as a community. It is a group of people who share the same place or live within the same area. Less variation in productivity from year to year is a feature of a stable community.
How do urbanization and an increase in population affect biodiversity?

Urbanization means the increasing number of people that live in urban areas due to shifting from rural areas to urban areas. It affects the population density and leads to more loss of flora and fauna since more space for residence is occupied by humans.
Which of the following is a feature of a stable community?

Resistant to invasions by alien species is a feature of a stable community. It is a group of people who share the same place or live within the same area. A group of populations is known as a community.
What is the protection and conservation of species outside their natural habitat called?

The off-site or the protection and conservation of species (genetic resources) outside their natural habitat (populations of plant or animal species) is known as ex-situ conservation. Areas such as botanical gardens, zoos, Gene banks, and Tissue culture banks are the places were ex-situ conservation is done.
In which approach do we protect and conserve the whole ecosystem to protect the endangered species?

The on-site or the protection and conservation of species (genetic resources) in their natural habitat (populations of plant or animal species) is called in-situ conservation. In this, we conserve and protect the whole ecosystem for the protection of endangered species.
What are the species confined to a particular region and not found anywhere else called?

Endemism is the ecological state of the species being confined to a particular region or only in one geographic region and not found anywhere else. Such species are known as endemic species. Some examples are the Asiatic lion, Purple frog, Sangai deer, Sapria Himalayana, etc.
How many total biodiversity hotspots are present throughout the world?

A biogeographic region with significant levels of biodiversity having a large number of endemic species that are threatened by human habitation is known as a biodiversity hotspot. In all, there are 34 biodiversity hotspots present throughout the world.
How much area of the Earth’s surface does the biodiversity hotspots cover?

A biogeographic region with significant levels of biodiversity having a large number of endemic species that are threatened by human habitation is known as a biodiversity hotspot. In all, there are 34 biodiversity hotspots present throughout the world covering up to 2 % of the Earth’s surface.
What is the number of biosphere reserves present throughout the world?

Biosphere reserves are protected geographical areas where along with flora and fauna human population also forms a part of the system. In all, there are 14 biosphere reserves in India. Nanda Devi, Manas, and Panchmarhi are a few examples of biosphere reserves.
What is the number of national parks India consists of?

A reserved area where activities like forestry, grazing, or cultivation are not allowed for the betterment of the wildlife. India consists of 90 national parks including Gir National Park, Silent Valley National Park, Corbett National Park, Kanger Ghati National Park, etc.
What is the number of wildlife sanctuaries India consists of?

A protected area in which human activities like harvesting and collecting minor forest products are allowed such that they do not interfere with the well-being of animals and only the animals are conserved is known as a wildlife sanctuary. India consists of 448 wildlife sanctuaries including Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary, Mount Abu Wildlife Sanctuary, Jaldapara Wildlife Sanctuary, etc.
By which of the following techniques the gametes of threatened species are preserved in viable and fertile conditions for long periods?

The technique by which the gametes, organelles, cells, tissues, or any other biological construct is preserved by cooling the samples to very low temperatures such that they remain in viable and fertile conditions for long periods is known as cryopreservation. It is used for the conservation of the threatened species.
Which phenomenon does the coevolved plant-pollinator mutualism explain?

The coevolved plant-pollinator mutualism explains the phenomenon of co-extinction. Co-extinction is the phenomenon that tells when a species becomes extinct, the plant and animal species also become extinct that are obligatorily associated with the host species.
Why was the African catfish Clarias gariepinus introduced?

The African catfish Clarias gariepinus was introduced for aquaculture purposes. The introduction was illegal and posed a threat to the indigenous catfishes in our rivers due to disease introduction, competition, and environmental modification.

Eichhornia crassipes also known as water hyacinth. It was first introduced from South America into China that later on became a serious environmental problem. It reduces the sunlight penetration and lowers the oxygen content in the water which hampers the water ecosystem.
Which of the following contains chemicals like parthenin, is toxic to cattle and causes pollen allergy in humans?

The carrot grass also known as Parthenium is an erect and annual herb. It is responsible for environmental, medical, and agricultural hazards. It contains chemicals like parthenin, is toxic to cattle, and causes pollen allergy in humans.
What happened when the Nile perch was introduced into Lake Victoria in East Africa?
Increase in the number of cichlid fish

The cichlid fish, native of Lake Victoria in East Africa were extinct due to the introduction of an alien species that is the Nile perch. It destroyed nearly 200 species of cichlid fish through predation and competition for food.
What happens when alien species are introduced unintentionally or deliberately?
They turn invasive and cause an increase in species
They turn invasive and cause the decline or extinction of indigenous species

The unintentional or deliberate introduction of alien (new) species into a habitat causes the aliens to turn invasive thus causing the decline or extinction of indigenous species. They can affect all types of organisms (animals, plants, fungi, and microorganisms) and ecosystems.
What was the reason for the exploitation of the Steller’s sea cow and the passenger pigeon?

The excess and unsustainable use of resources is known as over-exploitation. Many species such as the Steller’s sea cow and the passenger pigeon have been lost in the last 500 years due to human activities such as poaching.
Which animals are badly affected when a large habitat is broken up into small fragments due to various human activities?

When a large habitat is broken up into small fragments due to various human activities, the migratory species are badly affected. These areas are fragmented by humans for agriculture and urban development.

Match the following;

National Park

Animal

Kanha

Rhinoceros

Kaziranga

Tiger

Gir

Lion

The correct order is;

National Park

State

Famous Animal

Kanha National Park

Madhya Pradesh

Tiger

Kaziranga National Park

Assam

Rhinoceros

Gir National Park

Gujarat

Asiatic Lion
Ramatirtha Conservation Centre in Odisha runs a conservation program for protecting which endangered species?

The Ramatirtha Conservation Centre in Odisha plays a vital role in safeguarding the mugger crocodile (Crocodylus palustris), an endangered species. Established within the Similipal Tiger Reserve, this center initially began with eggs and juveniles of muggers procured from Tamil Nadu. Since 1984, more than 600 muggers have been captive-bred and released into the Similipal region, contributing significantly to their conservation efforts. The mugger crocodile is a medium to large-sized crocodile.
